speechtext:
that Bill C-226, an act to reduce automotive pollution, be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Natural Resources envelope.
He said: Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to present Bill C-226 for debate in the House today.
This bill is called the automotive pollution reduction act. It requires that all automotive fuels in Canada contain at least 3.2 per cent oxygen and that the use of MMT be banned in Canada.
This bill sets out an implementation period of six months. Being a realist, I am prepared to accept an implementation period of two years from the date of passage. This change can be implemented in committee.
This is an important bill in this day of environmental concerns and the amount of automotive pollution taking place.
Because of incomplete gasoline combustion hydrocarbons are being released into the atmosphere. The three largest aromatic hydrocarbon components of gasoline are benzenes, toluenes and xylenes. They all have a serious health impact and have been placed on the Canadian Environmental Protection Agency's priority substance list.
Increasing the oxygen content requirement to 3.2 per cent will result in complete combustion of the fuel burning of these hydrocarbons. As a result, emissions are much cleaner.
Since the introduction of this bill the government has introduced its green plan initiative. I believe this bill dovetails the green plan very well and strengthens it.
Ground level ozone and greenhouse gases will be reduced. The government did take steps to reduce automotive pollutants as promised in the green plan in its 1992 budget announcement of a tax break for the ethanol portion of ethanol blended fuels. Although this is an important commitment and I applaud it, it is one that has to be strengthened.
Because of this initiative, United Co-operatives of Ontario now has ethanol for sale in 21 of its stations and gas bars in southwestern Ontario. The first was opened on May 28 in the riding of the member of Parliament for Kent.
Although the green plan has proposed tighter emission standards by 1994, the proposals in this bill before us today will have a more immediate effect by changing the formulation of fuels which will reduce the emissions without substantial redesign of pollution control devices.
By banning MMT it will keep present control devices operating effectively. For example, studies show that compared to regular unleaded MMT-free gasoline, a 10 per cent ethanol blended gasoline reduces automotive emissions as follows: carbon dioxide by 5.9 per cent; carbon monoxide by 25 per cent; volatile organic compounds by 8.5 per cent; nitrous oxide by 5.7 per cent; and urban ozone by 5.3 per cent. This is particularly significant if one considers that a 1984 Environment Canada study found that adding the allowable amount of MMT to gasoline increased hydrocarbon emissions by 27 per cent.

Private Members' Business
The Canadian Renewable Fuels Association predicts in its brief to the House of Commons committee on global warming that the use of a 10 per cent ethanol blended gasoline would mean a direct reduction of 10 per cent in toxic carbon dioxide emitted into the atmosphere once the photosynthesis process and benefit of by-products are taken into account.
Denver, Colorado reported an 8 per cent reduction in carbon monoxide levels after just two months of use of ethanol blended fuels.
In the course of our research, we found that Canada allowed the use of this gasoline additive that has been banned in the United States since 1978. The gasoline additive I am referring to is MMT.
In the most recent waiver application to have MMT reinstated into the automotive fuels in the United States, the amount requested was only half the amount allowed in Canada. The request was for 31 milligrams of manganese per U.S. gallon compared with 66 milligrams of manganese per U.S. gallon allowed in Canada. Why is it applying for a waiver using only half the amount currently being used in Canada?
This gasoline additive, methylcyclopentadienyl manganese tricarbonyl or MMT, was first banned in 1977 in California. One of the U.S. leaders in air pollution control, the California Air Resources Board, in response to the concern expressed by that state's department of health regarding the potential health hazard of the manganese additive officially requested that MMT be phased out of all gasoline sold in California, effectively banning its sale. In 1978, it was banned throughout the United States in unleaded gasoline by the Environmental Protection Agency of the United States government.
This discovery led to a whole series of revelations.
First of all, I discovered that Canada does not conduct emission testing with gasoline containing MMT as the Canadian testing standards cite the American code which prohibits the use of MMT in unleaded gasoline. Therefore, Canadian emission testing of new automobiles is conducted with MMT-free gasoline imported from the United States. Consequently, Canadian automobile emission testing is a fraud.
I also discovered that in June 1990 while I was drafting my legislation the Environmental Protection Agency was conducting hearings into a waiver application submitted
by Ethyl Corporation to reallow MMT in unleaded gasoline in the United States, again proposing to use half the amount currently being used in Canada.
Ellen Silbergeld of the University of Maryland, formerly with the Environmental Defense Fund served on the EPA peer review panel on the EPA's most recent health assessment document on manganese. In her testimony in Washington, D.C. on June 22, 1990 she stated:
Manganese, like lead, is a cumulative toxin in that both its absorption and retention as well as its toxicity increase with time. At present there are insufficient data on the low level chronic sequelae of manganese exposure, similar to the case that was made for lead in 1925.
That was 67 years ago and here we are going through the process again.
Dr. John Donaldson is one of Canada's top neurotox-ologists. He along with other recognized experts in the field, such as Dr. Frank Labella and Dr. Andre Barbeau, have conducted research on this issue. Dr. Donaldson was one of the scientists selected by the National Research Council of Canada to participate in the mideighties study entitled "Manganese and the Canadian Environment". Dr. Donaldson told the EPA in Washington on June 22, 1990:
-one of the major theories in leading edge neuroscience which relate to the environmental issues of today is that there are agents, neurotoxins-insidious neurotoxins like manganese which are age accelerating neurotoxins.
Most vulnerable to the MMT's toxic hit are unborn children, infants, and young children whose defence systems against the retention of manganese have not yet been fully developed.
Manganese in its normal form is not that dangerous; we have it in our food, in our bodies, and we have it in the earth. But in the form of MMT which comes out of the exhaust systems of cars is the area where we are most concerned.
To quote Dr. Donaldson:
What we are talking about here is that manganese is insidious, a stealth toxin, hitting early and perhaps often and then revealing the damage as we get older.
Dr. Donaldson's contention is supported by other scientists including Aljandro Daniels of the large pharmaceutical company Burroughs Wellcome. "I totally agree with Donaldson," he is quoted as saying on the basis of his own animal research.
June 15, 1992

The U.S. Congressional Energy and Commerce Committee, Subcommittee on Health and the Environment in a letter to the United States Environmental Protection Agency dated June 29, 1990 and signed by the chairman and three other members of the committee warned:
As a nation, we cannot afford to subject ourselves again to the tragic results of using a neurotoxic heavy metal in gasoline. Nor is the use of such a dangerous compound necessary, given the wide availability of octane enhancers that are a derivative from farm products, such as ETBE and ethanol, and are not hazardous air pollutants.
If anyone wishes to examine the credibility of corporate arguments and their environmental and public health record, North America's experience with lead and gasoline is the place to start.
To quote toxicologist Ellen Silbergeld again, she says:
MMT is exactly like lead. All you have to do is substitute the word "lead" and you will have what they said (back in 1925).
Again in the 1990s, the company that manufactures MMT in the United States for export to Canada argues the amount of manganese in gasoline is insignificant in health terms but very important to the U.S. economy. I should point out there is no MMT manufactured in Canada.
It should be noted this corporation has attempted four times to have the additive reallowed in United States fuel. The most recent attempt was denied by the EPA in January 1992.
EPA noted in its denial of waiver that five car manufacturers, Ford, General Motors, Toyota, Chrysler, and Nissan, as well as the Association of International Motor Vehicle Manufacturers, the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association, and Manufacturers of Emission Controls Association all recommended the denial of requests and expressed two major concerns with regard to the addition of MMT with unleaded gasolines.
Thus the intent of Bill C-226, an act to reduce automotive pollution is to ban MMT and to require that all gasoline sold in Canada contains 3.2 per cent oxygen.
Studies show a net energy benefit in the production of ethanol, taking into consideration such agriculture inputs as machinery fuel, fertilizer and ethanol production costs, such as processing heat and electricity.
If existing waste heat from another industry could be
Private Members' Business
utilized such as from Ontario Hydro's Douglas Point reactor on Lake Huron, then the net energy balance would be even better. Such utilization, plus modem technology would result in a balance of approximately four times the energy inputs required.
But the process squeezes more than ethanol from the feedstock. When ethanol is made from grain, the byproduct is a high protein stillage, a mash that includes original vitamins and minerals which can be used as an animal feed or as an additive for low nutrition human food.
This by-product can be dried and used as a flour for cookies, biscuits, bread or muffins. It is extremely low in calories and high in protein and fibre content. It will be of particular value for Third World countries and for starving children of which there are millions in Third World countries today. It has great potential as a low calorie health food right here in Canada.
In August 1991 Mohawk Fuels and Sask Pools opened an ethanol plant at Lanigan, Saskatchewan, with an adjacent feedlot to utilize the stillage for beef cattle production. It is projected that this will allow them to produce ethanol for as little as 27 cents a litre.
The financially fragile farm sector will benefit by producing grain for ethanol fuel.
Rural small town Canada too will gain financially from increased employment in the fuel ethanol plants which would have to be built and operated. In turn, the depopulation of Canada's rural areas would be reduced. In addition a new market would be created that would consume about one-fifth of Canada's grain production.
I hope that members on all sides of the House will support this bill. It will benefit our environment, this planet, our economy, and the health of the Canadian people, particularly our children.
Mr. Speaker, because of the number of members who wish to speak on this bill I request at this time that the House give consideration to allowing the members to split their 10-minute time slots into five-minute speeches. Would that be acceptable to the House?

Private Members' Business

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Hon. members have heard the terms of the motion. Is there unanimous consent to have five-minute speeches?
Agreed.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ken James (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Labour):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to participate in this debate on Bill C-226, an act to reduce automotive pollution. I would like to indicate that I have a variety of concerns about the bill.
MMT, the manganese-based gasoline additive, was first introduced in Canada in 1977. It was introduced into Canadian gasoline in 1978 and has been in continuous use since that time.
MMT is manufactured by the Ethyl Corporation of Canada which also distributes and sells the product to refineries in Canada. Ethyl has 170 employees located in my riding of Sarnia-Lambton.
I rise today to present Ethyl's concerns and interests. There are always two sides to a story. I would like to focus my remarks on three areas: concerns about MMT and health; MMT and the United States situation where the company made an application; and ethanol and MMT.
My friend and colleague from Lambton-Middlesex has raised concerns about the issue of MMT and health. Members of this House will be interested to know that like many natural substances, manganese can have a harmful effect if consumed or inhaled in large quantities. However, to produce adverse effects the exposure must be chronic. The level of airborne manganese also must be in excess of 1,000 micrograms per cubic meter.
All members of this House will know that many organizations have established exposure guidelines to ensure human safety, including the World Health Organization and the province of Ontario.
Ethyl's research has demonstrated that MMT use in gasoline will result in a maximum of approximately 0.02 micrograms per cubic metre, which is insignificant in terms of air quality and health concerns. This is 50 times less than the lowest standard listed by health organizations as safe. The World Health Organization lists one microgram per cubic metre as being safe. So the tests show that it is 50 times less than that.
At the same time, Ethyl Corporation has undertaken extensive research in this area to add to the scientific understanding of the way manganese affects human health. In 1985 the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency studied airborne manganese levels. The levels studied were approximately 10,000 times higher than the level that results from the use of the additive which is, as I noted earlier, 0.017 or as I used, 0.02 micrograms per cubic metre at the most.
The EPA determined that even at the level studied, which was of course 10,000 times higher showed, according to their statement as "caused or contributed to air pollution which may reasonably be anticipated to result in an increase in mortality or an increase in serious illness". Certainly they have indicated that even 10,000 times higher would not be a health concern.
Ross Associates, a group of respected toxicologists, conducted a comprehensive literature search on the health effects of manganese. Ross' literature search determined that "the anticipated increase of manganese in the environment from the use of MMT is sufficiently small in comparison to the natural levels of this element and human intake of it that the body's ability to maintain consistent manganese levels should be unaffected. Indeed, manganese is necessary for proper functioning of the human body; thus, no effect on health would be anticipated".
Let me turn to MMT and the United States situation, which my colleague brought up. Much attention has been directed to Ethyl Corporation's application to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency for permission to use MMT in unleaded gasoline. This request was based on a comprehensive series of tests to scientifically evaluate and document the effect of MMT on automobile tailpipe emissions and air quality.
The members of this House may find it interesting that these tests show conclusively that the additive does not harm the catalyst and, in fact, significantly reduces pollutants, especially nitrogen oxide and carbon monoxide. In fact, nitrogen oxide emissions are reduced by 20 per cent and carbon monoxide emissions by 7 per cent, with no practical effect on hydrocarbon emissions. Overall tailpipe emissions are reduced by 8 per cent.

Ethyl's testing program also showed that the use of MMT in unleaded gasoline will not adversely affect the ambient air concentration of manganese.
A study done for the company by Stanley Industrial Consultants Limited of Calgary went on to say, in summary: "This study examined changes in air emission patterns in the event that the use of the octane-enhancing additive MMT in Canadian gasoline is eliminated". The tests say: "The Fleet Test Program results indicate significant decreases in nitrogen oxide and carbon monoxide emissions and a slight increase in volatile organic substance emissions due to the presence of MMT".
The study also went on to say they estimate "that benzene in vehicle emissions will increase in the order of 5 to 10 per cent due to the increased aromatic content of gasolines without MMT".
The ability to use MMT in Canadian gasolines is of major importance to Canadian refiners and the driving public. If MMT is eliminated, nitrogen oxide emissions will increase. The addition of nitrogen oxide emissions will be approximately equivalent to an extra 500,000 vehicles on Canadian roadways in 1995 and 1.3 million additional vehicles in the year 2000.
Without MMT, Canadian refinery crude demands will increase by approximately 6,500 barrels per day, equivalent to $60 million a year in 1995, assuming crude is selling at $25.50 a barrel.
Capital needs of great consequence will be required by our refineries. It would affect the refinery in Sarnia. Esso is in a difficult productive mode at this time so it could have a serious effect. Some companies would need to spend millions of dollars of investment.
If MMT is eliminated from Canadian gasolines there will be increased emissions of nitrogen oxide, carbon monoxide, sodium dioxide and volatile organic substances, all of concern.
It is important to put on the record that Ethyl does not oppose the increased use of ethanol as a blended agent in gasoline. It clearly can reduce emissions of carbon monoxide and hydrocarbons but members will know that ethanol does not have the same attributes as MMT and
Private Members' Business
is mistakenly represented as an alternative to this additive.
I appreciate the opportunity to participate in this debate today on behalf of Ethyl Canada and its workers. In the interests of the public present studies should be examined as we evaluate this bill as presented by my colleague from Sarnia-Lambton.

Mr. Speaker, before getting into the main body of my remarks, I would like to note that the speaker who just finished at one point stated that a series of effects would follow from a positive series of assumptions, one of which was a $25.50 per barrel price for Canadian crude oil.
I must say that I desperately hope God is listening today and will take that suggestion to heart and effect it because I can tell you $25.50 for a barrel of oil would be welcome news in Alberta. I suppose that is beside the point of the discussion here today.
Mrs. Sparrow. How about Canadian dollars.

We even take Canadian dollars, $25.50.
Mrs. Sparrow. You want U.S.

Yes, that would be great. $25.50 U.S. would be wonderful, but $25.50 Canadian at this point would be really great too.
In general I must say that we in the New Democratic Party are in agreement with the notion underlying the bill, which is that of replacing hazardous additives in gasoline with less hazardous and much more environmentally friendly additives that can achieve much the same result.
Again, referring back to the member who just spoke, he enumerated a number of very nasty things that would happen were MMT to be removed from gasoline, but the majority of effects in that list are predicated on the assumption that no replacement would be placed in that gasoline that would have equivalent or similar effects.
Whereas it is true that MMT mitigates several environmentally unfriendly elements of gasoline at the moment, that mitigation can be achieved as well in most instances by other additives, including biomass derived ethanol which is what I want to concentrate on today.

June 15, 1992
Private Members' Business
I should note as well that we acknowledge the effort of the hon. member for Lambton-Middlesex in encouraging the greater use of ethanol. We agree whole-heartedly that the greater use of biomass derived ethanol could expand Canada's domestic market for grains.
In fact, testimony last year before the Standing Committee on Energy, Mines and Resources indicated that a 10 per cent blend of ethanol, which is to say 10 per cent ethanol to 90 per cent gasoline, would require 3.45 billion litres of ethanol annually and would consume 9 to 10 million tonnes of grain annually. Canada's annual production of principal grains now totals between 50 and 60 million tonnes. Therefore, ethanol production, were it to reach the 10 per cent blend level in all gasoline sold in Canada, would require the equivalent of slightly less than 20 per cent of the entire Canadian annual grain harvest at present. That would be a real boon for grain producers.
I would also note that we agree with the hon. member's contention that ethanol use should be stimulated because this would be good for the environment. That is clearly the case. It is the case not just because of its additive qualities but because biomass generated ethanol is derived using carbon that is already in our biosphere and to the degree it is used it backs out carbon that is dredged up from the lithosphere and added as new carbon to the biosphere. Therefore, for every litre of ethanol you use in preference to a litre of gasoline, you have stopped the introduction of that new equivalent amount of carbon into our biosphere. That is the principal environmentally sound attribute of ethanol in our contention and one that ought always to be borne in mind when we consider the question of ethanol use.
Unfortunately, if passed in its current form, this bill would only achieve part of what it sets out to accomplish. The bill would succeed in banning methylcyclopentadie-nyl manganese tricarbonyl, or MMT, a manganese-containing compound for which there are legitimate health concerns despite the submission of the previous speaker, but it would not ban other hazardous compounds like the aromatics toluene, benzene and the family of xylenes. These are veiy worrisome elements in current gasoline and are left unaddressed by the bill. However, again, it would ban the methylcyclopentadienyl manganese tricarbonyl.
The bill's biggest failing, however, is that it would not succeed in encouraging the greater use of ethanol derived from agricultural products and byproducts or from wood waste. By stipulating that no gasoline sold in Canada, and I quote from the bill "has an oxygen content of less than 3.2 per cent by weight", the bill would allow the use, not just of ethanol, but as well of MTBE or methyl tertiary butyl ether and ETBE, ethyl tertiary butyl ether.
MTBE is a petroleum-based product. It does not stimulate domestic markets for grain. It does not result in reduced C02 emissions. But, because it is produced by the oil industry and because it is easily shipped through pipelines, MTBE is the additive of choice for that industry which is why, for example, a large new methyl tertiary butyl ether plant was recently built in Edmonton. The bill would essentially result in the replacement of MMT with MTBE, not with ethanol.
As for the use of ETBE, the bill does not stipulate that ETBE, although derived from ethanol, be derived from ethanol produced from grain or wood. The same with ethanol itself. Therefore, the same problem could arise in that you would be using lithospheric carbons to generate this new additive rather than using the biospheric carbons we have available.
However, the bill in its principle is a commendable one. Its elements can be individually addressed and repaired in committee. Therefore, the New Democrat caucus will be supporting this bill at second reading and attempting to get it into committee where what we submit are salutary changes could be made.

Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure for me to rise today and speak in full and complete support of the private member's bill by my colleague, the hon. member for Lambton-Middlesex. It is not very often that a private bill of such merit and importance gets called for debate in the House. This bill is well-researched, well-intentioned and totally worthy of support. However, I would expect nothing less from the member whose riding borders mine in southwestern Ontario.
This bill would require all gasoline sold in Canada to have a minimum oxygen content of 3.2 per cent. That is consistent with the original draft of the U.S. Clean Air Act of 1988.
June 15, 1992

Hundreds of my own constituents have signed petitions calling on the government for more action on ethanol with a legislated blend. Indeed, this comes on the heels of a meeting in my riding on March 23, attended by over 350 people. It was sponsored by the Kent Federation of Agriculture and the Chatham and District Chamber of Commerce and chaired by Stephen McGrail, president of the Kent Com Producers Association.
We all met to determine the possibilities of locating an ethanol industry in Kent county. It makes both economic and environmental sense, since my riding is the number one com producer in all of Canada. It is the fuel of the future while creating other markets for our grains and helping the local economy.
Environmentally friendly green gas was pumped for the first time in Ontario last month in Chatham in my riding of Kent.
Frank Anthony, president of the Ontario Com Producers Association, said that the move to ethanol at UCO's 21 Ontario stations will generate about $57 million dollars from 22.5 million bushels of com in the province.
My riding alone has over 5,000 com producers. Industry predictions indicate that 20 per cent of the Ontario corn production, some 200 million bushels, will go into the making of ethanol.
In 1990, Ontario drivers used over 12 billion litres of gasoline not including gasoline for aviation, marine, farming, construction, transportation or other off-road transportation. That accounts for over one-third of the 31.8 billion litres of gas used across the country. With that ethanol represents a lucrative market. While it cannot be used alone in conventional engines, when one part of ethanol is mixed with nine parts of gasoline, it becomes a viable alternative.
In the United States, 375 million bushels of com annually are distilled into fuel ethanol. That could grow to one billion bushels within the next seven years. The market is there so we now have to meet the demand.
Due to the clean burning and renewable nature, ethanol fuel blends were recently awarded the eco logo
Private Members' Business
by Environment Canada. This is the first time any transportation fuel was ever granted the logo.
This private members' bill is important both to help the environment and our agricultural economy. Plagued with drought, low commodity prices and rising costs, farmers have taken a battering in recent years. The situation has become so bad that there have been predictions that the family farm will disappear within the next generation.
The Chatham ethanol consortium is showing the type of forward thinking attitude needed as it conducts a feasibility study on whether or not a plant can be located in the city.
My colleagues will speak more about the dangers of MMT. My friend from Lambton-Middlesex has spoken out often and strongly for the banning of this deadly additive.
It is useful to point out that the Leader of the Opposition is the first federal party leader to support the use of ethanol and abandon the use of MMT in Canada.
We have consistently shown leadership on this issue by developing the policies for the future. Indeed, I was a member of the Standing Committee on Environment when in 1990 we released a report calling on the government to introduce a major research development and demonstration program to reduce greenhouse gases. This has already been done for ethanol. It is something positive that we can do right here in our own backyard to reduce global warming and thinning of the ozone layer.
I congratulate the member for Lambton-Middlesex for his fortitude and determination in sticking with this proposal, for developing this important private members' bill and for his leadership on this issue.
This bill is worthy of support by members on all sides of this House. Environment and agriculture need this type of initiative and Canadians are demanding concrete action. I am proud to support this bill and the efforts of my colleague from Lambton-Middlesex.

Mr. Speaker, I am happy to have five minutes to speak in support of this bill, Bill C-226, a private members' bill proposed by my colleague from Lambton-Middlesex. There are so many winners in this particular bill that I just cannot imagine why the entire House would not get behind it.

June 15, 1992
Private Members' Business
I will not go into all of the benefits that would accrue to the agricultural industry in this country. I will not go into all of the benefits in terms of new job creation that would result because of the fact that it is a new industry that would result with a commitment to this fuel. I would like to focus on the reduction of C02s.
You have to understand that in a city like Toronto we probably have 50 to 60 per cent of the entire C02 emissions of this entire country. If you fly into Toronto on a day like today, you can see the smog hovering over the city. If you ever have an opportunity, Mr. Speaker, to visit Toronto you will just be amazed at the Don Valley Parkway, the 401 highway, east and west, the Trans-Canada Highway and our Gardiner Expressway to the south. For at least five hours of every day these major thoroughfares are like parking lots. The health hazard that exists because of the emissions that are coming from the automobiles right now in the city of Toronto are unquestionably a danger to the health of that community.
In fact, in 1986 when there were air quality monitoring stations in Toronto, during an eight-hour maximum period that they were monitoring the air quality, at that time just at Yonge Street in downtown Toronto there were over 10 different times that the levels had exceeded the recommended amount by over seven times. This was in 1986. The situation is worse right now.
A member of Parliament has put forward a private members' bill which is going to reduce this toxic emission, and that is what it is. Doctors from all over the world are saying that this MMT is showing health effects that are certainly hazardous. I listened to the member for Samia-Lambton who had a different point of view. I cannot imagine all of these doctors from all around the world putting forward their position unless there was some scientific and substantive basis to their concern. I do not really see how we cannot get behind this bill.
From a member representing an urban area of close to
2.5	million people where we are just a step away form wearing masks in that city, those of us who are responsible for urban areas plead with this House for support. Anything that would reduce the toxic emissions into our community is something that we hope all members from all regions of this House would get behind.
For this particular fuel there is scientific information that shows that this ethanol fuel reduces these toxic emissions by close to 60 per cent and so we are pleading for support of this bill.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Belsher (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure for me to rise and speak to this motion which was brought forward by the hon. member opposite. The issue under discussion here today is whether we might by requiring some change in the way gasoline is produced in Canada create some benefits for the citizens of Canada in the form of a cleaner or a healthier environment.
The changes proposed in Bill C-226 would require the elimination of the anti-knock additive MMT and the addition of a fuel oxygenate, likely ethanol.
The United States has recently completed a thorough review of the potential for various changes to gasoline quality to address a variety of environmental concerns in several parts of that country. This process included extensive consultation with concerned parties, environmental groups, health authorities, vehicle manufacturers, fuel producers. The outcome, the Clean Air Act amendments of 1990, represents the consensus of all these parties about which gasoline specifications will improve the local air quality.
However, since different parts of the United States have different environmental problems, it is not surprising there are several so-called reformulated gasolines with the properties of an individual fuel being set to address most effectively the environmental concerns of the specific region where it will be sold.
Under the Clean Air Act amendments of 1990, gasoline sold in winter months in the 44 cities which exceed carbon monoxide standards must contain at least 2 per cent oxygen, rising to 2.7 per cent in 1992.
In addition, reformulated gasoline must be used in the 10 areas most severely exceeding the desired ozone levels beginning in 1995. This gasoline must have a 2 per cent oxygen content year round. Ethanol and MTBE, an ether produced from methanol and butane, can both be used to meet this requirement. The demand for ethanol and MTBE.are therefore expected to increase in the U.S.
June 15, 1992

The Clean Air Act regulations also provided for a waiver to allow fuel blends containing 10 per cent ethanol to exceed the standard for Reid vapour pressure by one pound per square inch. This higher vapour pressure however increases the fuel's tendency to emit hydrocarbon vapours and so the state of New Jersey, which is veiy concerned about local smog problems caused by high ozone levels, is currently refusing to allow alcohol fuel blends to exceed the normal vapour pressure. The Environmental Protection Agency's proposed regulations on reformulated gasoline released on April 16, 1992 do not provide a waiver for RVP.
That may have a number of effects such as giving preference to MTBE and affecting planned ethanol production expansion. Already the largest producer in the U.S., Archer, Daniels and Midland has cancelled a planned ethanol production expansion. It may require that petroleum producers provide a special tailored, in other words a lower RVP base gasoline for blending with ethanol. Various options to reach a compromise on standards for oxygenates in gasoline are yet being discussed in the U.S.
Canada too has its gasoline reformulation agenda. Government officials are reviewing the extensive information coming out of the U.S. process to determine how it applies to Canada's situation. They are beginning to consult with the many parties who will be affected by any decision to change gasoline specifications. They are beginning a dialogue with vehicle and fuel manufacturers in Canada to discover what changes are possible in Canada, what their effect on air quality might be, and what will be the likely cost to Canadians. Provincial governments, which largely have jurisdiction over fuel specifications, will have to be actively involved in this process.
Four years ago the concerted efforts of the government resulted in the most powerful piece of environmental legislation in the history of this country. Proclaimed as an act of Parliament on June 30, 1988, the Canadian Environmental Protection Act gave the government the legislative power to address the kind of issues raised in Bill C-226 in a rigorous and comprehensive way.
Private Members' Business
Sections 46 and 47 of the CEPA provided a comprehensive regulatory framework to prohibit the production or importation for the use or sale of any fuel that contains an element, component or additive in a concentration or quantity that exceeds the concentration or quantity prescribed with respect to that element, component or additive in relation to the fuel when in the opinion of the Governor in Council the combustion of the fuel would result in a significant contribution to air pollution.
This government went much further than that. In May 1989 the Ministers of the Environment and Transport announced a five-year plan to reduce emissions from internal combustion engines.
In 1990 the green plan reinforced several pollution issues such as smog, toxins and climate changes to name only a few which will result in several strategies to achieve the objective of a clean and healthy environment in a sound and prosperous economy for future generations of Canadians.
Energy, Mines and Resources; Environment Canada; Transport Canada; Industry, Science and Technology; and Health and Welfare are reviewing all aspects of gasoline formulations. They will workshop the complex subject of gasoline formulations with representatives from provincial ministries, consumer environmental groups, members of the petroleum industry, the motor vehicle industry, and consultants in the near future.
The cost of fuel quality changes to improve the environment will likely be high. A forecast of the capital expenditures required for refining and marketing by the industry to the year 2000 has been estimated at between $12 billion to $31 billion depending on what changes will be required. This estimate includes ongoing capital expenditures, low sulphur diesel, reformulated gasoline, stationary source emission control, and other refinery modifications for environmental controls.
Members of the House should be reminded that there is already in place a comprehensive review and consultation process as well as a regulatory framework to assist the linkages between gasoline components and air pollution. These comprehensive technical and social economic reviews will provide facts to assist government in addressing the need to make changes to existing gasoline

June 15, 1992
Government Orders
formulations to respond to environmental issues and concerns.
I doubt at this time that there has been sufficient data on the use of oxygenates in motor vehicle fuels and the effect on air quality in the Canadian urban areas.
Therefore I would make the point that I cannot support Bill C-225, given its restrictive nature and its failure to address a number of important factors which impact on the entire issue of automotive fuels and air pollution.

Mr. Speaker, it gives me a great deal of privilege to stand in the House today to give full support to this bill which I believe is a bill of common sense, a bill that is bringing the pollution question forward and giving a reasonable way to bring a solution to something which has become a major problem not only in this country but world-wide.
We all watched very much with interest at what was happening in Brazil with the environmental talks. I heard the minister for this country state: "We are entering a new era of environmental development". I believe it is the responsibility of this government to enter that era along with the minister if the minister is heading in that direction. However I do not see a move when I hear statements from the ministry or getting close to the ministry: "We do not have enough information". I believe that is wrong.
The information is there from a multitude of sources, information enough that could fill this room with environmental problems from auto emissions and other types of emissions in this world.
Before I continue though I want to offer my congratulations to my colleague, the member for Lambton- Middlesex. He has taken it upon himself to put together a tremendous background of research information and possibly that backgroung of research information should be pushed on to our government if it does not see research is there.
I really have a strong question about the availability of research. It is not because it has not been done, but if I understand that the United States has banned a product since 1977, the research must clearly show that this product is not acceptable to the majority of North
Americans. Certainly the track record of the United States has not been up front and first in the race to clear up environmental problems. When it has taken the initiative to ban MMT, we must be aware that there are negatives and there is proof. We have to stop that type of emission occurring.
The product itself is causing, as my colleague earlier stated, a manganese problem which becomes accumulative and may cause a tremendous amount of neurological damage to young, old and all people alike.
It is important to understand then that there are great volumes of information which tell us that MMT is not an acceptable product to be used in our country. Canadian emission testing does not use MMT. That seems to be a fraud in itself. When we do not see the product itself being used in the testing that we are sending out results on, there must be a major reason for concern. In that case I would question the whole process of testing itself.
It must be remembered that our goal is a goal of a cleaner atmosphere, a goal of a better environment for people to live in. Certainly MMT is not the only product we are talking about within this bill. We are also suggesting that we raise the oxygen content of our fuels up to a percentage of 3.2 by weight. That would-

speakeroldname: Mr. Robert D. Nault (Kenora-Rainy River) moved:
speechtext:
Motion No. 1.
That Bill C-51 be amended in Clause 5 by striking out line 1 and the heading preceding line 1 at page 4 and substituting the following therefor:
"Application
5. (1) In the event of any inconsistency between the provisions of this Act and the provisions of any land claim agreements affecting the Northwest Territories, concluded between aboriginal peoples of Canada and Her Majesty, the provisions of the land claim agreements prevail to the extent of the inconsistency.
(2) Nothing in this Act, the regulations or".
He said: Mr. Speaker, it gives me great pleasure this morning to rise in the House to debate Bill C-51, an act
Government Orders
respecting water resources in the Northwest Territories. There will be a bit of confusion today as we get into these two bills because Bill C-51 and Bill C-52 are so similar. Those who are watching us at home will have to watch very carefully because they are tied together and what we are doing is simply taking one bill and splitting it into two bills. There will be some very technical amendments, as people at home will notice, that we are talking about which in essence will make the new bill more consistent with the old bill.
I want to talk for a moment about Motion No. 1 and of course Motion No. 2 which was the identical one submitted by the hon. member for Nunatsiaq. I want to read it for the folks. It relates to the application of this particular bill to ongoing land claims in the Northwest Territories under Bill C-51 and also under Bill C-52 in Yukon.
It states:
In the event of any inconsistency between the provisions of this act and the provisions of any land claim agreements affecting the Northwest 'Iferritories, concluded between aboriginal peoples of Canada and Her Majesty, the provisions of the land claim agreements prevail to the extent of the inconsistency.
I am aware, after discussions with the government, that it will not be accepting our amendment. I tend to think this is a grave mistake for the simple reason that in committee, as we discussed this, we became aware that this legislation, Bill C-51 as well as Bill C-52, would have to be amended on a fairly regular basis because of the inconsistencies in it as it relates to the land claim settlements that are ongoing and, of course, those that have already been accepted. I use the Gwich'in land claim as an example of that.
I want to inform the House that the Northwest Territories Water Board calls the Northwest Territories water bill an interim measure because the inconsistencies in it in relation to the land claims are so glaring and so obvious.
I want to quote the minister, who is here today, as to the relation between land claims and these bills. The minister has agreed there are going to be some problems with this particular situation. He agrees the land claims will have to take precedence over the bills we are debating today.

Government Orders
I want to quote the minister in his press release of December 12, 1991 when he introduced the bills in this House:
Aboriginal rights and management roles concerning water resources may be defined and set out in future comprehensive claim settlement legislation. Where there is any inconsistency between these acts and future claim settlement legislation, the latter will prevail.
That is exactly the intention of the motion before us today, to show the inconsistencies and the glaring differences between what the land claim negotiations will give aboriginal people in the Northwest Territories and the legislation itself in this particular bill and the powers under it.
What I am suggesting is not something that is earth shattering. Basically what I am asking the government to do is acknowledge the fact we will have to revisit these particular bills as land claims go through the system and are negotiated and approved in the Northwest Territories.
In Yukon that may not be as difficult because there is only one group involved in negotiations in that particular area, but if we take a look at all the different aboriginal groups in the Northwest Territories, as many as five or six different negotiations may be undertaken over a period of a few years and we will be continually revisiting this legislation.
It is imperative that governments at all levels be very straightforward and frank with those who are involved in these licensing processes in those jurisdictions, that they understand there is going to be some revisiting of these particular bills in the future. It will not have to be a process of word of mouth to particular groups be it either the mining companies or individual user groups. They will understand there are land claim negotiations going on and they, as individuals who are concerned or interested in doing business in the Northwest Territories will be apprised of all changes as they go through because we have recognized that is a necessity in the bill.
What we did ask for in committee, what we suggested to the government and to the minister through discussions with his staff and with the parliamentary secretary, is that this particular legislation should be delayed somewhat in order for the Council of Yukon Indians, who wanted to make a further presentation to the different groups in the Northwest Territories, to have more input into this particular legislation.
It seems to me that this has been going on, and the government will say so when it has an opportunity, since 1988. It needs these technical changes in order to get on with a more modem process of dealing with water and the environment in the Northwest Territories and the Yukon.
I would ask the government to consider our amendment simply because it is more straightforward. It deals with the most important aspect of the issues that are ongoing in the Northwest Territories and the Yukon, and that is the land claims process that we hear so much about and so often in this place.
If we as parliamentarians can acknowledge the fact that this is an interim measure and that applicants for licences in the Northwest Territories and the Yukon are aware of it, then they will deal with their business accordingly. This is the most appropriate way to govern and to do business in this place and indeed all across Canada.
I think I have presented our concerns as a party in relation to Motions Nos. 1 and 2. We feel it would be to the government's benefit to consider looking at this in detail in order not to make it any more confusing than it already is for those who have been trying to follow these two bills in the last few years. Because of the processes that are going on in the Northwest Territories and the Yukon, they can expect these bills to be revisited on a regular basis as time goes on.
I ask the government again to consider accepting this amendment as it is a very legitimate amendment considering the facts that I have outlined today.

speakeroldname: Hon. Thomas Siddon (Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development):
speakerposition: Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am honoured to be able to play a role in this important debate on Bills C-51 and C-52, when we come to those amendments momentarily.
At this point I want to respond to the amendments just put forward and explained by the hon. member for Kenora-Rainy River. He would have provided in Motion No. 1 for an amendment to clause 5(1) suggesting that in the event of any inconsistency between the provisions of the proposed amendment to Bill C-51, and the provisions of any land claim agreement affecting the Northwest Territories that the provisions of the land
June 15, 1992

claim agreement prevail to the extent of the inconsistency.
I certainly understand the spirit of the hon. member's proposal and that also put forward as Motion No. 2 by the member for Nunatsiaq. As the land claim agreements are being negotiated both in the Northwest Territories and the Yukon, it is anticipated that certain of the existing laws of general application will be affected, as will policies and regulations flowing from that legislation at the time.
When the land claim settlement legislation and selfgovernment legislation is presented to Parliament, if there is then any overriding or paramount effect caused by the legislation which establishes the legal basis for the land claim agreements, then the question of paramount-cy will be determined at that time.
At present there are four northern land claims agreements under negotiation. All of these agreements could affect many federal statutes, not merely Bills C-51 and C-52. But the paramountcy of those agreements is not necessarily an unqualified general right; it will be determined in a way which also respects certain of the overriding laws of Canada. Therefore, when the land claim agreements are finalized, they will be implemented through settlement legislation brought before this House and debated in this Chamber.
The individual agreements will set out the matters which these settlement acts must address and the manner in which inconsistencies or conflicts with federal legislation shall be dealt with. Legal working groups within the claims negotiation process will develop the necessary consequential amendments to federal legislation.
Therefore, I would submit that the inclusion of a general amendment such as the one advocated by the hon. member for Kenora-Rainy River would constitute a precedent in that it would anticipate the conclusion of negotiations, the ratification by aboriginal groups and the governments affected, of the provisions of those settlement acts. If one were to make an anticipatory amendment of this nature it invites the question: Why not amend all federal statutes that will ultimately be affected by claims negotiations?
To come to the point, the inclusion of such a provision now would pre-judge the manner of implementing future land claim agreements and the specific develop-
Govemment Orders
ment of legislation which enshrines the principle of paramountcy in those jurisdictions which will be affected when that legislation is brought before the House.
So the government at this time, while understanding the spirit and the intention of the proposal made by the hon. member, is not able to support the amendment at this time.

Mr. Speaker, my constituency of Prince Albert-Churchill River has a fair amount of water that flows into the Mackenzie River system through Lake Athabasca and the Athabasca River system.
I would like to rise in support of Motion No. 1 which states that in the event of any inconsistency' between the provisions of this act and the provisions of any land claim agreements affecting the Northwest Territories concluded between aboriginal peoples of Canada and Her Majesty, the provisions of the land claim agreements prevail to the extent of the inconsistency.
That is an excellent amendment to be proposing at this time. We have just heard the minister indicate his rationale for not accepting that particular provision, but I really think that he has in many ways side-stepped the question.
First of all, he says that paramountcy as envisioned here is not necessarily binding or unqualified in all areas. This contradicts a quotation of the minister, contained in a press release which he sent out on December 12 which says that "aboriginal rights and management roles concerning water resources may be defined and set out in future comprehensive claims settlement legislation". The press release continued: "Where there is any inconsistency' between these acts and future land claims legislation, the latter will prevail". Those were the words of the minister at the time.
As I understand the amendment before us, it intends to include that thought, those words virtually, in the legislation before us. It seems to me when the minister issues a press release to the nation arguing that if there are any inconsistencies, that the land claim settlement will be paramount, that the latter will prevail, in his precise words, and now he argues that it is not necessarily the case, that kind of inconsistency really starts to undermine the good faith that has to underlie these negotiations.

June 15, 1992
Government Orders
I have some experience with these negotiations with constituents of my own. The Dene people of northern Saskatchewan, as well as those in northern Manitoba, have been very frustrated in dealing with this ministry and, with all due respect, with this minister regarding their traditional uses of the territories. There has not been, in many cases, an atmosphere of goodwill surrounding these talks.
For the minister to argue that while there may be inconsistencies and the negotiated land settlements may not prevail, and that is essentially what he is arguing, really serves to undermine the goodwill that needs to underlie these negotiations.
Also, the minister said this was anticipatory of what may happen and that if we were to make these kinds of amendments, then we should make amendments to all other legislation which the land claims negotiations might affect in the future.
In some ways it is a bit of a specious argument and I guess he needed to also round out his remarks. The fact is this is the legislation before us and the other bills are not before us. Therefore, it is not particularly germane to suggest that we would get into all of those at the same time. However, if we are to demonstrate our good faith in these ongoing negotiations at this critical time in history, as they do come up it is very important that they become recognized before the House.
It is important for the aboriginal people and all other people in this country to know that Parliament is taking seriously the general trend in constitutional negotiations toward self-government, the trend in the courts toward interpretation of aboriginal rights which very liberally interpret the right to traditional hunting, fishing and gathering rights and other trends in our society. It is incumbent upon Parliament not only to recognize those but, in fact, to show some leadership which we could do by accepting this particular amendment.
As well, I would like to make reference to the fact that the issue of water is a very substantial part of the negotiations which are under way with respect to claims agreements in the Yukon and Northwest Territories.
I note in testimony by the Council for Yukon Indians on April 28, 1992 before the committee studying this legislation that about 12 pages in the umbrella agreement initialled in November are devoted to water management. It is a very critical aspect of that whole agreement. In that chapter it does something very important in establishing a new use not recognized in the Yukon Waters Act, the traditional use for Yukon Indian persons for purposes of trapping, non-commercial harvesting, transportation, traditional heritage, culture and spiritual purposes. This is a traditional use that is very much a part of the negotiations that are under way. In fact, it is something that the federal government has already initialled.
My understanding is that this particular legislation before us does not even make reference to this new and very important right for native people and important use as far as regulating waters are concerned that will come into being with the finalization of these agreements.
I do not blame the people of the north, particularly the Dene and the Yukon Indians, for feeling that if we proceed with this legislation without recognition of this important new use which is a part of all the new negotiations at a time when we are negotiating self-government agreements and other agreements that will fundamentally change the jurisdictional relationship between native peoples and the Government of Canada and if we proceed without recognition in this legislation through the amendment that has been proposed, we are going to fall behind the course of history and might well be creating difficulties down the road as we proceed with these negotiations.

And No. 8, Mr. Speaker. I will talk about that at the same time. Let me again talk about these motions all in one lump and try and put them in a context that would be easily explainable to our folks back home and of course to the members who have not been following these bills as closely as they could.
First of all, we understand the difficulties that the Table had with Motion No. 8. We are aware that it does go somewhat outside of the legislation. What we had intended on doing with Motion No. 8 was merely to lift clause 50 which is in the Yukon Waters Act and transfer it into the Northwest Territories Waters Act. This is a clause that deals with the Northern Canada Power Commission in the Northwest Territories. What we are attempting to do in a technical sense, in the hope of reducing confusion, is take a particular clause out of the Yukon bill that deals with the Northwest Territories and deals with the Northern Canada Power Commission, which is in the Northwest Territories, and put it into the legislation that we are now talking about.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: I do not like to interrupt the hon. member, but we checked on Motion No. 8 and it is possible to group that motion with the other motions. Debate is on all motions, including Motion No. 8.

Mr. Speaker, as I said the first time I rose, I felt that it was going to be an interesting day because of how things were structured here. Of course, we are seeing that.
I would like to take this opportunity to thank the members of the NDP and the government for giving us unanimous consent to put this motion on the floor of the House of Commons because it is a very appropriate one. It is more of a technical one. Again, it is one that we are trying to deal with to reduce the confusion that is within the original bill.
When we divide the bill into two separate bills, of course, we would like to remove clause 50 out of the Yukon Waters Act and put it in the Northwest Territories Waters Act because the Northern Canada Power Commission deals specifically with the Northwest Territories.
I will go back to all the motions to try to explain the technical aspects of these particular motions in order to put some semblance of understanding before the House.
The motions are technical amendments which respond to concerns expressed more so by the Northwest Territories Water Board than anyone. In fact, Motions Nos. 3 through 9 are all transitional amendments which have been, if I can be so bold, accepted by the government and the opposition as amendments that would be accepted because of their technical nature.
The transitional provisions which are the bridge between the current Northern Inland Waters Act and the new Yukon and Northwest Territories water bills are all contained in the Yukon bill.
It is somewhat baffling to come across references to the Northwest Territories in the Yukon Act. It is equally disconcerting to read the Northwest Territories water bill as it currently stands and see no reference whatsoever to any transitional provisions.
When the Northwest Territories Water Board appeared before the legislative committee in April, this issue was raised. I will quote from the remarks made by the chairman of the Northwest Territories Water Board on this matter: "If a licensee picked up a copy of Bill C-51, he would not know whether his licences were going to lapse when this comes into effect, or what was going to happen to him. He would not know who to
June 15, 1992

phone or whether the old board was going to be in business after the new act came into place".
"We found afterwards that these transitional provisions had been put into Bill C-52 so you could either address this concern by putting the same or similar transitional provisions into Bill C-51 or alternatively, writing to every licensee and doing a public relations campaign to make sure they know where that information is available".
As you can see, there is a lot of confusion as to how things will apply once we split one bill into two. What is suggested by these technical amendments is to remove references to the Northwest Territories from the Yukon bill and to put the transitional provisions of one bill into another bill. I hope that does not confuse anyone, because it sometimes confuses me.
Clause 45 of the Yukon Waters Act, for example, says that persons who were members of the Yukon Territory Water Board or the Northwest Territories Water Board before the coming into force of this act continue as such thereafter.
Motion No. 3 creates a similar clause 45 for the Northwest Territories Waters Act. We have in this case struck out the reference to the Northwest Territories Water Board in the Yukon bill and put it as a new clause 45 in the Northwest Territories bill.
In essence, to make a long story short, these technical amendments are basically the process of removing references of one particular area in one bill that do not relate to that particular area.
Of course, Motion No. 8 on which we just got unanimous consent was somewhat different in that it dealt with the Northern Canada Power Commission as it relates to the Northwest Territories and, for the sake of removing confusion, we are hoping to take that particular clause when we get into discussion of Bill C-52 out of that particular bill completely and put it into the Northwest Territories Waters Act.
That explanation is as concise as I can give in the short time I have to explain the technical amendments. It is my understanding, and I hope it is correct, that the government accepts those amendments. It is also my understanding that the New Democratic Party accepts those
Government Orders
amendments. Basically they are ones to clarify the two different bills as they were lumped together in one bill.

speakeroldname: Hon. Thomas Siddon (Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development):
speakerposition: Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the government is prepared to accept the amendments put forward by the hon. member for Kenora-Rainy River to Bill C-51, Motions Nos. 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 and 9.
I certainly understand the confusion as it has been described by the hon. member for Kenora-Rainy River which appeared to arise from cross-references in the alternate pieces of legislation when each was to have been a self-standing bill affecting either Yukon or the Northwest Territories water act.
Bill C-51 and Bill C-52 are drafted in such a way that they both must come into force at the same time since they will replace one existing statute, the Northern Inland Waters Act. Thus the legislative drafters felt that the transitional provisions need only appear in one of the bills. Bill C-52 was chosen to repeal the existing Northern Inland Waters Act, so it also contains all the transitional provisions for both Yukon and Northwest Territories, hence the confusion.
As the member has pointed out, when the legislative committee was reviewing these bills one of the witnesses, specifically the Northwest Territories Water Board, indicated that some confusion among the affected stakeholders might arise due to the absence of these transitional provisions in Bill C-51.
I want to thank the hon. members for Nunatsiaq and Kenora-Rainy River for their co-operation in putting forth these important amendments. Their adoption will only help to improve and clarify these bills for all the affected stakeholders.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to rise and briefly indicate that on behalf of the New Democratic Party we will also be supporting the motions currently before us. I think it behoves us all to try and make sure that the legislation that we produce in this Chamber be as watertight-I guess that is the proper word-in this particular debate as possible.
Therefore it was important that some of these technical changes be made to ensure that the legislation is clear. I as well would like to thank the members who

Government Orders
have put hard work and effort into making sure that this legislation is as complete as possible.
