speakeroldname: Mr. Robert D. Nault (Kenora-Rainy River) moved:
speechtext:
Motion No. 1.
That Bill C-52 be amended in Clause 5 by striking out line 7 and the heading preceding line 7 at page 4 and substituting the following therefor:
"Application
5. (1) In the event of any inconsistency between the provisions of this Act and the provisions of any land claim agreements affecting the Yukon Territory, concluded between aboriginal peoples of Canada and Her Majesty, the provisions of the land claim agreements prevail to the extent of the inconsistency.
(2) Nothing in this Act, the regulations or".
He said: Mr. Speaker, we are now debating Bill C-52, which is the Yukon water bill. What we are tiying to achieve with the amendment that I have presented and classified as Motion No. 1 is the same thing I attempted to do in debate under Bill C-51, namely, to put in the legislation a transitional clause regarding inconsistencies between the provisions of this act and the provisions of
June 15, 1992

any land claims agreements affecting the Yukon Territory concluded between the aboriginal people of Canada and Her Majesty. Those land claim agreements will prevail to the extent of the inconsistencies.
I listened very intently to the minister's response and rationale to my amendment under Bill C-51. I find it somehow difficult to understand the approach by the government on this particular amendment. The necessity of being consistent in these particular pieces of legislation related to the land claims negotiations is obviously completely impossible.
Therefore, what is going to be negotiated when there is a land claim may vary depending on the particular group the government is negotiating with. The particular aboriginal group in that area may decide that there are certain provisions necessary in its land claims agreement but which are not necessary to another group. In essence, every particular land claims negotiation will be unique in certain respects.
Therefore, what we are suggesting is during the negotiations that the government will undertake with the four or five different groups during the period of the next few years, and I hope it does not take much longer than that, the government will go into these negotiations with the understanding that the land claims settlements enacted through the negotiations will take precedence over this particular piece of legislation. This is in order that the traditional users of this particular resource in a particular area will have the ability and the jurisdiction to control that piece of land and the waters that flow in and out of that land to the point of giving them the jurisdiction and the wherewithal to deal with the problems that may occur within that boundary.
If the minister suggests that is not necessary, once the land claim is settled we would have to go back to the House to amend these particular pieces of legislation every single time. It seems to me that would be a waste of the House's valuable time and a considerable expense to the Government of Canada. In essence, with a clause like we have suggested what could be done is that there could be a clause put in during the negotiations on the land claims settlement which would give precedence to
Government Orders
the particular aboriginal group that is being negotiated with.
Therefore, the inconsistencies within the bills that are being passed, Bills C-51 and C-52, would no longer play an important role. Aboriginal people in those particular areas would feel comfortable in that these particular pieces of legislation that are being passed today would not trample over their rights in the area of inland waters.
I would have hoped that the minister would see the very common sense rationale to this particular amendment and not look at it as a precedent. We are suggesting that the land claims settlements will take precedence over these particular bills. That in itself may be classified by the government as a precedent.
I would suggest that every land claim settlement that will be done in the future would not take place unless the aboriginal people are assured that they will have some legitimate rights and control over the water resources within their own borders. Therefore, it may seem on the surface to be somewhat of a precedent but in reality the facts are that these land claims will suggest and be put in place with that understanding and belief by the aboriginal people once they are signed.
I was hoping that the minister would look at this as a friendly amendment in order to make things much clearer to the people who live in the Northwest Territories and to the people who live in Yukon. It would be a practical amendment that would put in place a regime of better understanding as to what we as members of Parliament are really trying to achieve by putting this new regime in.
We drafted an amendment on this issue for clause by clause.
First, we were advised before the meeting started that our amendment would be ruled out of order by the chairperson at the particular meeting when we were trying to deal with this in committee. We felt it was important to bring this to the people's attention in Canada, the Northwest Territories and in Yukon because it is going to come back to haunt us down the road. I suggest the new government that will come into this

Government Orders
House after the next election will have to deal with this inconsistency.
In conclusion, Motion No. 1 recognizes that there are inconsistencies between the water bills and the water provisions of soon to be finalized land claims agreements. The inconsistencies have been acknowledged by our own government and the water bills will have to be amended as soon as the claims agreements are finalized.
The government acknowledges that amendments to the water bills will be necessary in order to bring them in line with the claims agreements because the minister has suggested that.
The government is also well aware that aboriginal organizations had requested a delay in the passage of these bills. They preferred to have their claims agreements finalized first so the water provisions of their agreements could be integrated into the proposed new water bills before they were brought into this House.
In this way the water bills would be completely updated. There would be no need to amend the bills subsequently to make them consistent with land claims, as is now the case. The government, however, did not want to wait for the finalization of the claims before bringing the new water management legislation forward.
Members on this side accept the need for a new water management regime in the north. We would have preferred, however, that the government acknowledge in these acts what it is prepared to acknowledge outside these acts, namely, that the bills are inconsistent with what has been negotiated in northern land claims.
Our amendment is a compromise which avoids delaying these bills until land claims are finalized. It is simple and straightforward. It informs everyone of a basic fact on which there is no disagreement. It confirms the minister's position. It clarifies what could be a very confusing situation for northern residents and industry.
Again I suggest to the minister and the government that this is a very friendly amendment. It is meant to make things a little clearer, which we were attempting to do, and it is hoped the government will reconsider because we feel it may cause a lot of confusion, especially in Bill C-51. We may be back in this place every year amending that particular act because of the land claims
settlements that are going to be ongoing and approved in the near future.

speakeroldname: Hon. Thomas Siddon (Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development):
speakerposition: Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in speaking to the proposed amendment, Motion No. 1 to Bill C-52 and also the companion motion offered by the hon. member for Nunatsiaq, I would like to say to the hon. member for Kenora-Rainy River that I do look upon his amendment as a friendly amendment. There is no question about that.
I understand the spirit in which he is offering this proposal. However, this amendment is premature and it is premature for the reason that, as the hon. member has stated, every land claim negotiation will be unique in certain respects.
I know he has made the case that it would save time later in not having to return to the Northwest Territories and Yukon waters acts to further amend them, but when the settlement legislation is brought before this House, after it has been ratified by a particular first nation, well after a negotiated agreement has been reached, when that settlement legislation is brought into this House the amendments he is concerned about will be but consequential amendments to other pieces of existing federal legislation.
There is no doubt the federal government is committed. I have publicly committed myself to ensuring that in the affected jurisdictions, in the areas which are the settlement areas contained within a land claims agreement, the first nation's laws or the laws of the aboriginal party will prevail according to the terms that are negotiated in each individual case.
In terms of Bill C-52 and the amendment before the House, it is premature to anticipate the nature of those negotiations and the time it might take to include them, notwithstanding the suggestion of the hon. member that we might save time in the future. It is an inappropriate principle to anticipate agreement on a particular land claim until that agreement is reached.
I restate one final time for the record that there is nothing in Bill C-51 or Bill C-52 which prejudices the future implementation of land claims agreements with any of the aboriginal parties north of the 60th parallel. When those agreements are implemented, the settlement acts which will be brought before this Parliament and debated will determine what changes might be made

to laws of general application in order to accommodate the land claims agreements.

Mr. Speaker, we are engaged in a debate on Bill C-52, the Yukon waters act, and particularly Motion No. 1 which states:
In the event of any inconsistency between the provisions of this Act and the provisions of any land claim agreements affecting the Yukon Territory, concluded between aboriginal peoples of Canada and Her Majesty, the provisions of the land claim agreements prevail to the extent of the inconsistency.
This is an excellent motion. I am a little disappointed that the minister twice within the last hour has offered arguments against its adoption. I really cannot understand the basis for his argument. I was impressed on December 12 when he issued a press release from his department saying that aboriginal rights and management roles concerning water resources may be defined and set out in future comprehensive claims settlement legislation. Then he added that where there is any inconsistency between these acts and future claims settlement, the latter will prevail.

speakerposition: Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext: I said that here.

The minister adds from across the way that he has made a very strong statement to that effect again. I appreciate that he says those things but that is why I have trouble comprehending why when he is prepared to put it in a press release he is not prepared to put it in this legislation.
The minister is arguing that it anticipates land claims agreements which maybe different from case to case and may be included in specific settlements legislation. That much is true. However, at the same time this amendment anticipates such differences existing between different agreements and says provision of the land claims agreements-plural-prevail to the extent of the inconsistency.
Really the wording of the motion is such that it would not make any difference which particular claim would come before us and what the provisions would be. This provision would automatically kick in and be an operative clause.
Government Orders
I really cannot see what the minister's argument is and I see some danger in not pursuing this particular motion and not including it in the legislation.
The legislation before us is very important. It covers probably half the land area of the country. The waters in that vast tract of land are some of the cleanest and least polluted waters in the country that we as Canadians have an absolute stake in preserving and keeping from going the way of much of the water in southern Canada.
This legislation is important to my constituency, which borders on the Northwest Territories. The northern waters systems do not necessarily reflect political boundaries. It would probably be a mistake to wait two, three, four or five years until all these settlements are negotiated. At the same time, it is important to recognize in very practical ways, as well as in symbolic ways, what is happening in these negotiations.
The Council of Yukon Indians made an excellent presentation to the committee in which it said that in the umbrella agreement which was initialled in November between the Yukon Indians and the Government of Canada there are a dozen pages devoted to water management.
It is a very important aspect of that particular umbrella agreement. What happens in there is that it establishes an entirely new use as far as legislation is concerned when it comes to water management. That is the traditional use for the purposes of trapping, non-commercial harvesting, transportation, traditional heritage, cultural and spiritual purposes. This use is guaranteed to Yukon Indian persons without a licence or a fee.
This is what is being anticipated in the land claims negotiation. The courts, in decisions like the Sparrow decision, have made very clear it is part of the fundamental fabric of the country. At the same time, we are at the constitutional table trying to convince the aboriginal peoples of this country, the Metis, the Indian and Inuit people, that we are serious in recognizing what traditionally has been the self-government role which has not been recognized in the Indian Act and other kinds of legislation. We are now saying that is an inherent right, it has always been there. We will finally get around to recognizing this in the Constitution. That is a commitment that has been made not only by the Government of

June 15, 1992
Government Orders
Canada but I believe by at least nine out of the ten provinces and the two territories of this country.
It seems to me that if we are establishing that kind of a jurisdictional context in the country, it really calls into question how serious we are about that kind of rhetoric if we refuse to include in legislation like the Yukon waters act an operative clause that basically indicates that when we are talking about these kinds of changes we are talking in good faith.
Aboriginal people have some reason to be concerned about this. First of all, the consultation process with respect to this bill was somewhat flawed. We were assured earlier on when this legislation was introduced and scheduled for quick passage that all the interested parties had been consulted and basically went along with this legislation. When the committee checked around with those people, the interested groups in Yukon and the Northwest Territories, it turned out those people had not felt they had been consulted at all and that if they had been consulted they certainly had not been listened to.
That is a bit of a pattern, unfortunately, with some of the people who consulted on behalf of the present minister and previous ministers. Certainly in my experience with issues like post-secondary education, Oka, and most particularly with the Nunavut settlement with the Inuit people and how it affects the Dene people in Saskatchewan and Manitoba, there has been a long string of instances in which negotiations and consultations certainly have not met the expectations of the aboriginal people even though they may have exceeded the expectations of the minister.
As I mentioned, in this case we had again an instance in which people felt they had not been consulted and various groups came forward to make presentations on this legislation. That was as it should have been. There were the Council of Yukon Indians, the Northwest Territories Water Board, the Klondike Placer Miners Association, the Northwest Territories Chamber of Mines and a submission from the Dene Nation.
Central to those presentations was this whole question of what is going to happen with the land claims. On the one hand you have the aboriginal peoples saying that water use, traditional use, is part of their treaties, part of constitutional negotiations, part of the claims negotiations. It is the stated intent of the minister to include
recognition of this kind of jurisdiction by aboriginal people. These people ask why this is not in the legislation.
On the other hand there are the other water users in the Northwest Tferritories and Yukon who need to know and have before them in legislation the fact that times are changing, that there are new actors on the scene, that there are new jurisdictional arrangements being made.
While it is important that this bill goes forward, I really do believe that it is a mistake for this bill to go forward without Motion No. 1, which would eliminate any inconsistencies between land claims and this bill. It is a real mistake to let that legislation go forward the way it is without that particular amendment.

Government Orders CRIMINAL CODE

speakerposition: stagedirection
subtopic
stagedirection
speechtext: The House proceeded to the consideration of Bill C-49, an act to amend the Criminal Code (sexual assault), as reported (with amendments) from a legislative committee.

speakerposition: subtopic
Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext:
There are two notices of motions set down on the Notice Paper in amendment to Bill C-49, an act to amend the Criminal Code (sexual assault).

Motion No. 1, standing in the name of the hon. member for New Westminster-Burnaby, will be debated and voted on separately.

Motion No. 2 standing in the name of the hon. member for Cape Breton-The Sydneys was moved, debated and negatived in the legislative committee.
I understand that there was a tie vote in the committee on this particular amendment, with the chairman casting his vote in the negative, allowing for further consideration of this amendment at the report stage.
Therefore, in this particular case, I am selecting the motion which will be debated and voted upon separately.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Motion No. 1.
That Bill C-49 be amended in Clause 1 by adding immediately after line 32 at page 2 the following:
"(4) Consent shall not be presumed on the basis of the complainant's clothing, appearance, age, ability or membership in any group, including on the basis of race, colour, religion, country or ethnic group of origin, marital status, sexual orientation, immigration status or employment, including prostitution.
She said: Mr. Speaker, this amendment seeks to name in the body of the bill the women most vulnerable to violence and the women with the least access to the justice system. The amendment states that consent on the part of the complainant cannot be presumed on the basis of membership in a disadvantaged group.
Over 60 diverse women's organizations in this country came together and agreed on a set of amendments to Bill C-49. They shared their experiences and their perspectives, and suggested amendments which would tell all women and men that sexually assaulting a woman because she is an aboriginal woman, a black woman, a prostitute, an immigrant or on any other basis would also be punished.
I introduced many of these amendments at the committee stage of this bill, and all but one was defeated by the majority on the committee. The amendments I introduced used the words that these women had worked on and struggled over, and had come to an unprecedented agreement on.
Members of Parliament are barred from proposing the same amendment twice so I have had to reword what is among the most important of the amendments and ask that members of this House reconsider it. The amendment I am proposing states that:
Consent shall not be presumed on the basis of the complainant's clothing, appearance, age, ability, or membership in any group, including on the basis of race, colour, religion, country or ethnic group of origin, marital status, sexual orientation, immigration status or employment, including prostitution.
This amendment would mean that sexist and racist myths about women would no longer be acceptable excuses to commit a sexual assault.
Women are still divided in our society into "good girls" and "bad girls", with the bad girls being less worthy of protection. Prostitutes, lesbians, black women, aboriginal women are often considered targets of violence in a society in which all women are not equal.
The Native Women's Association stated in their brief to the committee:
Aboriginal women are doubly damned by stereotypes.
June 15, 1992

As women, we are often subject to the presumption that we lie about being assaulted, that we are emotionally unstable, that we are spiteful and seek revenge, or that we provoke the attack.
As aboriginal women, we are also subject to the presumption that, if we had been drinking, we are drunks and would not have been assaulted if we were sober.
There is also still the perception that aboriginal women are available to provide sexual gratification to any man who demands it. People still cannot rid themselves of the notion that there are "good girls" and "bad girls".
People who think this way perceive that aboriginal women by their nature are bad girls.
In recent years, Inuit women have been subject to other judicial proclamations that incest is normal in Inuit societies, that a girl is ready for sex when she begins to menstruate, and that it is acceptable to have sexual relationships with young girls.
Aboriginal women experience higher rates of violence than most other women. Aboriginal women are living with the legacy of destruction and abuse in their own communities bom of residential schools, powerlessness and poverty, as well as the history of abuse by a white dominated society which called them savages and treated them as such.
Aboriginal women live with Helen Betty Osborne in their hearts and other aboriginal women, raped and murdered, and on which no action was taken by society at large.
Kitty Nowdluk-Reynolds is an Inuk women who was dragged across the country, handcuffed and imprisoned for eight days. Her crime was that she was a victim of sexual assault. There were no charges against her. She was locked in a van with her rapist, not by the rapist but by police. Ms. Nowdluk-Reynolds said this would never have happened to her if she were a white woman.
We heard during the committee hearings that most police officers, Crown counsels and judges are white, middle class men, and they find it easier to protect women who look like their wives and mothers.
Jails are filled over-proportionately with aboriginal people. Many aboriginal women do not trust the justice system and do not come forward because the justice system does not work for them.
We need to overhaul the criminal justice system, educate judges, lawyers and police, get more women and minorities integrated as an essential part of this system, but right now we can start with a law that would make a
Government Orders
racially motivated sexual assault a crime rather than an excuse to escape punishment.
The Native Women's Association says that naming aboriginal women in the bill would make it easier for aboriginal women to come forward with reports of sexual violence.
More than 40 per cent of disabled women have been sexually assaulted. We heard at committee that disabled women are targeted because they are more vulnerable and less likely to be believed by police and in the courtroom. Disabled women are often more dependent on others and have learned to keep silent in order to survive.
A study of assaulted disabled women found that charges were laid 14 per cent of the time, few cases were taken to court, and 5.8 per cent of the accused were found guilty. That means that 94 per cent of those who assault disabled women are still out there targeting perhaps other disabled women for assault.
The committee heard that the excuses made in the sexual assaults of disabled women included, "it is okay to rape her, she did not know what was going on anyway" and "it was okay because she could not feel anything anyway".
Bill C-49 must explicitly state that such excuses will no longer hold up in court and that consent cannot be presumed on the basis of disability.
Prostitutes have been raped and murdered and their reports of violence against them are not taken seriously. It seen they cannot be raped because they take money for sex. This should not mean that they never have the right to say no to sex or no to sex for free or that they deserve to be beaten or deserve to die. There have been 38 sex trade workers killed in the lower mainland of Vancouver. Even murders of prostitutes tend to be closed and abandoned earlier by the police. Prostitutes' rights organizations have told us that they have been put into the position of having to find the evidence and do the work.
Immigrant and refugee women are also particularly vulnerable to abuse. Women have been deported for reporting that their husbands abused them. If their husband is their sponsor and the sponsorship breaks

Government Orders
down, the woman might find herself out of the country very quickly.
There has also been a case of a Canadian immigration official demanding sex in exchange for entry into the country. We must make it clear that this is not acceptable in our country and is punishable with strong criminal sanctions.
A recent survey of college men in Canada found that 30 per cent of men said they would rape if they thought they could get away with it, one-third of the young men who were surveyed. What we need to say clearly and strongly is that they cannot get away with it, not any more.
During the committee hearings we heard stories of racism, lack of access to the justice system and aboriginal women and women of colour less likely to be believed by the police and the court system.
I have also added clothing and appearance to this amendment because these are often used against women. Everyone, woman, man or child, has the right to security of the person. This right is not given up on the basis of a low-cut blouse, lack of underwear or any other excuse.
A judge found that a woman provoked a physical assault against her because she was wearing a T-shirt that made her husband mad. Our assault laws must be clear that clothing and appearance are not the issues in sexual assault. Violence is the issue. We are looking at whether someone committed a crime, not at the fashions that have been sported by the complainant.
The Minister of Justice has refused to support an amendment that would name doubly oppressed women in this bill because she and her department have said that all women are vulnerable to sexual violence. That is true. Every woman, young or old, can be a target of sexual violence but some women are much more vulnerable than others.
It is important that Parliament of Canada make it clear that sexist and racist myths can no longer be used as excuses to sexually assault women. I would hope that all members will take this important amendment into consideration today.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to support the amendment suggested by the hon. member for New Westminster- Burnaby. It is an amendment which has a lot of good common sense.
We in the legislative committee on Bill C-49, as the hon. member said, heard a great deal of testimony from women's groups that wanted this sort of amendment. Frankly, the hon. member and I both presented amendments in committee to achieve this result but unfortunately they were defeated. While I do not particularly like the wording here as much as I liked the wording we presented in the legislative committee, certainly the House should support the amendment.
Frankly, there is no other way to word it because it cannot be worded in the same way and brought in at report stage and that is unfortunate. The member has done a very good job in wording this amendment. As I mentioned, I would like to support her on this.
The women's groups that came before us made a great deal of sense in their application. They said that women of colour, aboriginal women, disabled women and women who are under pressure because of immigration or employment status are not given the same consideration in our criminal justice system as are white women who are gainfully employed and do not have these pressures or these disadvantages in presenting themselves before our criminal justice system.
They say that white women are believed in front of the criminal justice system without any question by the judges and by the lawyers and by the police, much more so than women of colour, aboriginal women, sex-trade workers, disabled women and those who have some kind of employment or immigration question pending. They say there is more of a tendency to assume that they consented to the sexual assault than is the case with other women.
They say that in our system, as it is today, all women should be given the benefit of the doubt and believed that they are telling the situation as it happened. However, they say they are not receiving the benefit of the doubt which may go to other women. They say that regardless of the law stating that all women are equal in their complaints on sexual assault, they are not believed.
June 15, 1992

They are not believed by the courts and they are not believed by the police.
While it can be said that this type of an amendment is not necessary in our country because we have equality before the law, there is the de facto situation which has been pointed out to us by these women which says that they are disadvantaged before the law. They want this amendment included.
They wanted some changes to the preamble. The Minister of Justice has stated that the preamble is not going to be part of the Criminal Code. It will be a part of Bill C-49, a part of the legislation and presumably will be mentioned in the commentary of the Criminal Code but will not be a part of it. For that reason we need this clarification in the bill.
The request being made by these women is perfectly understandable and I feel that the House should support them completely and unanimously.
One of the reasons I was pleased that we were having a report stage is that I thought the minister would actually be tabling an amendment to accomplish this. From her commentary, it seemed that she felt there was a valid concern here that these women did have a very valid point that needed to be addressed and that she would be bringing forward an amendment. However, the Department of Justice has not brought forward an amendment either in legislative committee or in this report stage today. I am very disappointed in that. I was hopeful that the government would support the concern that it seems to have been stating.
However, I do feel that this amendment is very important and certainly I would support it.

Mr. Speaker, we are dealing with Bill C-49, a sexual offences bill. It has been at second reading stage, it went to committee and the committee heard many witnesses and it is now back to report stage at which we have two amendments to be made.
The history of sexual assault, and some years ago rape, is very interesting. There is absolutely no doubt that under the common law the law was very much weighted against the interests of women in this area of sexual assault and rape.
Parliament stepped in and in 1976 it made some amendments to limit the old common law rules. In 1983 Parliament stepped in again and refined them further.
Government Orders
Now in 1992, as a result of the Supreme Court decision in Seaboyer, Parliament is stepping in again.
I am quite convinced, although one can never predict these things with any absolute certainty, that this bill will come as close to being charter proof as any bill can at this point because the law is really starting to reflect the changing attitudes of our society.
The women's groups did a very good job in the consultation process leading up to the bill and this bill constitutes a real step ahead.
With respect to this motion which purports to add a new subclause 4 to the bill, I submit that it would really be a fundamental flaw to put such a list in the actual body of the statute.
The committee had an extensive debate on this. The committee made changes to the preamble to point out in the preamble the prevalence of sexual assault against women and children. Parliament is declaring to the courts across the whole land the importance of judges in that context. That is about as far as Parliament can go.
We had before us in the committee a number of different words for this type of clause and every one has a problem because the minute you start to put a list, some people might be left off it. Because the wording of it is that consent shall not be presumed, they make a list and if you are somebody who is not on the list there is an implication that maybe you have consented. We could all come up with our own lists.
For example, what if a woman is a hitch-hiker? She is not on the list, therefore is it presumed that she has consented? Other things could include motorcycle riders or a woman going to a man's apartment after having two or three drinks. Is that not capable of being abused?
We have to get back to the point the minister stressed again and again which responds to the latter point my friend from Cape Breton made. This law, as framed, applies to all women, all people, in terms of sexual offences. The minute you start limiting it down you are going to get yourself in trouble. The minister persuasively argued that we should stick with a law that covers everybody and makes it crystal clear.
It is very important that we do not make laws based on decisions of individual judges or individual instances because they often reflect only a foible of one person at that time or poor administration rather than a fundamental flaw in the law. Therefore, for those reasons I am asking members of the House to defeat this motion.

June 15, 1992
Government Orders

Mr. Speaker, I want to rise along with my colleague, our justice critic, in support of this amendment.
The member for New Westminster-Burnaby in her remarks brought some information forward to the House which I found particularly interesting. She said 30 per cent of men surveyed in college thought that if they could get away with rape they would commit it.
As I listened to the member going through all of her remarks, all of her insights, I could not help but think that one of the problems we have in our society is the lack of awareness when a bill like this goes through the House with all the different changes.
In my own riding there are many immigrant women who are constantly suffering from abuse. This new law that we are going to put through the House might get into one or two of the major newspapers, but for all intents and purposes most of those women will not know anything about it.
I certainly support the amendment. However, once this does become part of the legislation we must figure out a way to communicate all of these changes, and not just in a press release or by sending out copies of the bill to the various institutions involved. We are conducting a competitiveness campaign in this country and are buying ads on television and in the ethnic press, et cetera. There is enough dramatic change in terms of education in this particular bill so that we should consider how to ensure that all of those people who are directly affected-aboriginal women, immigrant women and disabled women- are aware of the changes in this law.
To return to the survey that the member quoted, if people realized that they were not going to get away with this form of abuse or rape, or the other acts of abuse related to it, then that might go a long way in diminishing the number of attempts.

Mr. Speaker, I also rise to support this amendment.
In looking at the amendment one must first look at the nature of rape itself. It is not a sexual act, it is an act of power and violence. People who perpetrate sexual assaults and rape are trying to demonstrate their power over women.
This amendment is trying to deal with the fact that there are some women in our society who are doubly disadvantaged. They are powerless because they are women but they are also powerless because they belong to identified minority groups that have traditionally not had power in our society. They have been the ones who have disproportionately been abused by society and subject to sexual violence.
The other thing we must understand is that legislation, including criminal legislation, tries to do two things. It sets out the kind of behaviour that society says is not acceptable, and it also tries to change the attitudes of people toward certain kinds of behaviour. This amendment is definitely trying to change the attitudes that people have toward sexual violence to women who are in a disadvantaged position. As a result of that it would go a long way in providing protection for these women. Once we start changing attitudes then we can start changing behaviour.
I have worked in the court system and in corrections. Very clearly, women in these disadvantaged groups are the ones who are subject to the highest incidence of sexual violence, particularly aboriginal women. Women in the inner cities, particularly native women, and women on reserves have always been subject to a disproportionate amount of sexual abuse. Immigrant women feel particularly vulnerable to sexual abuse during the time they are landed immigrants because they are concerned that if they make an issue of it they will be deported or will not be allowed to proceed with their Canadian citizenship.
We should take the opportunity when we are passing legislation to ensure that we clearly set out not only standards of behaviour but the changes in attitude that we want in this society.
This amendment goes a long way toward that goal because it points out clearly that it is no longer acceptable in our society for people in disadvantaged positions to be abused.

speakeroldname: Mr. Russell MacLellan (Cape Breton-The Sydneys) moved:
speechtext:
Motion No. 2
That Bill C-49 be amended in clause 2 by striking out lines 4 and 5
at page 4.
He said: Mr. Speaker, there are some areas in this bill that I would rather see changed, I do not think there is any question about that, even though I support the bill and think it is a major step forward.
However, there is one area that really must be changed. It causes me a good deal of concern. It is not a major point and can be deleted without any difficulty. It is just that the government has chosen not to.
This bill deals with two major areas. One is consent, the woman giving consent to the sexual activity or consent between two adults and what constitutes that consent. The other major area is the past sexual activity of the complainant and whether that should or should not be an issue.
It has been decided in this legislation that during the trial there will be a hearing within the trial, in other words a voir dire. It will be determined at that time whether the past sexual activity of the complainant is an issue and can aid the case of the accused, or whether it may just dredge up a lot of information that cannot help the accused but can cause severe distress and embarrassment to the complainant.
It is an important area. The government in this bill has listed the things that will be taken into consideration. It says in clause 2, which is an amendment to 276(3) of the Criminal Code, that:
(3) In determining whether evidence is admissible under
subsection (2), the judge, provincial court judge or justice shall take
into account-
Then it lists the things that will be taken into account.
Government Orders
The second item to be taken into account is society's interest in encouraging the reporting of sexual assault offences.
In my opinion this is particularly unacceptable because it interferes with due process and the right of the accused to a fair trial. I think that society's interests are of paramount importance. Please do not misunderstand me on that.
However, there are areas in which society's interests are taken into consideration. For instance, society's interests are now being taken into consideration when we debate this bill in the House of Commons, when we go through the second and third reading stages, and report stage and when we are before the legislative committee.
We are taking society's interests into account because we are trying to make this bill as good a bill as we possibly can and deal with the needs of society, particularly those people who are going to be involved: the complainant and the accused. All of society's interests must be taken into consideration, so we do that. We take society's interests into account when we consider the bill.
We also take society's interests into account when the Crown prosecutor is determining, in co-operation with the police and other parties, whether to lay charges, what charges will actually be laid and what section of the Criminal Code will be applied. We are taking society's interests into account then.
Once the determination of innocence or guilt is brought forward we take society's interests into account in the sentencing. In these three major areas we take society's interests into account. That is the way it should be.
However during the trial itself what must be of paramount importance and what we must never lose sight of at any time during the trial proceedings is the innocence or guilt of the accused. That person who is brought before our courts is entitled to a fair trial without any outside agendas being imposed on the case. That is not only the case with respect to the actual trial itself, the main trial, but it also must be the case when we are taking into consideration voir dires or other hearings that determine what is to be introduced in the main trial.
It is not that society's interests are not important, but they cannot be allowed to interfere with the determining of the innocence or guilt of the accused. That is what is

June 15, 1992
Government Orders
going to happen if we allow society's interests to be a factor in this process.
The other thing that is perhaps even more alarming is that it will undoubtedly become a precedent. It will become a precedent when we are talking about other legislation. Once we bring the concept of society's interests into a court of law then it is going to be very difficult to withdraw it.
For that reason I ask that those lines regarding society's interests as a consideration in the hearing of the past sexual conduct of the complainant be struck out.

Mr. Speaker, as my friend opposite pointed out the committee had a debate on this motion. The vote was divided equally among the committee members. As the chairman I voted against it on the basis that it could be brought back and the member could make his case here in the House.
I would like to put the arguments against accepting this motion. It seeks to delete one of the factors that a judge must consider in determining whether evidence of the complainant's sexual history is admissible in accordance with the test for admissibility set out in the bill.
It is important to make a distinction between the factors to be considered and the actual test that is set out in the bill. The test follows those principles enunciated in R. v. Seaboyer and Gayme.
Evidence of a complainant's sexual activity is not admissible unless it is evidence of specific instances of sexual activity, it is relevant to an issue to be proved at trial and it has significant probative value that is not substantially outweighed by the danger of prejudice to the proper administration of justice.
When applying this test the judge is guided by a series of factors that have been set out in the bill. The judge must take these factors into account when determining whether the evidence has significant probative value that is not substantially outweighed by the danger of prejudice to the proper administration of justice.
In other words, the judge must weigh the probative value of the evidence against the danger of prejudice. I appreciate that these are fancy legal words but they have
very real meaning in the day to day operations of the court.
The factors are offered to guide and to assist and to ensure that all judges in Canada are guided by the same considerations when determining the admissibility of evidence.
Bill C-49 proposes seven specific factors which the judge should consider. In addition, the judge may take into account any other factor considered relevant. No one single factor will determine admissibility. The factors are not the test.
For all of those reasons I would ask members to vote against this motion.

Mr. Speaker, I too speak in opposition to this amendment. In all of the testimony that we heard at the committee from women's organizations and in the arguments I put forward on my amendment which has just been defeated in the House to include doubly disadvantaged women, one of the things that women understand very well is that we have been conditioned in our society not to bring forward charges of sexual assault. Young girls are still socialized today to keep things of this nature-perhaps being touched by a person, which is inappropriate to a little girl-secret and to be quiet about them.
Women are conditioned this way all through society. I understand my friend's concern from a legal perspective but I must speak very strongly from a personal and female perspective on the need for our society to encourage women and children to come forward, to speak clearly about these issues and to have some sense that their concerns and their personal experiences as women and children will be taken seriously by the court.
I would encourage members in the House today to vote against this amendment.
