speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, another chapter in the struggle for democracy in the countries of the former Soviet Union unfolds this week as we prepare to welcome Russian President Boris Yeltsin to Canada.
In the interest of international peace and security, Canada has thrown its full support behind all of these countries. For example, last February Canada signed a declaration of friendship and co-operation with Russia.
Canadians are disturbed, however, by the continued presence of approximately 200,000 Russian troops in the Baltic states of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. This is an unwanted occupation in complete violation of international law.
Just yesterday Lithuanians voted 90 per cent in favour of an unconditional withdrawal during a national referendum in that country. All of us are aware of the difficulties associated with sending these troops back to Russia where shelter and employment opportunities are rare, but the time has come for their troops to leave.
I therefore urge the Prime Minister to raise this issue with President Boris Yeltsin and insist that further assistance to Russia be contingent upon a complete troop withdrawal from the Baltics.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in 1990, 94,180 Canadian babies were aborted. That comes to approximately 24 abortions for every 100 live births.
For those abortions done in hospitals and even in some private abortion clinics, medicare funded by tax dollars is paying for a procedure that has nothing to do with health care and everything to do with the destruction of human life.
The House resumed at 2 p.m.

June 15, 1992
Abortion is not therapeutic. It treats no medical, psychiatric or social problem. It cures no disease. However, we know for certain abortion eats up a hefty chunk of the health care budget.
We have a crisis in medicare with people waiting for life-saving treatment while provincial governments fund an elective procedure, abortion, at a time when genuine health services are being slashed. By paying for abortions, governments are mismanaging scarce tax moneys entrusted to their care.
In view of the increased pressure on health funding, I call upon all governments to stop public financing of abortions.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as a former unionized employee of The Toronto Star, I regret the present situation at the Star. The management of the newspaper is refusing to negotiate with the union representing journalists and support workers. Indeed, the owners of the paper have brought in replacement workers to try to keep the paper operating despite this legal strike.
Not surprisingly, they have been met by continuing protests aimed at stopping strike-breaking. This angry confrontation shows how essential it is that the labour law reforms in Ontario be passed. These changes will prevent the hiring of strike-breakers. The result will be greater fairness and less violent confrontation in labour relations in Ontario.
Meanwhile, I urge the owners of the Star to remember Joseph Atkinson who made the Star a crusading paper for the rights of workers and to settle this dispute through fair negotiation instead of the use of force.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the earth summit in Rio was the largest and most important global gathering in human history. There were some who cast doubt on what would be accomplished in Rio.
I believe the five principal documents that came out of the earth summit, namely, the Rio Declaration, the
Statement of Forest Principles, Agenda 21, the Global Warming Convention and the Biodiversity Convention, all attest to the over-all success of the summit.
Prime Minister Brian Mulroney did all Canadians proud in not only his excellent address but especially in the way he provided a clear direction and acted as a constructive bridge on the many important issues dealt with by the world leaders in Rio. Environment minister Jean Charest is to be commended for his outstanding contribution as leader of our Canadian delegation. I believe the earth summit will go down in history as the point when all nations of the world began to focus on preserving our common home. I am glad to have been part of that process.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, printers across Canada are deeply concerned by the impact of this government's economic mismanagement of their industry. Canada's fourth largest manufacturing employer has lost 10,000 jobs in the past 18 months.
When the federal government recently announced its "Buy Canada" campaign, the Canadian Printing Industries Association launched its new "printed in Canada" logo as part of its contribution to this effort. The Minister for Small Businesses and Tourism personally unveiled this logo on Parliament Hill.
Last week we learned that Canada's main tourism guide, the official Traveller's Guide to Canada, paid for in part by Tourism Canada, was printed in the United States. The minister was wrong when he said in this House last Thursday that this was an American publication. It is a Canadian publication that the government had printed in the U.S.
The federal government is spending $4 million to encourage Canadians to shop at home. It is a sorry day, Mr. Speaker, when this government will not support its own "Buy Canadian" program.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Abitibi- Temiscamingue has been left out in the cold again.

Selection du Reader's Digest has just published a Guide de la route au Canada, in which No. 117, the Trans-Canada Highway, is shown as ending at Mont Tremblant in the Laurentians. This perpetuates a situation that is one of the grievances of the general director of the Val d'Or Tourism and Convention Office, Ms. Louise Potvin, as well as of the general public in our area. They feel that once again, their region and James Bay are being given short shrift.
A researcher with the publishing department of Selection in Montreal added that only the more densely populated areas had been chosen. In the pages on Quebec specifically, among the peripheral regions only the northwest and north were left out. The Gaspe, Saguenay-Lac-Saint-Jean and the north shore were included.
I would like to invite the directors of the Reader's Digest to come and visit our vast and beautiful region.

speakerposition: subtopic
stagedirection
speechtext:
Mr. Francis G. LeBlanc (Cape Breton Highlands-
Canso): Mr. Speaker, a labour dispute in my constituency has been allowed to get out of hand due to inaction by the Nova Scotia government and over-reaction by the RCMP.
Workers at the Clearwater lobster plant in Cape Auget have been on a legal strike since May 14. Union and management had been progressing toward a new contract settlement. However, the appearance of scab workers during this strike has created strong feelings among workers and poisoned the bargaining atmosphere.
Last week's use of riot police, complete with attack dogs and billy clubs to break up a demonstration against replacement workers, provoked a violent confrontation.
The industrial inquiry agreed to Thursday by Nova Scotia Minister Leroy Legere at the insistence of MLA Richie Mann is better late than never.
Now it is time for cooler heads to prevail. Both labour and management need to suspend their mutual suspicions and focus on the issues that matter: wages, working conditions and seniority provisions that will allow the workers at Clearwater to go back to work.
Considering the millions of dollars in grants and loans which Clearwater has received from the federal government, management can afford to be generous.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise today to recognize the achievement of Mr. Robert Stewart, a native of Barrie, Ontario, and a son of a former member of Parliament of Simcoe South, now Simcoe Centre, Mr. Ron Stewart.
Robert Stewart is one of the four Canadians chosen by the Canadian Space Agency to attend a NASA training program in Houston to become a full astronaut and a candidate for a future shuttle mission.
I know that the members of this House join me in extending most sincere congratulations to Robert Stewart and best wishes for his future success. I know he will do Canada proud.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, for the 3,000 people in the Athabasca region of Saskatchewan isolation carries a heavy price tag. Overcrowded housing is causing outbreak of tuberculosis, communities lack proper sewer and water systems, food prices are sky-high, economic opportunities are limited because of the cost of shipping out local products like freshwater fish. Meanwhile, the Coast Guard reports that the construction of an all-weather road would save $1 million to $2 million now being spent annually on dredging and navigational aids for barging.
Studies by the Prince Albert Tribal Council indicate a road would save the Department of Indian Affairs and Northern Development and First Nations $1.5 million on operations each year.
The cost of shipping materials for new housing, schools, and sewer and water systems, would be cut by additional millions. This is an obvious case of where we can save money and help people at the same time.

Therefore, I call on the Department of Indian Affairs, the Coast Guard, and the provincial Department of Transportation to get their act together and start work on an all-weather road into the Athabasca.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as Canadians make their travel plans for the summer months, I hope they consider visiting the place where Canada was bom, my province of Prince Edward Island.
This year marks the 125th anniversary of our Canadian nation and celebrations are happening all across the country. Special events are happening on Prince Edward Island as well, as Islanders recreate the spirit of the historic Charlottetown Conference which led to Confederation.
Visitors to the island in search of rest and relaxation will also appreciate our magnificent beaches, delicious seafood, exciting live theatre, and our famous island hospitality.
Our reputation for celebrating the many aspects of our lives and of our history continues to draw visitors to our enchanted isle. In fact, whenever you visit the island there is certain to be an unforgettable community event awaiting your arrival.
On behalf of the citizens of Malpeque, I am delighted to extend an invitation to all members of this House, their families, to all Canadians to visit Prince Edward Island, one of the world's great islands.

speakerposition: subtopic
Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, veterans in my riding of Fraser Valley East are outraged at the biased and defamatory CBC National Film Board series The Valour and the Horror.
Terence McKenna and his brother Brian decided to use public funds to develop a revisionist view of World War II. Despite technical and factual errors identified by academics and veterans, the CBC is quite happy to rerun this series.
Freedom of expression is a fine freedom. It is a freedom for which Canadian sailors, soldiers, and air
personnel fought and died, but freedom without responsibility is dangerous. It creates an imbalance and is a drain on the very system which guarantees the freedoms in the first place.
I do not advocate censorship, nor do veterans. What I do advocate is that the CBC begin to act responsibly and inject some balance of measure and fairness into the programs it funds and airs.
Terence McKenna can cast aspersions as he wishes. He is entitled to his views. But when it comes to representing Canadian war efforts, a biased and a very subjective diatribe is not worthy of public funding.
This series could well be the only information that many Canadians see about Canada's war effort. It is therefore imperative that the CBC provides a balance so that the public can make up its own mind and not be contaminated by the poisoned view of revisionist journalists and pseudo-historians.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise today to again state my support for the Canadian panel on violence against women. This panel has heard from thousands of women across the country, women who have dared to come forward to tell their stories of physical and mental abuse endured for years.
These women come from all levels of our society but they share one thing in common, the violence that has been directed at them for years.
The final report of the panel will be a comprehensive plan to deal with violence against all women: native, minority, rural, disabled, elderly, and young.
The changes needed in our society will be great. The greatest change is to change attitudes to women themselves. It is a difficult task but this is where the co-operation of law makers and society in general is crucial. We must unify our energies around this issue to work together on a common agenda and not be affected by incongruous demands.
Let us all work toward exterminating violence against women in Canadian society and let Canada be an example for the rest of the world.
June 15, 1992

Mr. Speaker, the headline in The Globe and Mail of June 12 reads:
Canada a winner in free trade. Survey shows exports to the U.S.
gained with imports no threat.
This was a survey of 325 companies conducted by the Canadian Manufacturers' Association in April and May and the data compiled this month. It covered a wide range of business issues.
For the most part the results confirm claims made by the proponents, the supporters of the FTA, and it states that nearly half of the respondents said they increased capital investments in Canada since the agreement came into effect while only 9 per cent reduced investment.
It also pointed out that 56 per cent said they have not lost domestic market share to imports since 1989 and 39 per cent said exports to the United States have grown since 1989. Also, three-quarters of the companies see the U.S. as Canada's most attractive market in the future, 30 per cent citing Europe as the best market.

speakerposition: Speaker pro tempore
speechtext: The hon. member's time has expired.

speakerposition: subtopic
subtopic: THE DISABLED CONSUMER SOCIETY OF COLCHESTER
THE DISABLED CONSUMER SOCIETY OF COLCHESTER
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the disabled community in my area has worked hard to improve their quality of life and have succeeded in several areas.
The Disabled Consumer Society of Colchester has established a special bus system to provide transportation in the Truro community. They have organized an employment service to locate employment for the disabled with funding from Canada Employment and Immigration. They have also participated in drafting legislation to provide access, opportunities and awareness.
The society is now urging Parliament to pass amendments to the Human Rights Act which will include a duty to provide accommodation for people with disabilities. As well, they are seeking to provide an undue hardship
5. 0. 31
clause and they want a barrier removal process to be implemented right away.
These amendments would enhance the employment opportunities for the disabled and help them participate in every aspect of Canadian society. They have proven that if given the tools with which to work they will achieve their goals. I hope that I can play a small part and be of assistance to them in their efforts.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, six Innu children died in a house fire in Davis Inlet in February of this year. They died because there was no running water to fight the fire in their community-
One hundred and fifty members of this Innu community were forced to relocate to an isolated island off Labrador by the Government of Newfoundland. The result of this forced relocation was the complete social disintegration of the community.
It is time for the premier of Newfoundland and the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development to stop denying responsibility for this community and to sit down and develop a plan for implementation of complete self-government and to institute a plan with sufficient resources for community and social reconstruction.
Action must take place by these two parties before any other children die in similar circumstances.

Mr. Speaker, the Tbrkish Cypriot leader, Mr. Denktash, has said he is not troubled by Canada's threat to pull our peacekeeping forces out of Cyprus. Of course not. Mr. Denktash is backed by 30,000 regular Turkish troops facing a much smaller Greek Cypriot national guard across the green line.
If Canada did pull out, it would hurt one side and help the other. Giving one party the upper hand will certainly not create an incentive for a peaceful, just and viable solution to the Cyprus problem. In fact, just the opposite.

Oral Questions
Rather than removing our peacekeepers, Canada, through the Prime Minister's special relationship with President Bush, should push the United Nations during the Cyprus meetings scheduled to begin on Thursday in New York City to bridge the differences between Greek and Turkish Cypriots once and for all.

speakerposition: topic
subtopic
speechtext: ["Mr. Speaker, I hope the member opposite agrees with the mandate of Marine Atlantic to manage the taxpayers' money properly. It has put in a structure that will do that without overcharging for small shipments. Again, I invite him to meet not with the Chamber of Commerce or others, but the CEO of Marine Atlantic who have put this new rate structure in place and dispel many of the misconceptions that have arisen from that."]

Mr. Speaker, the government's principal justification for a free trade agreement with the United States was secure market access, but Canadian exporters, most recently steel producers, continue to face long and costly trade actions launched by the United States.
Contrary to the earlier statements of the Minister for International Trade that the U.S.-Canada Free Ttade Agreement would not be re-opened, the Minister for International Trade is now suggesting that the North American free trade agreement will correct some of its flaws.
Can we assume from this that Canada will finally win true secure access to the U.S. market and real exemption from U.S. trade law?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased that the hon. member has acknowledged that the dispute settlement mechanism under the free trade agreement is working. He would like to see it working a little bit better, but in fact we have won ten of those panels and lost nine, which is pretty good. We have equality with the United States when we have a dispute.
If that mechanism can be improved in any way, of course the government will do so.

Mr. Speaker, the minister is fond of saying that the dispute settlement mechanism somehow resolves all trade questions between Canada and the United States, but he knows, as we all know, that the process takes months or even years to bring about any resolution, if indeed there is a resolution.
The minister also knows that there will be no secure access to the United States market unless all three countries in the North American free trade agreement can agree on a definition of subsidies and on dumping. Yet all the government ever says is that somehow this issue is being addressed in the current Uruguay round of the GATT. It is NAFTA the North American free trade agreement, which this government is on the verge of signing, not a still uncertain Uruguay round.
Can the minister now assure Canadians that the government will not sign the North American free trade agreement until it includes a clear definition of subsidies and a clear definition of dumping?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member complains about the amount of time that it takes to resolve a dispute under chapter 18 or chapter 19 of the free trade agreement.
In fact, the limit in one case is 180 days, the other, 315 days. He complains that it is too long, but what did we have before the free trade agreement? Nothing.
Oh, oh.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
We had three or four or five years, millions of dollars of expenditures on the American terms alone in order to settle any kind of trade dispute.
Now we have a time limit. Now we have panels that are constituted with one American, one Canadian, a neutral chairman. We have equality when it comes to a dispute. This is a tremendous improvement compared with what went before.

Mr. Speaker, the minister knows perfectly well that in the pork dispute, for example, it took 21 months to reach a settlement.
During that long and costly process, Canadian exports to the United States were severely disrupted. Let me put the question to him even more simply. Is there going to be in the North American free trade agreement a subsidies code and a dumping code, or will there not be? Will this government sign a NAFTA that does not include a subsidies code?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I cannot give a premature disclosure of that.
June 15, 1992

The government will announce what is in the agreement when it is signed. However, the hon. member does know that the whole subsidies discussion is part of the free trade agreement. It is the same with dumping, and it is important that progress be made.
What the hon. member must remember is that there are some American actions when it comes to dumping. There are American actions when it comes to subsidies that we do not find acceptable. We have an interest in making sure that there is progress on both those dimensions.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext: Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister. Full integration of sustained development in all trade treaties is one of the major items on which a consensus was reached in Rio. For Canada, the next trade treaty on the horizon is the one now being negotiated with the United States and Mexico. In this regard, could the minister give the House the assurance that all three countries will be subject to common environmental standards integrated as part of the principal agreement, and second, that failure to apply these standards will result in trade reprisals?

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Clark (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of the Environment):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, environmental considerations with respect to NAFTA are being addressed in several different aspects simultaneously during the negotiations. They are part of the negotiations themselves.
Key participants of the environmental communities are part of the SAGnk. The Government of Canada has agreed that there would be an environmental assessment of the plan when it is completed.
Also there is an agreement that each country will continue to have its sovereignty right as you would wish, to establish and to protect its own environmental standards.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question for the parliamentary secretary.
Oral Questions
How future historians will judge the conference in Rio depends on how the nations of the world act in the months to follow. The issue is, will the focus of international trade shift from raw market forces to the needs of sustainable development?
Canada's position on this is about to be put to the test in the Mexican agreement.
First, will a dispute settlement mechanism in the agreement enforce the environmental standards of the countries involved? Second, will the parliamentary secretary or the Deputy Prime Minister assure us that the onus of proof in any dispute will be such as to favour those who would protect the ecosystem? That is the lesson of Rio.

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Clark (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of the Environment):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, first of all the hon. member makes reference to Rio.
I want to say that I, and I am sure the vast majority of Canadians, are exceedingly proud of the leadership that this government provided at Rio.
In fact, Mr. Speaker, there are a series of quotes that I am sure you would be interested in, but time does not permit me to read all of them today or even any at this particular point in time.
As I said just a moment ago, what is very clear is that this government is committed to sustainable development. It is evident in the green plan. It is evident in our actions in a number of instances. It is evident in the way in which the NAFTA agreement is being negotiated.
Furthermore it was very evident at Rio. That was perfectly clear in view of the response with which the Government of Canada, including the Prime Minister, was received at every available public opportunity.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the spokesperson on international trade.
Given the fact that in this House the only two parties that support the North American free trade agreement talks are the Liberals and the Conservatives and the fact that they are out of tune with 67 per cent of Canadians who are opposed to the talks, the government has decided to launch a program to suggest to Canadians why this is good.

Oral Questions
I would like to ask the minister this question. Will the minister, in preparation for this discussion with the Canadian people about their views of the free trade agreement, release as requested by me on April 1 all of the sector by sector studies done, so that the people of Canada can have hard facts in front of them? Will the minister release those sector by sector studies or were they ever done before the government went into the negotiations?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the sectoral studies that have been done by the Department of Industry, Science and Technology and other parts of the government are well known to the hon. member.
Every time the Minister for International Trade or the Minister of Finance appears before a committee, they quote from the studies that the government has done. He knows that these documents exist.
He also knows that the confidential studies which have been done are not public. Generally, most of these sector studies are well known to the hon. gentleman through various briefings that he has attended and continues to attend.

Mr. Speaker, I have been present at every single committee meeting when the Minister for International Trade has been there to address these questions. Never once has the minister referred to any sector by sector studies. Unless I have been struck stone deaf, we must be talking about two different meetings.
I ask the minister who is speaking on behalf of the minister, on behalf of the excuses for the government, if the government is prepared to spend millions of dollars in an advertising campaign to sell its point of view on the free trade agreement and whether those who oppose the free trade agreement will have access to taxpayers' dollars to present the other side of the argument to the Canadian people?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member knows that he and his party have been offered confidential briefings on the NAFTA arrangements and the NAFTA negotiations. As I understand it, he can make himself available for those. I gather he does not want to make himself available for those.
His position and the position of the NDP, if it is similar to the NDP in British Columbia where the hon. member comes from, is that we should not negotiate at all for NAFTA. What should happen is that Mexico and the United States should negotiate and they should do a deal. Then at the last minute they would decide whether Canada should do a deal.
This is a ridiculous approach to tripartite negotiations. That is not our approach. Our approach is to be there from the beginning and to get the maximum benefit for Canada.
Mr. Speaker, I am just a humble boy from the country.
Oh, oh.

When I go into negotiations to buy a house or sign an agreement, I hire a lawyer. Some of the best firms in British Columbia are available to me.
I also talk to scientists and researchers before I put my name to any document. Could this government explain to Canadian people why it would call a meeting where there are no sector by sector studies, say that it is quoting from such studies that do not exist, and then go out and tell Canadian people that it is good for them without showing one shred of evidence to the people?
I would not sign a deal like that on a mortgage on a house. Why would the government mortgage this country without some hard evidence before it goes into these negotiations?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the humble country boy opposite would have us do the following. This is one of the problems perhaps with having that particular humble boy doing any negotiating for Canada. What he would do is have our whole negotiating position made public before he went in to negotiate. This is absolutely ridiculous.

Mr. Speaker, like many other members of this House during the weekend I was stopped many times and was asked: "Is my telephone bill going to go up because of Friday's CRTC decision?"
June 15, 1992

speakerposition: Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
speechtext: Where? At the tennis club?
Oh, oh.

speakerposition: Speaker pro tempore
speechtext: The hon. member has the floor.

With the opening up of telephone competition in the long distance field people are worried about their local rates. The industry says it doubts that local rates can stay down and Mr. Spicer says: "Don't worry. They will be protected".
What specific assurances can the government give to local phone users that their rates will remain reasonable and that these rates will not go up? What kind of confidence can they have?

speakerposition: Minister of Communications
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my first inclination if somebody put that question to me would be to quote the hon. member who was on CBC a couple of days ago.
She said about the CRTC: "Really they opened the whole box of competition. I would say that with that open door I am certainly not going to tell you we should close that door. I am going to say that we are going to watch what Mr. Spicer said when he made a very important point of ensuring that we would have affordable local rates, that they are going to be maintained. That is what I would say to them".

Mr. Speaker, that is fine. That is what I said. That is what Mr. Keith Spicer said. What does the minister say? Is the minister going to ensure that local rates will stay down for all Canadian consumers?

speakerposition: Minister of Communications
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as the hon. member will know, a key part of Bill C-62 is designed to ensure that all Canadians in all parts of Canada have affordable phone rates and the best possible service anywhere in the world.
I would think the best way to guarantee that sort of service to all Canadians would be for this House to move expeditiously on Bill C-62.
Oral Questions CHAMPION SPARK PLUG

Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Acting Minister of Industry, Trade and Commerce.
Last Friday the American owners of Champion Spark Plug in Windsor announced that they were turning it into a warehouse and transferring the production jobs there to their plant in Iowa in spite of the efficiency and co-operation of the Canadian workers.
I ask the minister: Why is it that, since the signing of this government's free trade deal with the United States, when these kinds of moves take place they are almost always at the expense of the Canadian workers?
I further ask the minister: Will he contact the American owners of Champion Spark Plug today to urge them to keep that plant open and recognize the productivity and efficiency of these Canadian workers?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend is doubly out of date. First, he does not know, at least in his question, that there has been a drastic decline in the size of the North American spark plug market as a result of smaller and cleaner burning engines.
He is from an automotive town. He should know that these cleaner burning engines have been a major factor in this industry and this is what has led to a downsize in the demand for spark plugs.
Also he does not know-and the Canadian Manufacturers' Association made it clear last week in its big survey, the survey of its membership-that in fact capital investments in Canada have increased since the free trade agreement.
In fact twice as many manufacturing firms in Canada expanded their investments in Canada since the free trade agreement than decreased them; 56 per cent said they had not lost domestic market share to imports; 39 per cent said that exports have grown significantly; 42 per cent expect higher exports; and so on.
What is happening since the free trade agreement is that our manufacturing sector, contrary to everything we

June 15, 1992
Oral Questions
hear from the hon. member, is increasing and improving. The hon. member refuses to recognize this.

Mr. Speaker, plants that have closed down do not answer surveys, so what he has to say has little meaning to the workers at Champion Spark Plug and at plants like it which are losing their jobs because the jobs are going to the United States.
He has not answered my question as to why, if the market for spark plugs is declining, the jobs are not consolidated in Windsor rather than in Iowa.
Why was it that when the minister of industry was asked about this on Friday all he could say was that this was a sign of "a dynamic economy"? Canadians will shudder at the idea that for this government a dynamic economy is one that means our plants are turned into warehouses and the jobs go to the United States.
Will the minister assure us that in any North American free trade deal there will be a return to Canadian content for automobiles to help prevent further Champion Spark Plug situations? If not, how will such a deal help Canadian workers in the auto industry, in that industry as a whole?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think it is dangerous for the hon. member to stand up and ask questions about the automotive sector in Ontario when in fact in his riding, in Windsor for example, Chrysler has just added a third van line. We have a $2 billion to $3 billion announcement by Ford in Oakville. There is tremendous expansion coming there. Ste. Therese in Quebec has just added 800 workers to expand its work force.
There is example after example of the fundamental truth about the North American environment for automobiles, and that is 10 years ago we had a 14 per cent share of the automotive production in North America. Today we have 24 per cent.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to put a question to the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs regarding the Unitel matter.
In the CRTC decision the minority opinion said: "The United States is an example of a country where, with long distance competition, there have been significant increases in local rates".
We were told that it costs $300 to install a phone in California. I checked today and in a rural town such as Southend in northern Saskatchewan as a result of the competition they are talking about $5,000 now. We know it went up in Japan as well and anywhere else there was deregulation.
Will the minister ask for a cabinet review of this decision? In the cabinet review will the cabinet build in guarantees that the ordinary Canadian phone user, the home phone user, will not be gouged as a result of this decision?

speakerposition: Minister of Communications
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I can hardly believe my ears. Is the hon. member saying that Sask Tel which is owned by the NDP Government of Saskatchewan wants to charge $5,000 for telephone service to residents of that province? It is astonishing if that is so.
On the particular point raised by the hon. member with regard to the situation in the United States, all I can do is quote the chairman of the CRTC who said, directly on the point raised by the hon member: "Canadians of all social and economic circumstances want us to be vigilant in maintaining affordable local telephone service". We are committed to doing exactly that and to preventing unnecessary or excessive increases. Before anyone tries scare tactics on Canadian consumers, let me underline that today's decision was made in Canada, not the United States. It is not deregulation. No phone company is being broken up. Canadians can still buy both their local and long distance services from the same company.
Let us not use phoney arguments to scare Canadian consumers. Let us stick to the facts.
Mr. Speaker, phoney arguments. If the minister had any guts he would stand and answer my question and give the consumers a guarantee-
Order, order.

speakerposition: Speaker pro tempore
speechtext: I ask the hon. member to withdraw that remark and then put his question.

Mr. Speaker, I am sorry. I know the minister has lots of intestinal fortitude and I withdraw that.
I would have asked him to give a guarantee because the CRTC itself said it did not predict significant increases. It did not say there would not be increases. I ask him to consider that.
June 15, 1992

On another tack and as a supplementary question, I want to ask him this seriously. Tlte Unitel decision will hurt one of Canada's largest companies. Indeed I think it may be the largest; Bell is the 40th largest in North America. Jean Monty, president of Bell, has said that the real competition will not come from Unitel but that it will come from the American telecommunications giants.
How does the minister propose that Canada compete in the North American communications trade when we are hamstringing one of the few Canadian businesses that could in fact compete with the American multinationals? What is he going to do to change that situation?

speakerposition: Minister of Communications
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I never thought I would live to see the day in this House when the spokesperson for the NDP would call on us to protect one of the largest companies in Canada against competition. What a change in philosophy there has been there.
When the hon. member raises the issue of Saskatchewan, the best way to deal with protecting consumers in Saskatchewan is for members on all sides of this House to pass Bill C-62 to ensure that there are rate hearings for the residents of Saskatchewan on their phone service, which there are not today; to ensure that the CRTC can continue to bring down rates across the country; local rates do not go up; and that the people of Saskatchewan also have that protection.
When we talk about protecting Canadian companies against the United States, the best way to do that is to ensure that Canadian phone services are affordable and that Canadian companies are not routing through the United States to get cheaper services.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Deputy Prime Minister.
In 1986 Canada announced that official development assistance would no longer be meted out as loans to developing countries. Since then Canada has provided unconditional ODA debt forgiveness to the poorest sub-Saharan and Caribbean countries.
Oral Questions
Last week, however, the Prime Minister in Rio targeted 10 impoverished Latin American countries to receive $145 million of conditional debt relief.
Unable to service any ODA debt in any manner, what incentives will Canada provide to these countries to invest in sustainable development projects?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as the hon. member knows, this is one of the initiatives at Rio of which Canada is very proud and in which our Prime Minister played a lead role.
The forgiveness of the debt in relation to environmental projects is very specific. What it means is that it is not a blanket review of debt of these countries. It is tied to specific proposals.
The forgiveness of debt over time under the Trinidad terms has been very generous to underdeveloped countries, and indeed we have taken the lead in putting that into place as well.

Mr. Speaker, the Prime Minister used words in Rio to promote the enhancement of our International Development Research Council's independent and internationally renowned reputation, but the government continues its plans to scrap the council's independence by incorporating it under the Financial Administration Act.
Will the government agree today to stop its meddling in the mandate of the IDRC and give up its intention of internalizing it under the Financial Administration Act?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think this is an entirely appropriate role for the IDRC which has really embraced this expanded mandate. It is an organization that we are very proud of and that will now be in a position to have even more impact on the world than it has had before.
I believe this move is a very constructive one and it will be very helpful to the countries involved.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in the absence of the Minister of the Environment, my question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister.

June 15, 1992
Oral Questions
At the earth summit in Rio, Germany, the Netherlands, Austria, Sweden, Denmark, New Zealand and Australia all pledged to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by as much as 20 per cent from 1988 levels.
If the government is really committed to sustainable development as the parliamentary secretary earlier announced, why did Canada fail to exercise leadership in this crucial area by not committing to carbon dioxide cuts beyond stabilization?

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Clark (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of the Environment):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Canada is one of a relatively few number of countries in the world that have in fact provided leadership at Rio by indicating that we would stabilize at 1990 levels by the year 2000. There are other countries we wish had chosen to adopt that same significant standard of leadership but did not. We are very proud of the fact we were there and were in the forefront.
Furthermore, we also made a commitment to quick-start the same convention. In fact, the Prime Minister was one of the first leaders to sign the convention in question. He indicated we would be ratifying it this veiy year.
I would also hope that those who had the opportunity to attend Rio as part of the official Canadian delegation would come back and be very supportive of that commitment which, indeed, is a significant one.

Contrary to the answer by the parliamentary secretary Canada unfortunately is not leading the pack.
Therefore, I have to repeat my question. If Canada is really committed to sustainable development, why does the government not implement the commitment made by the Prime Minister last Tbesday in this House as recorded on page 11654 of Hansard, to put reduction in gas emissions, not stabilization, firmly on his political agenda?

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Clark (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of the Environment):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
First of all, the question of what happens after Rio is very significant. We on this side have understood that Rio was in a very real sense just the beginning of a very important process. The debate will probably go on for a few weeks as to who did what at Rio.
I would just like to take this opportunity to refer to the quotes of Mostafa Tolba, the executive director of the
United Nations Environment Program, who said: "Canada has broken the ice by signing. We are grateful to Canada and we are grateful to the Prime Minister." That was with reference to the biodiversity convention which was one of several very important achievements at Rio.
I truly believe, as do most Canadians, we were in the forefront with respect to environmental change, with respect to the convention to which the hon. member refers, with respect to biodiversity and with respect to fisheries. We have made some progress with respect to forestry as well.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs. I appreciate the sort of hiatus in the discussions now. The Prime Minister is returning and I know the minister has to brief the Prime Minister. Perhaps eventually the House will find out in more detail what we have heard in the press which has led us to this present hiatus.
I would like the minister to clarify some confusion and uncertainty about one of the very important matters which seems to have been agreed upon in principle. That is the inherent right of the aboriginals to self-government and the statements of the minister and others at the conference that in effect this item can be delayed for three years and be negotiated and then perhaps referred to the courts.
How can this be a very tenable position when I am sure the minister knows, and certainly the Minister of Justice knows coming from British Columbia, on this very day in British Columbia the Court of Appeal is hearing the case of Delamuukw v. the Queen and the Attorney General of Canada on this very issue?
I would like to know how that can be rationalized. It is clear from the court case in British Columbia what the aboriginals believe self-government means is a little different from what we have seen in the press.

speakeroldname: Right Hon. Joe Clark (President of the Privy Council and Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs; President of the Privy Council
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, obviously constitutional discussions are now underway. Once they are concluded in the next two to three weeks they cannot affect a question that is before the courts now.
June 15, 1992

What has been agreed on is there would be a recommendation to Parliament and the legislatures that we recognize the inherent right to self-government, that we recognize it is not a contingent right but that the Constitution would also reflect an agreement entered into voluntarily by all governments and by all aboriginal leaders and groups that no one would take that new non-contingent inherent right to court for at least three years. That period of time would allow for discussion and negotiation as to the interpretation of an inherent right in a particular case.
That is an admirable compromise. I congratulate the aboriginal leaders on being willing, once they have established their right, to negotiate its application during a three-year time period.

I appreciate, in part, the minister's response.
Talking about compromise, how can the fact be rationalized that one party says it is going to delay the interpretation when at the very moment in British Columbia there is another three weeks of this very fundamental and important case, an appeal from Chief Justice McEachem, on this very issue?

speakeroldname: Right Hon. Joe Clark (President of the Privy Council and Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs; President of the Privy Council
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, for one thing, I understand that the issue is different.
For another thing, I do not think anyone has suggested that the fact a matter is under discussion in constitutional deliberations should mean all actions in all courts having relation to that matter should suddenly cease.
We cannot act retroactively that way. The hon. member would be one of the most vigorous to oppose it were we to suggest that kind of retroactivity. We are dealing with matters that might arise in the future and I think we have found a way.
Frankly, it needs a little more refinement in the discussions that are going on. That will occur and we will be able to find an agreement which will be broadly acceptable.
Oral Questions

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of State for Agriculture. Both the Quebec farmers' union, UPA and the Quebec agriculture minister, Yvon Picotte, think that the agriculture summit which ended in Trois-Rivieres yesterday gave Quebec's agrifood community new confidence in the future. The UPA president took the lead on Thursday by announcing to everyone's surprise that his organization was determined to take on export markets, provided the risks were shared by the other partners, namely the distributors and other intermediaries.
Can the minister tell us today that Quebec farmers will have help from the Canadian government in making Quebec's agrifood industry more competitive internationally?

speakeroldname: Hon. Pierre Blais (Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Minister of State (Agriculture)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think that these statements reported in the press last week show how sensible farmers in Quebec and Canada are. It also ties in with the review of all our agricultural policies that we began about two years ago.
I will repeat some of what the UPA president said:
The UPA president thinks that Quebec agriculture has everything it needs to gain new export markets. "The farm community is ready for change. It is better equipped with its expertise to face international competition in the future," said Mr. Proulx.
That shows that this government's policies asking farmers in Quebec and Canada to prepare for the future in a positive and dynamic way will have good results.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Associate Minister of National Defence.
The government has tried to justify the $4.3 billion helicopter deal by saying it would be unsafe to modernize the existing Labrador and Sea King helicopter fleets.

June 15, 1992
Oral Questions
If that is so, why did the United States navy, the Australian navy and the Japanese navy recently upgrade their Labrador fleets at one-fifth of the cost? Why has Great Britain just upgraded its Sea King helicopter fleet at a substantially lower cost?
Finally, why is the government wasting money on this $4.3 billion helicopter deal when it tells the world all it can do for the global environment is forgive $145 million of Third World debt?

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, first of all, I would like to remind my colleague that there is no deal. There is no decision. Our department is looking at a variety of options by which we can ensure we will have the kind of equipment needed to go into the 21st century.
Ib upgrade equipment is still not the best answer. It is like having a car. You can keep on upgrading the car but eventually there comes a time when it really does not work as effectively as it should.
We could spend a few dollars perhaps to put in some new engines. That will not provide the capability really needed for the future. We could spend a few more dollars but actually, looking at the costs of doing a full upgrade, it is almost comparable to buying a new helicopter.
If I were to ask what the hon. member would rather have, would he rather have a refitted engine, a refitted car, a refitted helicopter that still would not do the job, or a brand new one that would get us ready for the 21st century?

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Minister Responsible for the Status of Women has shown herself to be a very strong advocate for helicopters at a cost of over $4 billion to the Canadian taxpayers.
When will the minister become just as strong an advocate for the women and children of this country? When will she honour the commitment her government has made over and over again to a national child care program for the over one million children in desperate-

speakerposition: Speaker pro tempore
speechtext: We must try to keep going.

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this supplementary is perhaps not in order. Nevertheless, I am pleased to respond to my hon. colleague.
I can assure the hon. member of my advocacy on behalf of women in this country by ensuring that we deal with the primary issues of equality, of violence against women, of looking at ways in which to ensure that work and family responsibilities are attended to not just by government but by employers as well.
On the issue of child care, this government provides over $1 billion a year to the provinces for child care, a substantial portion to assist those families requiring those kinds of needs. We will continue to attend to the needs of children through such programs as the $2.2 billion child tax credit.
I can assure my colleague that this government looks after every sector of people in this country, including the men and women in the Armed Forces, including the children of this country.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the minister of fisheries.
Last week's decision at the earth summit to hold a conference on high seas fishing may help to address the problem in the long term. The real question of course is whether there is a long term and whether there will be any fish left to save a year or two from now.
What assurances does the minister have from the European Community that it will now honour the NAFO moratorium until the conference deals with the issue?

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it was very significant that at the summit meeting in Rio a week ago, for the first time as far as I know, the organized world community of 180 countries recognized that overfishing and the failure to apply principles of sustainable development in the fishery was a major world environmental problem.

The 180 nations there adopted a resolution which was an initiative of Canada together with 39 other countries. This will be a great help to us in the longer term with reference to future fish stocks.
We have to start somewhere. No one can expect that the whole world will arrive at the decisions one would like within five minutes or five months, but we are well on the way.
In the meantime, there is a short-term problem, hopefully short-term, in the northwest Atlantic with reference to the northern cod and flatfish stocks. I am sorry to have to relate to the House that there is a problem with cod fish in other areas as well, for example, off Iceland. There is a problem this year off Greenland in the Baltic with reference to cod stocks. While misery loves company, it is too bad that this is happening in other areas as well.
With respect to our own problems, we will act when we have all the information that is necessary in July. If we have to close any fisheries-

speakerposition: Speaker pro tempore
speechtext: Let us see if we can move on. The hon. member for Burin-St. George's, a supplemental.

Mr. Speaker, when the minister gets all the facts. How many more facts, how many more closed fish plants does he need for proof? He has enough facts. The problem is right on his doorstep.
The straddling stocks are as vulnerable as ever. In that respect, despite all the optimism and the rhetoric of last week, very little has changed, if anything.
I want to know how far the minister is prepared to go to protect that resource? How far is he prepared to go? Why is he ruling out taking over custodial management despite the fact that last week at Rio he was strongly urged by an expert in international law to do exactly that?

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am disappointed to see that the hon. gentleman is more negative today about the achievements we made in Rio last week than he was in Rio. I am sorry that he has had this change in attitude.
Oral Questions
How far am I prepared to go? I am prepared to go as far as is necessary to overcome the issue of overfishing in the northwest Atlantic as well as in the rest of the world.
What is the best way of achieving that? The best way is by getting 180 nations on your side, not having 180 nations oppose you because you want to adopt some premature cowboy tactics and unilaterally extend management controls in an area.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Transport.
After three years of disastrous fishing activities the incomes of Labrador fishermen have gone consistently down, yet the increase in rates of Marine Atlantic which is their supply line in the summer have gone consistently up. This year there is another 15 per cent or 20 per cent, at least, increase in rates of Marine Atlantic.
In view of the fact the government may very soon I hope announce a compensation program for the fishery on the Atlantic coast, will he now order Marine Atlantic to freeze its rates at last year's level on behalf of the fishermen on the Labrador coast?

speakerposition: Minister of Transport
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I thank the member for his question. At this stage I would like to invite him to meet with the CEO and other officers of Marine Atlantic so some of the misconceptions arising out of its tabling of its recent structure can be ironed out.
In fact, the minimum charge on small shipments is going to remain at $25 a piece. If the shippers are prepared to work with Marine Atlantic, they will find they have ways to minimize the increases because what Marine Atlantic is really trying to recover here is not full recovery. It is $600,000 out of the $28 million in subsidies we have been providing it over the past few years.

Mr. Speaker, a short supplemental. I met last week with the Chamber of Commerce in Goose Bay and I have talked to small businessmen along the Labrador coast. They are not fooled by the snow job the minister has been given by Marine Atlantic. There is going to be an increase in rates, at least 15 per cent to 20 per cent.

Routine Proceedings
Will he listen to the people there? Will he listen to the businessmen there and freeze Marine Atlantic rates this year at last year's level?

speakerposition: Minister of Transport
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I hope the member opposite agrees with the mandate of Marine Atlantic to manage the taxpayers' money properly. It has put in a structure that will do that without overcharging for small shipments. Again, I invite him to meet not with the Chamber of Commerce or others, but the CEO of Marine Atlantic who have put this new rate structure in place and dispel many of the misconceptions that have arisen from that.

subtopic: AUTHORIZATION FOR STANDING COMMITTEE TO TRAVEL
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I move:
That in relation to their study of the competitiveness and viability
of Canada's ports, eight members and two staff of the Standing
Committee on Transport be authorized to travel to Halifax, Nova
Scotia, to attend the Conference on Canadian Ports Competitiveness
from June 16 to 18, 1992.

speakerposition: stagedirection
speechtext: Motion agreed to.

speakerposition: subtopic

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I have five petitions again today dealing with the Court Challenges Program.
Canadians have made it known that they are very supportive of this program which gave access to the courts for those of us, groups and individuals, who wanted to test our constitutional right to come to court dealing with freedom of expression, the question of language rights and equality rights.
These petitioners would like to have the Court Challenges Program reinstated. It was abolished by the government some months ago. It was not a very expensive program at about 10 cents per year per Canadian. It was a very good program. In times of reviewing our constitutional arrangements, I think it would be appropriate if Canadians had access to public funds to defend themselves in front of the courts when their language rights and their equality rights are questioned.
Therefore, these people humbly ask the Parliament of Canada to reinstate the Court Challenges Program.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I rise today to present a petition signed by 27 constituents of Sarnia-Lambton. The constituents call upon Parliament to enact legislation providing for (a) a referendum of the people binding upon Parliament to accept or reject constitutional amendments proposed by the
June 15, 1992

government; (b) the acceptance or rejection of the proposed amendments to be determined by, one, a majority vote of the total votes cast in the whole of Canada, together with, two, a majority vote in the majority of provinces with the territories being given the status of one province.
I thank these constituents for their interest in our constitutional amendment process.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I rise today to present petitions that have been signed by many constituents of my riding of Sarnia-Lambton.
These petitions were organized and distributed by the Kinsmen and Kinettes of Sarnia. They urge all Canadians to take pride in a united, strong and independent Canada by participating in the Proud to be Canadian project. This project is an opportunity to nurture a positive life-long relationship with our heritage and our flag and to encourage stronger ties among all Canadians for the further advancement of Canada as a leader in world circles and promote our tremendous pride in being Canadians.
I thank the Kinsmen and Kinettes of Sarnia for their Proud to be Canadian project and thank the many people of Sarnia-Lambton who signed the petition.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I have two petitions today, pursuant to Standing Order 36, calling upon the Government of Canada to reinstate the Court Challenges Program. These are residents from the province of New Brunswick who have signed the first petition.
The second petition is from residents primarily of the province of Ontario again calling upon the Government of Canada to reinstate the Court Challenges Program which they believe to be a very important program for Canadians to have at their disposal.
I would hope that the government would see the wisdom of the suggestion and would rescind its earlier decision to cancel this most worthy program.
Routine Proceedings NATIONAL REFERENDUM

Madam Speaker, I wish at this time to present a petition which was started by my friend Bob Newell in Waterdown. It has about 50 signatures.
It is virtually the same language as the petition of my hon. friend from Sarnia-Lambton.
It is asking for a referendum of the people, binding upon Parliament, to accept or to reject constitutional amendments proposed by the government to be determined by a majority vote in a majority of provinces with the territories being given the status of one province.
As is duty bound, these petitioners will forever pray. I know that they are all Canadians to the core as I am and I pray too that the outcome of a referendum, if necessary, will mean the preservation of this country as we know it.

Madam Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 36,1 have three different petitions to table today.
The first one is regarding the subject of individuals within the bodies of their mothers. The petitioners state that the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms applies to the Parliament and Government of Canada and that the charter in article 15(1) states:
Every individual is equal before and under the law and has the right
to equal protection and equal benefit of the law.
They call upon Parliament to call on the government to enact laws which protect individuals while they reside within the bodies of their mothers.

Madam Speaker, the second petition is about the closing of postal station 'B' in my riding of Parkdale-High Park.
The constituents state that they have heard that postal station 'B' is going to be closed whereas they believe that as Canadians they have the right to efficient mail service and that the service rendered by postal station 'B' is very important to the local businesses, seniors and those wishing to mail parcels or use priority post.

Routine Proceedings
They call upon Parliament to call upon the minister responsible for Canada Post to review the decision to close postal station 'B' and instead renew the lease and ensure the service remains at the Ritchie Street location.

Madam Speaker, the third petition is three different petitions on the same subject. To save time I will put them all together regarding the human rights violations in Rwanda.
These petitioners state that the issue in the current armed uprising in Rwanda is not an ethnic conflict as the current Rwanda regime and its backers would like the world to believe. Rather the real issue is the fact that Rwandan people are rebelling against a military dictatorship.
They humbly pray and call upon Parliament to urge the Canadian government to apply pressure on the Rwandan regime to immediately stop killing innocent Rwandans. They urge the Canadian government to support the EEC resolution on Rwanda, issued on February 20, 1992.

speakerposition: Liberal Party Caucus Chair
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I have the honour of presenting to the House of Commons a petition signed by residents, many of them and most of them senior citizens from my riding.
They point out that hundreds of thousands of Canadian citizens live below the poverty line and particularly that 80 per cent of single women over the age of 65 live in poverty.
They are complaining of the 37 cents increase in April on their Old Age Security cheque. They are petitioning this government and this House to ensure pension benefits for seniors that would allow them not only to have their ends met, but to also allow them to have dignity at the same time.
We are asking this government to review this policy and to think that it was a shame to send a 37 cents increase per month per senior citizen.

Madam Speaker, I have the honour to present three petitions on the same subject representing about 90 people in my constituency and elsewhere.
The petitioners represent dump truckers which have little or no legal means of enforcing prevailing rates on the 'stated in contracts'.
They call upon this government to enact legislation for adoption of minimum rates schedules for dump trucks on federal projects at rates not less than the minimum truck haul rate and conditions set by each province with a federal project that is to be undertaken.

Madam Speaker, it is my privilege to present a petition concerning the Court Challenges Program.
This program has helped many individuals and minority groups to clarify their constitutional language and equality rights before the courts.
The elimination of this program represents an incalculable loss for social justice and equality in this country.
Parliament should consider the option of reinstating the Court Challenges Program, which gives all Canadians equal access to the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

Madam Speaker, it is my pleasure to present to the House a further petition spearheaded and gathered by Mrs. Eileen MacDonald from my riding. It is signed by around 70 residents of North York, Don Mills, East York, Toronto and Scarborough.
It calls upon the Parliament of Canada to enact legislation providing for a referendum binding upon Parliament to accept or reject constitutional amendments proposed by the government, the acceptance or rejection of the proposed amendments to be determined by a majority vote of total votes cast in the whole of Canada, together with a majority vote in a majority of provinces with the territories being given the status of one province.
This is a further petition presented through the hard work of Mrs. MacDonald. I am sure that the Parliament of Canada and the Government of Canada will ensure that this petition is granted.
June 15, 1992

Madam Speaker, I rise to introduce a petition signed by many people in the national capital region. These people are complaining about the unfair gasoline prices in the Ottawa-Carleton region.
As you know, gasoline prices in the Toronto area are much lower than in our region. This issue has really been of concern to many residents in my area. They look at it as discrimination against the consumers in this region and are calling on the federal government to take action on this issue.

Madam Speaker, I rise to present a petition signed by 100 people from Winnipeg who are very concerned about the treatment of the Tamils in north and east Sri Lanka.
Many of these people have had first-hand experience in dealing with this situation. They call upon the Government of Canada to intervene and to stop the flagrant human rights violations committed by the government of Sri Lanka and to ensure basic food, medicine and fuel supplies be permitted to reach the Tamils in the north and east of Sri Lanka.

Madam Speaker, I am very pleased to present a petition today signed by several hundred people from the province of Prince Edward Island.
It states that all provincial ministries of transportation and departments of highways have long recognized the validity and stabilizing effect of establishing minimum rates and cites a base for their own contracts involving dump truck work.
The lack of such minimum rates in federal projects leads to ruin of such prevailing rates. It creates predatory pricing and opens the door for other abuses.
The truckers have little or no legal means of enforcing prevailing rates unless stated in the contracts.
In the interests of keeping a viable and meaningful dump truck industry, these petitioners call upon Parliament to enact legislation for the adoption of a minimum rate schedule for dump trucks on federal projects at
Routine Proceedings
rates not less than the minimum truck haul rates and conditions set for each province where a federal project is to be undertaken.

Madam Speaker, I have the honour to present a petition concerning the proposed closure of light stations on the Pacific coast.
The petitioners request that the Government of Canada having decided not to close these lighthouses implement the terms of The Future Role of Light Stations report and that it return the roughly $1 million a year of federal funding removed from these light stations and the person years that were removed in anticipation of closures.
According to the petitioners, this would restore the safety and viability of light stations as a major component of the safety net on the coast of British Columbia.

Madam Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 36,1 would like to present a petition which relates to the Canadian government applying pressure on the regime in Rwanda to immediately stop killing innocent Rwandans.
The petitioners urge the Canadian government to stop economic aid and other forms of assistance to the current Rwandan regime. They urge the Canadian government to support the EEC resolution on Rwanda issued February 20, 1992.
