speechtext: The House resumed consideration of the motion of Ms. Campbell (Vancouver Centre) that Bill C-49, an act to amend the Criminal Code (sexual assault), be read the third time and passed.

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I introduced amendments to the Criminal Code regarding sexual assault on December 12, 1991.
The driving force behind the Bill C-49 amendments was the need to restore protection for victims of sexual assault in the wake of the Seaboyer decision which struck down former section 276 of the Criminal Code, commonly referred to as the rape shield provision.
Bill C-49 received second reading on April 8,1992 and was referred to a legislative committee for detailed review.

I was struck by the favourable reception given by members to Bill C-49. The same attitude and co-operation were evident during discussions before the legislative committee.
I have said many times, in response to questions about the wording of certain provisions of this bill, that the legislative committee was the appropriate venue for fine tuning the text to reflect accurately the general principles and substance of the bill. I am very grateful to the committee for the attention and care it gave to analysing the text of the bill, and I am also veiy grateful to the many witnesses who came to offer their comments and advice and tell us about their concerns.

June 15, 1992

The legislative committee heard a large number of witnesses, including representatives of the Canadian Bar Association, the Criminal Lawyers Association, the Canadian Civil Liberties Association, the Women's Legal Education and Action Fund, the Disabled Women's Network, the National Organization of Immigrant and Visible Minority Women of Canada, the Native Women's Association of Canada and the Canadian Association of Sexual Assault Centres. The committee also received briefs prepared by interest groups, individuals and academics.
Despite the extremely diverse interests represented by this broad range of witnesses, the principle of the bill was very well received by all. Comments and concerns tended to concentrate on a few similar aspects of the bill and the amendments proposed by the legislative committee are in direct response to the concerns expressed while the bill was being examined. I think these amendments have done much to improve the bill.

Before I begin to sketch out the amendments made by the legislative committee, I would like to set the record straight for those who have been following the media coverage of this issue by making some general comments about what Bill C-49 is not.
Bill C-49 does not outlaw sexual activity after a few glasses of wine. It does not require that written consent forms be signed before sexual activity, or that a third party be present as an observer to ensure that consent was given. It does not prohibit sexual activity between an employer and an employee, nor does it permit a person to wake up in the morning and revoke the consent given to the previous evening's sexual encounter.
This may seem like a frivolous thing to say about the legislation but it has been extraordinary in my mind to see some of the commentary and caricature of the very serious intent of this legislation that, in fact, makes it necessary to make those kinds of comments about what the bill is not.
On the contrary, Bill C-49 deals with three fundamental issues regarding sexual assault. The admissibility of evidence of a sexual assault and the complainant's sexual history and the applicable procedure, the definition of
Government Orders
consent, and the defence of honest but mistaken belief in consent. Amendments made by the legislative committee touch upon all three of the key features of Bill C-49.
With respect to the consent provisions, the committee amended three subsections which set out circumstances where no consent is obtained.
The subsection dealing with incapacity and intoxication was revised to delete the phrase "by reason of intoxication or other condition". The paragraph now reads: "No consent is obtained where the complainant is incapable of consenting". The revision puts the emphasis where it belongs, on incapacity rather than on the reason for the incapacity. It states the obvious. A person does not consent where they are incapable of consenting.
Section 273.1(2)(c) was revised to avoid the possible interpretation that an abuse of a position of trust or authority would exist where two people involved in such a relationship engaged in sexual activity, that is, to avoid the criticism this provision prohibited sex between an employer and employee or professor and student.
The key issue here is the abuse of the position. The revised wording will provide that no consent is obtained where the accused induces the complainant to engage in the activity by abusing a position of trust, power or authority.
The revision adds the requirement that the accused induce the complainant to engage in the activity and maintains the requirement of abuse of the position. The word "power" has been added to cover relationships not captured by the phrase "trust or authority".
Section 273.1(2)(e) was revised to avoid the criticism that consent could be revoked after the fact. For example, the next morning a person could claim that they no longer consented to the previous evening's sexual encounter. Although the law would never have permitted such a retrospective revocation, in the interests of clarity the provision has been amended. The revised wording will provide that no consent is obtained where the complainant, having consented to engage in sexual activity expresses by words or conduct a lack of agreement to continue to engage in the activity. That lack of consent of course only applies to the continuation of the activity for which there is no consent.

Government Orders
With respect to the defence of honest but mistaken belief in consent, the Canadian Bar Association, the Criminal Lawyers Association and the Civil Liberties Association argue that the requirement that the accused take all reasonable steps in the circumstances known to the accused at the time to ascertain consent in order to assert the defence imposed a standard which would be impossible for the accused to meet. However, the central idea that an accused should have done something to ascertain consent in order to argue that he honestly believed the complainant had consented was not disputed.
The committee, therefore, amended the provision to delete the word "all". The revised provision will state: "It is not a defence that the accused believed that the complainant consented or the accused did not take reasonable steps in the circumstances known to the accused at the time to ascertain that the complainant was consenting".
I believe this sets a standard which protects the complainant, the standard that was suggested by the Canadian Bar Association, "or any steps", we all agreed was too low. At the same time, it also respects the fundamental principle of criminal justice and that is the need to have a guilty mind or mens rea in order to establish criminal culpability.
I would also like to point out that this defence arises only after the Crown has proved that the complainant did not, in fact, consent to the sexual activity.

The legislative committee has amended the provisions relating to the prohibition of the publication of the judge's decision and reasons.
These amendments came in response to concerns expressed by the Canadian Civil Liberties Association, the B.C. Civil Liberties Association and the Canadian Association of Journalists, as ardent defenders of freedom of the press. They also respond to questions raised by various women's groups which maintain that the complainant's right of privacy should be protected, but the public should know how the law is applied.
According to the amendments made by the legislative committee, where the evidence is judged to be admissible, the judge's determination and reasons may be
published. Where the evidence is judged to be inadmissible, the judge's determination and reasons may be published if the judge so orders, after taking into account the complainant's right of privacy and the interests of justice. The judge who initially decides that a hearing should be held to determine whether the evidence is admissible may, after taking into account the complainant's right of privacy and the interests of justice, order publication of the decision.
In addition to the amendments made to the clauses of the bill which I have highlighted, the legislative committee carefully considered the contents of the preamble. I attach a great deal of importance to the preamble since it states our collective intentions as members of Parliament and as legislators in reforming our sexual assault laws.
The legislative committee has amended the preamble to refer specifically to the prevalence of sexual assault against women and children. In addition, the order of the paragraphs has been changed to put greater emphasis on the protection of charter rights, which will now be in paragraph 3. Some minor changes in the wording have also been made.

We now have before us a considerably improved and readily comprehensible bill that aims to identify and codify the rules of law for determining the admissibility of evidence relating to the complainant's sexual history, a bill that fills in the gaps in the former rape shield provisions which caused them to be struck down.
Procedural safeguards for victims of sexual assault have been reinstated. The complainant is no longer obliged to testify at the preliminary hearing to determine the admissibility of evidence relating to the complainant's sexual history; the hearing will be held in camera. Publication of the judge's determination and reasons may be prohibited in certain circumstances. The current provisions of the Criminal Code will prohibit publication of information revealing the identity of the complainant.
These amendments are based on present day reality and on the principles set forth by the Supreme Court of Canada. They take into account the fundamental principles of trial procedure and admissibility of evidence.



I would like again to thank all members of the House, particularly the members of the legislative committee, for their comments and careful consideration. The provisions of Bill C-49 will ensure the much needed improvements to benefit sexual assault victims while respecting the rights of accused persons to defend themselves against allegations of sexual assaults.
I would also like to emphasize that during the period of time since this bill was tabled in the House, particularly over the period of time when my colleagues on the legislative committee were hearing witnesses and discussing the bill and generating public debate, I have had an inordinate number of comments made by members of the public across this country with respect to this legislation. I have been very gratified to see that irrespective of gender and irrespective of region, Canadians feel very comforted by this piece of legislation. I have had men thank me for this piece of legislation and for the law relating to sexual assault, and women who feel very strongly gratified and validated that the reality of life as they live it in Canada and their concerns have been reflected in this legislation.
I want to conclude by again thanking my colleagues in the House, the critics and the member for Cape Breton-The Sydneys over there who has played such a fundamental role along with his colleagues. Our colleagues in the New Democratic Party I believe at the moment are involved in a very important press conference on another issue relating to women. They have been very, very helpful as well. I want to thank them again for their care and consideration in dealing with what was in many ways a contentious and sensitive issue. They did it in a way that I believe represented the finest of the parliamentary tradition. I believe that we have made an important statement. I believe that we are dealing with an important provision of law that is respectful of the fundamental traditions of criminal justice that we all uphold but, at the same time, is a law for the last decade of the 21st century and truly enfranchises all Canadians.
Therefore, I want to again say thank you and to say that it will be many years before I forget the second reading debate on this legislation and the kinds of comments made by members in this House. They represented a quantum leap in the enfranchisement of Canadian women and the ability of parliamentarians of both
Government Orders
founding genders of this country to respect and understand the reality of all Canadians. I thank them very much for that experience.

Madam Speaker, I am very pleased to be able to debate today on Bill C-49.
I want to share with the minister my feelings and my satisfaction that we have here a good piece of legislation. There are some points, some things about it, that I had hoped would have been changed and I will refer to some of those. Basically, as the minister has said, we have made a major leap forward with this legislation.
I do feel that we have to have some idea in Canada, everyone in this country has to be aware, of what we are trying to do with this legislation. There have been a lot of things said by various members of the bar, by other segments of society, which indicated to me that they really did not know the depth of the problem that exists, not only in Canada but throughout the world, and the disadvantaged position in which women find themselves in this country and throughout every country in the world.
What we have to do here is ask if we are going to accept that. Are we going to say that we want to keep legal niceties at the risk of putting women in a position in which they will constantly feel fear, will constantly question the justice system, will constantly ask members of Parliament and other members in authority in this country when they are going to realize that women do not have an equal position in this country?
We have talked about job equality. We have talked about equal pay for work of equal value. This is an area in which men in Canada do not realize that women have had a very, very detrimental position as far as their rights within the law are concerned. We have not realized that the law has actually put women in a very derogatory position as far as their rights are concerned.
What we have to look at is what we want to achieve. We want to achieve for women in this country the right to be able to bring action against sexual assault. We want every Canadian to feel that sexual assault is not something that is going to happen or that there is nothing that they can do about it. We have to erase the feeling that sexual assault is a part of growing up, that it is a part of living and there is nothing to be done, that you just have to endure it. That is not the way it has to be in Canada. That is not the way it should be in Canada.

June 15, 1992
Government Orders
Before 1983, a woman who brought a charge of sexual a bold move on the part of the Minister of Justice. It is a assault was questioned without, in some cases, any very difficult thing to do. It is very important because this bounds whatsoever on her past sexual history, not only is the way we can state in the legislation exactly what with regard to the accused, but generally speaking on all consent is going to be. her sexual activity that the other side could conjure up. It would get to the point at which the woman was actually
the accused because she was placed in such an uncom- We will be able to say that women in this country have fortable position within the court structure that no means by which they know what their rights are. The woman wanted to bring an action of sexual assault. men will have to learn this act and realize that things
such as extreme intoxication of the woman are not consent. That is very important.
Fortunately in 1983 there was an amendment to the Criminal Code in section 276 in which it was stated that you could only bring evidence of the past sexual history when: one, the Crown opened up the area by bringing in allegations or information on past sexual history; two, where it was alleged that the accused did not commit the assault; and three, where the accused was saying that it was important that this information come forward because there was other sexual activity that happened just before, just after or about the same time so that it was an integral part of his or her case.
This greatly reduced the trauma that women felt in bringing sexual assault cases before the courts. Unfortunately or fortunately, whatever way you want to look at it, we could not maintain section 276. It is also fortunate that within our system of law in Canada our courts are looking after the rights of all Canadians. They decided that section 276 could not stand a charter challenge and that it contravened section 7 of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. That was in August 1991.
Then the Minister of Justice brought forward this bill, Bill C-49, last December. As the minister said, we had a very good debate on second reading and then it went to legislative committee. There were some changes made. The bill is a much better bill.
The bill we have today does three things mainly. It provides for strict guidelines in determining the admissibility of past sexual history as far as the evidence in court is concerned. It outlines clearly the procedure which must be followed in admitting such evidence.
It also defines the notion of consent to sexual activity. This idea of defining consent is a very important one and
That is going to mean that a lot of people who go out and party and get intoxicated are now going to realize that their actions are going to be under severe scrutiny if the complainant states that he or she did not give consent. That is a major step forward. It is important that the ramifications in this bill receive a clear screening and that we educate Canadians as to what this bill really does. It is an important bill. It is important for Canadians to realize exactly what it says.
One of the aspects which raised concern initially was that there may be no consent if the complainant is incapable of consenting by reason of intoxication or other conditions. We have since in the legislative committee taken out the words "intoxication or other conditions". That does not, however, mean that intoxication has been taken out of the bill as far as prohibiting consent is concerned.
If a person is intoxicated, severely intoxicated and really would not know what she or he is doing, consent cannot be assumed. It will have to be determined by the courts whether he or she gave consent to the sexual activity. That is very important.
In the next section the minister says that honest but mistaken belief in consent is not a defence. We mentioned the fact the accused did not take "all reasonable steps" in the circumstances known to the accused at the time to ascertain if the complainant was consenting.
You look at that and you say well that is just not reasonable. If a person is before the courts and they are accused, then evidently they did not take all reasonable steps. You cannot have it as a criteria that the accused took all reasonable steps.
June 15, 1992

Second, who is to say what all reasonable steps are. In each case a judge will determine whether there is something else the accused should have considered. If every time there is a trial, a judge or defence counsel states this is something else that could have been considered, the case would have to be thrown out, because here is a new criteria of reasonable steps that was not taken into consideration.
While there are concerns among some of the women's groups that the bill is no longer strong enough, I believe this amendment was made in the best interests of the legislation and of really protecting this legislation from a charter challenge.
There were groups which said that instead of saying all reasonable steps we should say any reasonable steps. That would go too much the other way. We would then be weakening the bill. By just saying reasonable steps, it would leave it to the court and I think that is a very fanway of doing it.
There are some things about the bill, however, I have difficulty with. One is that the question of whether the complainant's past sexual history is to come before the courts is going to be decided in what is really a voir dire. It is going to be a hearing within the main trial itself, at which time the judge will decide in closed court if the evidence is or is not suitable to the nature of the case and if it has a bearing on the accused's case.
The question is, what is going to be considered as relevant? That has to be left up to the judge and that is important. If the judge determines that the past sexual history should be allowed in and it is in the interests of the accused that this be brought forward, the judge can also then decide whether the press should be able to report on that evidence. That was another change in second reading.
My concern here is that the complainant is not compelled to testify in this hearing. It may be a problem as far as the courts are concerned as they may feel the accused is not able to get a fair hearing because the complainant does not have to testify. That is not to say that in most cases the complainant's testimony would be important. It may very well not be important in most cases but in certain cases it may be necessary.
I am also concerned because if the complainant is not being compelled in certain instances to testify, there is
Government Orders
going to be a lot of hearsay evidence brought into the hearing.
Another thing that concerns me is that in the hearing the judge has to consider society's interests. I honestly feel in a court of law there is to be one major objective, and that is the innocence or guilt of the accused. Under no circumstances should we be trying to decide anything else.
When we are talking about legislation, we are talking about society's interests. Right now debating this bill, we are discussing society's interests. That is very important. We have to look at society's interests. It is a fundamental obligation of members of Parliament when we are discussing legislation. We are now looking at society's interests.
When the Crown prosecutor decides whether he or she wants to proceed and on what grounds, under what section of the Criminal Code for instance, the Crown prosecutor is looking at society's interests and taking them into consideration.
When the decision of innocence or guilt is brought forward, the judge will determine sentencing in society's interests. In the actual body of the trial or any hearing within the trial, to me it is not right to inject society's interests. That is not a fundamental factor in determining the innocence or guilt of the accused. The accused should not have to bear that hurdle. I feel that should not be in the legislation and frankly, it is harmful to the legislation.
I do feel there was one area in which we did not go far enough, not that the area is of vital importance legally because not everything that is in legislation has to have strict legal terminology and is only for legal purposes. We are saying in this bill, by the wording in the preamble, that we want to get our intentions to the judge and that we want the justice system to know about our feelings on why this bill is being presented and what we want to achieve as parliamentarians.
The government stated that very eloquently in the preamble. The language is very good and it is very clear. I think it is going to be helpful. The minister has said that the preamble is not going to be a part of the Criminal Code. That is fair enough. It will presumably be in the commentary in the Criminal Code. That is going to be helpful as well.

June 15, 1992
Government Orders
Women's groups that came before us said that we did not really understand the problems of disabled women, the problems of visible minorities, of sex trade workers, of those who are under pressure because their immigration hearing is pending, or because they are in a vulnerable position because of their employment. They explained to us that we do not realize that these people are not able to convince a judge or a policeman or somebody else in the criminal justice system that they did not consent more easily than a white woman would. What judges who are mainly white middle-aged men see in a white woman is their wife or their daughter or somebody like that. They do not see that when the person is from a visible minority. They do not as readily give the benefit of the doubt to somebody who was not a visible minority.
We know what the law says. The law says that everybody is treated equally before the courts, that justice applies equally to all Canadians. We know that. We have heard it, we have had it told to us, we have read it and that may be the case in most instances. That is something we want to believe. We have seen it. They have been assaulted by policemen who feel because that person is a visible minority, it will not matter if they are sexually assaulted. We have seen cases of that. We know that the law does not apply equally.
We want to overcome that. We want to redress that problem. We want to say that consent should not be implied because the person is a sex trade worker, because the person is disabled, because the person is a visible minority, because the person is under pressure of an immigration hearing or because of their employment. We want that in the bill. They may say it is not necessary but we feel it is.
After hearing these women I frankly feel it is necessary because there is obviously a problem. I think it is important not only to these women but also to people in homosexual relationships, and where we in Canada believe the rights of people have to be upheld. We also feel that if Canadians feel they are not being given equal treatment before the law then we have to bring forward a statement that would help these people see that the law is going to be equally applied to them.
This is a very important request. I know the minister thinks there should be something done in this regard. I
am hoping that something will be done even though it is not in the bill.
The education of the members of the judiciary is very important. I think that should be done. I was hoping the government would bring forward an amendment at report stage that that would deal with this, but unfortunately it did not.
I leave it with the minister and I ask her to please consider this concern that many Canadians have. I ask her, in ways that she may think expedient, to address this concern.
The concern does not end there. This bill is, as I have stated, a major advance as far as women's rights in Canada are concerned. We have to do considerably more. We need new pornography laws. As a result of the Butler decision the minister has said that she hopes to bring forward new pornography laws in the fall, hopefully in September, particularly with respect to child pornography.
These are all parts of what we want to achieve. The question of urban violence is a major concern in this country.
What we have to realize is that in this country women have not had the same feeling about protecting themselves that men have seemed to feel that women should have.
They do not realize, and I have said this before, that a woman leaving a bus stop, getting off a bus after dark in any size Canadian city these days is in constant fear as she walks to her home or to her apartment. That fear does not end upon the woman going into the building. The fear can exist that someone on the elevator, or someone on the very floor on which she lives, could assault her. This fear is constant and I do not think many men in this country realize this.
Frankly I think it is this bill and legislation such as this that will help to address this question.
It is really not satisfactory when we realize that in this country one woman in four is sexually assaulted. Of those one in four that is sexually assaulted only one in 10 will actually report that sexual assault. That is largely because the woman does not think that her concerns are going to be taken seriously by the judicial system. She feels that she is just really letting herself in for a very

difficult time when all of the past sexual activity is going to be brought up in open court.
We should not be convicting people who are not guilty, but we should be making sure that those who are guilty are going to be convicted. Not every time, there is no way you can assure that that is going to happen. The circumstances have to be such that the woman will come before the court to lay a charge and that the structure will indicate that there is a path to follow, that there is a means of bringing forward the evidence and that a conviction actually can be brought forward, certainly more frequently than once every 20 cases when it comes to trial.
We had some concern in the legislative committee. There were people proposing that this bill was not going to be charter proof on the basis that it did not differentiate between a sexual assault that was done through the mistaken belief that the accused had consented, on the one hand, and a sexual assault that was premeditated and done with full planning and intent to injure on the other. There were those who said that it is unconstitutional if you cannot ensure that those who do something through negligence or by accident do not receive a lighter sentence than those who commit an offence intentionally. One case that comes to mind is the Martineau case where Chief Justice Lamer gave the decision. He stated that it was a constitutional principle that those who cause harm intentionally must be punished more severely than those who cause harm unintentionally.
I asked the minister and officials of the Department of Justice and they were able to assure us that that principle would be upheld. They gave the assurance that he who commits an assault through the mistaken belief that he had consent would not be treated as harshly as somebody who intentionally committed the assault. I feel that that is important and I have every reason to believe that the Department of Justice has looked at this point.
In closing, I feel that this bill is a major step forward. We have done something here which is going to greatly correct the imbalance that women have suffered as far as their equal rights before the judicial system are concerned. These were not intentional oversights; it was just the way the law was. It seemed to indicate to women that they were going to be victims themselves if they were
Government Orders
willing to withstand the harsh cross-examination on past sexual history. We now have a clear idea of what constitutes consent. There are those who will say that this is too rigorous, but I want to say that we have the definition and that is very very important. Because we know what we want to do, because it is stated in the bill, I think that this will be a major step forward. This is a good bill. We are doing something here that really has needed to be done for a long time.
I think this is going to be accepted by Canadians, both men and women, throughout the country as a major step forward.

Madam Speaker, I rise on behalf of my party, the New Democratic Party, to make some remarks on this bill.
As the House knows, in committee and in the debate the major spokesperson for the NDP was my colleague from New Westminster-Burnaby, who is our spokesperson on women's issues. She will be speaking later in the debate today. I rose because as my party's justice critic I wanted to make some specific comments on the bill.
This is a bill which we are supporting, a bill on which we worked very hard in committee to make better. We succeeded somewhat but in other parts we did not succeed. I will speak about that in a moment.
It is an important bill, one of the most important bills of this Parliament. I want to be honest and straightforward here and give a little bit of a personal reaction if I might. Before I do so, I congratulate my colleague, the hon. member for Cape Breton-The Sydneys, the Liberal critic who spoke eloquently today. He spoke especially eloquently at second reading of the debate.
That leads me to my confession. I come at this issue as a former criminal lawyer, as a prosecutor and especially as defence counsel. I guess I have the focus that the criminal bar has on the accused and the rights of the accused. It was put well by the member for Cape Breton-The Sydneys. We were taught the old saying that it is better that 10 guilty men go free than one innocent man be found guilty. Notice the word "men" that is used in the expression.
Where the criminal bar comes in, the defence bar, is a real focus on protecting the rights of the accused. I came at the debate with support of the bill but with some scepticism about the bill. I had an opportunity to listen. As Tommy Douglas used to say when people heckled

June 15, 1992
Government Orders
him: "The good Lord gave you two ears and only one mouth. That means you should listen twice as much as you speak". Maybe we should take that advice more in politics.
I had the opportunity since my colleague from New Westminster-Burnaby was the lead spokesperson on the bill to junior, if you like, in legal terms, to be the kind of second lawyer or the second string part of the team here. I got a chance to listen.
What I heard was remarkable, in three areas. One was in the House in the debate on second reading. Second was in committee and third in the level of public debate that we had in the country in the papers, on radio and television.
Let me talk about the House because it was a remarkable debate. There was a clear view expressed in this House of a determination to change the present law, more than any other debate I have seen in a long time. It was really a wonderful debate. It was wonderful in the sense that people poured out emotions and spoke from the heart, especially the women members of the House.
I learned that violence against women and children is epidemic in our society. I knew that, but I had not had it expressed in the same kind of way it was expressed in the House. That male violence seems to be rooted in the inequality in our society. That inequality reinforces the violence and that is something we should all think about.
The statistics are dramatic. One in four women are victims of sexual assault, half before the age of 17. One hundred and ten women are murdered every year by a male intimate, 110 women. One in eight women is battered by a partner. The majority of women in Canada are afraid to walk the streets of our cities and towns.
You may say: "You should have heard that before". Coming at things from a male point of view, especially a white, middle class, WASPish male, sometimes you are not aware of that. You are aware but you do not really feel it. You can walk down the street at night. You can park your car in a dark garage with no problem. What is the problem?
When I heard my fellow members of the House express their concerns and feelings, it made quite an impact on me, and I hope it made an impact on Canadians.
In the committee the National Action Committee on the Status Women in a first-rate brief said: "We believe from our experience that the majority of women have experienced some form of male violence if we include sexual harassment, sexual assault, incest, and battering". That is staggering. I was listening to that in committee.
Some of the other evidence or words that I heard were that sexist and racist stereotypes and myths promote sexual assault and prevent access to justice for survivors. Men are socialized to become aggressors in sexual relations, women to be passive and submissive.
I remember these comments in the House where women members said that women are divided into good girls and bad girls, with the bad girls being less worthy of legal protection. Aboriginal women experience a significantly higher level of violence than other women. More than 40 per cent of women with disabilities have been sexually assaulted. Prostitutes experience an average of five rapes a year each. These were staggering-
More than that.

My colleague says "more". The evidence that came out in committee was pretty staggering. I guess what I am saying is that I was listening to that in the House.
Then we went into committee and we had a number of briefs in the committee. Again, according to the rape crisis centres in the country, only one in 10 women who report sexual assault to the crisis centres get access to the criminal justice system, yet 27,000 sexual assaults were reported to the police in 1990.
A 1977 study found that 70 per cent of rapes reported to the police never reached trial and only 10 per cent of the original charges resulted in conviction. One would like to think that things have dramatically changed but a 1990 study shows that 15 per cent of sexual assaults reported to police were considered unfounded compared to 4.3 per cent for break and enter reports.
June 15, 1992

I had confirmed to me in committee what I knew before, but I never had it confirmed in such a systematic way. Sexual assault is the most under-reported and under-convicted crime against a person.
There you have it. There you have the need for this law. That is a situation where a crime is not being reported because women are afraid to come forward. They are not listened to and so on. They have to go through a hassle in the trial including, before we had passed the previous law, their whole being coming under attack, their own sexual history. In fact instead of being the victim they become almost like the accused. That is rough. That is the problem. That is why this bill is here.
I should say that I am disappointed that the government did not accept the amendment introduced by my colleague, the member for New Westminster-Burnaby, to specifically name doubly disadvantaged women. Sixty diverse women's organizations came together to work on the wording and finally agreed on amendments that all women felt comfortable with. I believe their perspective is not reflected in the bill.
In some ways the bill is still a bill for white, middle-class-this time-women. We have forgotten about visible minorities, disabled people, and other groups of women who are particularly hard hit. We have introduced amendments on behalf of the New Democratic Party to address the concerns of these particular groups.
Nevertheless, the bill is a step forward from the sexual assault law that we now have, in which men can claim that they have an honest but reasonable belief that there was consent and that is good enough to get them off no matter how hard the woman fought, what she said, or whether there was really any consent. I have already said that the number of sexual assaults that were unreported and the rate of conviction were very low.
The law also states for the first time that consent cannot be given by a third party. A man was acquitted of sexual assault despite a clear lack of consent on the part of the woman in the case because her husband told the man that she liked rough sex. Husbands and pimps can no longer encourage other men to rape women and get away with it under the provisions of this law.
In other words, an accused cannot come into court and say that this other man, this third person said that she
Government Orders
was willing. That is not consent; you have to ask her. That sounds logical, does it not? It sounds simple but it is a big change in the law and it is in this bill. That is one of the reasons we are supporting this bill.
The bill defines an abuse of trust and authority as an assault. If a woman is forced into sex by virtue of the fact that the man is a police officer, or has other power over her, that is now unacceptable in the eyes of the law. Again, that is an amendment that was a long time coming.
There is a preamble in this bill, making it a different sort of bill. It makes explicit that the Parliament of Canada wants to see justice served by protecting the rights of the accused as well as the victims. This is something new, and it is a good direction for Parliament. We are looking at the rights of victims as well.
It clearly states what this law is for and why it is being enacted. We hope this will prevent the misuse of sexual assault laws, such as the sexual assault charges levelled against an HIV positive woman in my own province of British Columbia who had sex with two men without condoms. She was charged. We should look at the intent of this law, the courts should look at it, the prosecuting officers should look at it, and it is set out in the preamble of the bill.
Under this bill a man cannot rape an unconscious or incapacitated woman and get away with it, as in several unfortunate and painful cases in the past. There was a case in the Northwest Territories in which a woman was raped who was incapacitated by alcohol. The judge said: "Well, if there is a pair of hips there, that is asking for it".
There are some things we should watch with regard to the bill, and the member for Cape Breton-The Sydneys considered them. We should be watching the media provisions, the reaction of the court in terms of whether the bill is charter proof, the development of the cases, the conviction rate and so on to determine whether the bill makes any difference.
I said when I started that I listened to speeches in the House and in the committee, and I mentioned the level of debate in the public. I recall waking up one morning-,I was trying to sleep in-and listening to the

June 15, 1992
Government Orders
Gzowski show on CBC Radio. Who did I hear on it but the Minister of Justice debating with Clay Ruby, a distinguished lawyer in Toronto and a very good friend of mine.
Mr. Ruby and I handled our first case together in Yorkville in the hippie days in Toronto. He is a very articulate and experienced lawyer and this was an articulate debate. The Minister of Justice certainly held her own, and perhaps did even better than hold her own.
I think the Minister of Justice would agree that there was a high level of debate in the public. The minister wrote a letter to the editor. There was a high level of debate in that. There were replies, especially in The Globe and Mail. The matter was treated seriously. It was treated seriously in editorials.
I know that J. J. Camp, president of the Canadian Bar Association, made a real effort to try to get the rough edges off the bill but keep it an effective bill.
We have been lucky in this debate. It is the way Parliament should work. We will see what happens as the bill becomes law and it affects cases.
A strong rape law will not prevent sexual assault. I think we all recognize that. I wish it would. I wish all we had to do was pass this bill and that would be the end of the problem.
It may not even convince most women to report the crime of rape, although we genuinely hope they will. We hope the bill will help there. Eliminating the sexist and racist biases of our society as a whole and the judicial system in particular is necessary if we want to convince more women to report rape.
A strong "no means no" law is a beginning step toward the other changes that must be made. A strong "no means no" law would be a signal to judges, Crown counsels, defence lawyers, police, and most important, women, that Parliament intends justice to apply to women as well as men. A strong "no means no" law could help to change our culture in regard to sexuality.
That is why I am supporting this bill. I learned a lot in the debate. I think it was an excellent debate and an excellent process with regard to this bill. My colleague
from New Westminster-Burnaby will have other comments to make and I hope some of my other colleagues will speak in this debate this afternoon.
With that, I will conclude and urge that the House pass the bill.
