Madam Speaker, I am delighted to stand today in support of Bill C-49, on the admissibility of evidence of sexual conduct.
On August 22, 1991 the Supreme Court of Canada struck down section 276 of the Criminal Code, which was commonly known as the rape shield provision, in the case of Seaboyer and Gayme.
Section 276 prohibited the reception of evidence in sexual assault cases of a victim's previous sexual history except in three narrow circumstances. The Supreme Court of Canada held that section 276 overshot the mark in protecting complainants. It held that section 276 had the potential to exclude evidence relevant to the defence and was therefore a violation of sections 7 and 11(d) of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. The Supreme Court of Canada suggested guidelines to govern the receipt of evidence of past sexual activity in the absence of legislation.
The decision of the Supreme Court of Canada was swiftly criticized by equality rights-seeking women's groups. It cannot be denied that although sexual assault can be committed against a man the overwhelming majority of victims are women and children. Women feel very vulnerable without the protections formerly provided by the law. While the Supreme Court suggested guidelines for the admission and use in evidence of a sexual assault victim's sexual activity the judgment was silent on a number of issues of great significance to victims of sexual assault.

The proposed amendments in Bill C-49 will clarify the law and the procedure regarding the admissibility of evidence of the victim's sexual activity and will restore essential protection for the victims.
Victim's rights advocates have long maintained that victims of crime are the forgotten persons in the criminal justice system. The amendments proposed in Bill C-49 are an excellent example of how law can effectively respond to victims of crime without jeopardizing in any way the fundamental rights of accused persons. The Bill C-49 amendments are also an excellent example of how the law must conform to current social realities.
The offence of rape was abolished in 1983 and replaced with three levels of sexual assault offences. The trauma suffered by rape victims cannot be so easily abolished nor can the image of the rape victim being once again victimized, this time by the court process.
The Supreme Court of Canada has clearly stated that striking down the so-called rape shield provision does not revive the old common law rules of evidence that permitted evidence of sexual conduct and condoned invalid inferences from it. The rules must be adapted to conform to current reality. The myths that the rape shield provisions sought to eradicate have no place in a rational and just system of law.
The Criminal Code amendments proposed in Bill C-49 will ensure that a rational and just system of law prevails. With respect to the admissibility of evidence of a sexual assault victim's sexual activity with any person, including the accused person, the proposed amendments include a general statement about the purposes for which such evidence may not be used, a new test for admissibility of such evidence, and detailed procedural provisions to govern determinations of admissibility.
The Supreme Court of Canada has unequivocally stated that the fact that the complainant has engaged in other sexual activity with any person, including the accused, should not lead to the inference that the complainant is more likely to have consented to the sexual activity in question nor should it lead to the inference that the complainant is less worthy of belief.
Subsection 276(1) will put this principle into the Criminal Code to ensure that evidence that the complainant has engaged in sexual activity is not admissible
Government Orders
to support an inference that the complainant is more likely to consent or is less worthy of belief.
Bill C-49's single most important feature is the test for admissibility of evidence of a complainant's sexual activity. I would prefer not to use the term "new rape shield provision" but this may be unavoidable.
Proposed subsection 276(2) sets out the test for admissibility of evidence of a complainant's sexual activity with any person, including the accused. The amendment avoids the pitfalls of the former section 276 that was struck down. It does not set out a blanket exclusion with narrow exceptions that the evidence an accused seeks to introduce must fit into. The new test for admissibility places the responsibility of determining whether the evidence is admissible on the trial judge. The trial judge has the task of assessing whether the evidence meets the requirements of section 276.
The questions the judge must ask are: Is it evidence of specific instances of sexual activity? Is it relevant to an issue at trial? Does the evidence have significant probative value that is not substantially outweighed by the danger of prejudice to the proper administration of justice? If the answer is yes to all three questions then the evidence will be admissible.
The task of determining admissibility will not be a simple one. Trial judges will be required to give serious consideration to this issue.
Proposed subsection 276(3) sets out a range of considerations which a judge must take into account in determining whether evidence of a complainant's sexual activity is admissible in accordance with the new test of admissibility. These factors are intended to assist judges in the difficult task of assessing whether the evidence should be admitted. The mandatory factors ensure that all Canadian judges will be guided by the same considerations in exercising their discretion in determining the admissibility of evidence.
The factors to be considered include: the interests of justice, including the right of the accused to make a full answer and defence; society's interest in encouraging the reporting of sexual assault offences; whether there is a reasonable prospect that the evidence will assist in arriving at a just determination in the case; the need to remove from the fact-finding process any discriminatory

June 15, 1992
Government Orders
belief on bias; the risk that the evidence may unduly arouse sentiments of prejudice, sympathy or hostility in the jury; the potential prejudice to the complainant's personal dignity and right of privacy; the right of the complainant and every individual to personal security and to the full protection and benefit of the law; and any other factor that the judge considers relevant.
Bill C-49 also includes a clear and enhanced procedure applicable to a determination of admissibility of sexual conduct evidence. Basically a two-stage procedure is proposed. First, an application to adduce evidence of a complainant's sexual activity must be made. Second, if the application is granted a hearing must be held to determine whether the evidence is admissible in accordance with the new test proposed.
The procedure begins with an application in writing setting out detailed particulars of the evidence sought to be introduced and the potential relevance to that evidence. The application must be made to a judge with a copy to the prosecutor and clerk of the court. A seven-day notice period is provided to enable the prosecutor to prepare argument as to whether or not the evidence should be subject to a determination of admissibility. Provision is also made for an abridged notice period where the interests of justice so require.
The application stage is designed to discourage frivolous attempts to introduce evidence of sexual activity. Where the judge is of the opinion that the evidence sought to be introduced is not capable of meeting the test for admissibility, the judge will not hold a hearing to make such a determination. Where an application is granted, the judge will hold a hearing to determine the admissibility of evidence in accordance with the test proposed.
The hearing will take place in the absence of the jury and members of the public. Note that the complainant is not a compellable witness at the hearing. At the conclusion of the hearing, the judge will determine if the evidence is admissible and will be required to state the reasons for. the determination.
The reasons must be written or recorded and must refer to the factors that have influenced the determination. The reasons must also indicate the manner in which the evidence is expected to be relevant. The judge may determine that only part of the evidence sought to be
adduced meets the test of admissibility and, if so, the reasons would state the part of the evidence to be admitted.
These procedural provisions require judges to proceed through a staged analysis when considering admissibility. More than a brief reference to the test of admissibility is required in the judge's reasons.
The amendments proposed in Bill C-49 also restore provisions which protect the victim from embarrassment and which respect the victim's privacy and dignity. For example, the hearing to determine admissibility shall be held in camera, that is the public and the jury are excluded. The victim shall not be compellable at the hearing, that is the victim cannot be compelled to be a witness at the hearing although the victim may voluntarily take the stand. Evidence taken or information given at the hearing shall not be published in any newspaper or broadcast.
The re-enactment of the non-compellability provisions is essential in order to protect victims and encourage their co-operation in prosecutions. Note that the complainant may give evidence if he or she chooses to do so.
However, the complainant could not be required to testify at the hearing to determine admissibility. Bill C-49 also provides that the determination of admissibility of evidence of a complainant's sexual activity shall be conducted in the absence of the jury and members of the public, i.e., in camera.
The procedural provisions set out a two-step process, an application followed by a hearing. A judge considering an application to introduce evidence of a complainant's sexual activity must do so in the absence of the jury and the public. If the application is granted and a hearing is held to determine the admissibility of such evidence, the hearing must also be held in camera.
The objective of the in camera hearing is to ensure that the jury and the public do not hear evidence of the complainant's sexual activity before a judge has determined whether such evidence is admissible. The exposure of evidence of the complainant's sexual activity which may be misleading and irrelevant would have a highly prejudicial effect on the trial process and would cause unnecessary embarrassment to the complainant.
June 15, 1992

The proposed amendments governing the reception and use of evidence of a sexual assault victim's sexual history reflect the current reality of the 1990s. That is that evidence of the complainant's sexual history is rarely relevant to the issue before the court.
However, where that evidence is relevant, the Criminal Code permits its admission. Bill C-49 amendments reflect the very sensitive balance between the interests of the victims and the rights of the accused persons.

Madam Speaker, I am delighted to rise to participate in this debate at third reading because of the absolute essential nature of having this legislation.
The problem that this legislation is meant to address is essentially a problem of attitudes and it is very, very difficult as everyone in this Chamber knows to legislate with regard to attitudes. Indeed, for many years one of the arguments against legislation of this nature, one of the many arguments against the legislation that this is replacing-in other words, the charter defeated rape shield provisions of the Criminal Code-was that you cannot legislate attitudes. I think all of us who support this bill say that not only can you legislate attitudes, but you must.
There is a very frightening attitude if you will in this country today. It is not held by all fortunately, but unfortunately it is held by enough people. That attitude is that women somehow are less believable, that women are less credible witnesses, that women invite sexual assault, that women are somehow less innocent victims when the crimes of which they are the subject are crimes that have "a sexual nature".
First of all, it is well established in the academic and scholarly literature surrounding these criminal issues that such crimes are not crimes of a sexual nature. That is the first attitude that legislation like this must change. Indeed, crimes of this nature are crimes of power and crimes of violence. Women in our society are by and large powerless. This is why they are so frequently the victims of these cowardly crimes.
When the legislation was first changed some 10 to 12 years ago, one of the things that was changed was the removal of the word "rape" from the Criminal Code. The theory behind that deletion was that the word itself was so pejorative that it set up a victimology, the same
Government Orders
kind of victimology we are trying to delete right now with this legislation. The word rape was so pejorative that people immediately reacted to it by blaming the victim.
It is interesting. We do not deal with it in this legislation nor indeed is it perhaps necessary to deal in this legislation right now with these particular amendments. I hope we will deal with it at some other time.
A lot of feminists and criminologists thought that perhaps we moved too quickly and moved too soon on the removal of that word from the Criminal Code. There is no question the word is blunt, it is direct and you know what it means. We have removed that and replaced it with the words "sexual assault" which somehow contributes to the attitude that these crimes are not as serious as the vast majority sitting in this room know they are.
We are hearing over and over again, as we read in the papers, as we watch television, as we listen to our radios and as we as parliamentarians hear the experiences of our constituents, that there is an upsurge in crimes of violence against women including those crimes of sexual assault. My own fear, and sometimes I almost hesitate to articulate it for fear of articulation making it more true, is that we are suffering through a major backlash that relates to the further emancipation of women in our society today. The fear of women stepping out of the traditional roles of homemaker and mother and into the boardrooms, into the professions and even to a small extent into this Chamber, Madam Speaker, and into your chair, is creating a backlash of fear, anger and yes, even hatred among certain sectors in our society.
Because of this backlash of fear, anger and hatred, crimes of violence against women are on the increase. We certainly know they are on the increase. We are waiting for various people and various organizations such as the Canadian Panel on Violence Against Women to give us some answer as to why they are on the increase.
When the old rape shield laws were thrown out by the Supreme Court based on the charter argument, it was absolutely crucial that the government step forward and give us something to replace them with. This legislation may not be perfect. My colleague, the member for Cape Breton-The Sydneys, brought forward a number of amendments that I certainly supported. By and large,

Government Orders
this legislation deserves to be supported because it is a fairly substantial step in the right direction.
There are two major problems, the first one being the attitudinal problem. The second one is the need to convince women that they can get justice without too much fear in our law courts. Without legislation such as this, it makes it all the harder for those people working in the area against sexual assault to convince women of this.
As every one of us must know, those of us who are lawyers have seen it first hand, others have heard about it, read about it or witnessed it through family and friends, the events surrounding a trial, surrounding charges being laid on matters of sexual assault create a double victimization. Even if all of the victim's rights are protected, her privacy, her right not to have to disclose irrelevant background information, et cetera, even if these rights are respected, the mere fact of pressing the charge means that she has to relive the horror of the sexual assault. That is going to be a difficult endeavour for anyone. How much worse will it be if she does not feel that she is protected against having to be cross-examined on what is ostensibly irrelevant information.
It is crucial that the women of Canada understand exactly what this legislation will do. We know the statistics but they bear repeating. In 1990, 27,000 sexual assaults were reported to the police-27,000, Madam Speaker, and we know that over 60 per cent of sexual assaults are not reported. So when you see those figures, you see just how widespread a problem it is and how many people are affected.
This year it is estimated that one in four Canadian women will experience sexual assault, yet fewer than one in 10 will report it. Unless we make it known to Canadian women and back it up with legislation that they need not fear a double assault, an emotional assault in the law courts, then we will not see an improvement in these statistics.
The other thing that Bill C-49 will do is make all Canadians aware of sexual assault law. There is no question that in this area women practise denial, as do men. "It cannot happen to me" or "It cannot happen to my sister, my wife, my daughter. It can't, it can't, it
can't". It can, Madam Speaker, we all know it can, and we know sadly that the streets are not safe for Canadian women. We know that. We know that Canadian women are not safe in their houses from assault. All of us know the horror of the case involving the 911 line in Calgary, when a woman called while a man was trying to break in through her back door and police protocol was such that they did not respond in time. We all felt the horror to some degree that the woman must have felt when she lived through that experience. Only an awareness of how widespread sexual assault is will lead to the proper protocols and the proper responses.
One of the most important things in Bill C-49 with regard to an attitude change is the message that no means no. Interestingly enough, this is the message that has received the most intense response.
If this subject were not so serious and so crucial to the well-being of not just Canadian women but Canadian society in general, I could almost say that I am faintly amused by the response. I have had men of my acquaintance say to me things-I mean, seriously, one man said to me: "Well, it's sure not going to make courtship much fun". My response was: "Gee, dates with you must have been really terrific".
I do not know what people who are afraid of the no means no statement in the law are really afraid of. The amendment brought forward by the government and supported by our side of the House that you remove all reasonable means to establish consent to reasonable means, is indeed a reasonable amendment. But I am not sure what the difficulty is in the minds of those people who still think that this is going to create a terrible tyranny on men in their social endeavours in this country.
It is true that a great deal of what passes between men and women in these relationships is tacit. But what women are saying is that too much has been taken for granted and taken tacitly for granted. When we have had in this country a woman who was deaf and mute, who kicked and screamed and fought back, and a judge still said that she had not been able to establish her lack of consent, I think that the women of this country have a right to stand up and say: "We want it explicit that no means no".

When we have had a judge of the Supreme Court of British Columbia call a three year old girl sexually aggressive-it is so difficult to encompass the thought it is almost hard to say the words-then women in this country, and men too, have a right to see a law that says no means no.
When we have had a judge in the Northwest Territories say that: "It does not matter as much if you assault native women because they are either drunk or asleep", then the time is long overdue for a law in this country that says no means no.
The time has come for all Canadians to understand that there is a responsibility in social relationships. Women are not playing games when they say no. Women are in the vast majority of cases not walking around on the earth to torment and bedevil men, although with the greatest of respect sometimes that might not be such a bad idea. Women have a right to say what they want and what they do not want, and if they happen to say it in a bar room or in a bedroom or on a beach, or in a public street, the location does not matter, the circumstances do not matter. What matters is that no means no.
Again and again we have heard from various groups that this is going to be impossible to establish. That is one of the stupidest things I have ever heard.
I said to a rather well-known lawyer in this country who made that statement at committee: "Which word did you not understand?" I think that phrase is something all of us should carry forward in arguing in support of the no means no section of this bill.
For too long the tacit belief that women when they say no mean yes has been accepted and has been laughed about and joked about. For too long there has been some sort of general belief among a certain segment of the male population and I want to make perfectly clear to all of my esteemed colleagues that I do not put all of them in that category. I put some of them in there but not all of them.
The response is such that women have a right to be taken seriously and what this law finally does is take the reactions and the responses of women seriously. It may be more difficult. It may make social interaction more complicated and complex, although I cannot imagine how that could possibly be the case, it is so complicated and complex right now.
Government Orders
Unquestionably it is what we must have. Unquestionably it is what we must put in the Criminal Code for the protection of women in this country.
It is a sign to the judges, to the police officers, to lawyers and to society in general that sexual assault is not a joke and it will not be tolerated. It is something we need to say to judges when we stand here in this Chamber and know that 40 per cent of Canadian judges have yet to avail themselves of the gender sensitivity training courses.
I have already listed in my remarks this afternoon the most outstanding shall we say, of horrifying comments by judges in the area of sexual assault. I know of another judge in this country who hears the majority of sexual assault cases in his particular jurisdiction and on the rare occasions when he convicts will give intermittent sentences or very light sentences, sentences that show he just does not take these offences seriously.
We have to make a change. This legislation is a step in making that change. While the government still refuses to institute mandatory training for federally appointed judges, then all the more reason to support legislation of this nature. We must have something that the women of this country can depend upon to protect them in the rising epidemic of sexual assault, and the rising epidemic of violence against women.
This is not an anti-men amendment. This is not going to change the actions of the vast majority of good, decent men who live their lives understanding that women have a perfect right to make their intentions known.
It is going to make a difference to that subspecies of humanity that does not seem to believe that women have a right to make a choice. When we lost the old amendments to the code after the Seaboyer and Gayme decision, it was absolutely crucial that the government step in with new amendments. Bill C-49 fulfils, to the best of its ability in this particular circumstance, the steps which must be taken for the proper admission of evidence.
I want to say a few words about the preamble to the bill. The preamble makes special mention of the prevalence of the crime against women and children. We know that this is absolutely so. We also support the naming of doubly disadvantaged groups: visible minorities; sex-trade workers; disabled persons; lesbians and those whose immigration status is questionable. Unfortunately the government did not accept that.

June 15, 1992
Government Orders
We are also aware that the preamble to the bill does not really have much of an influence on courts per se so we had wanted both of these changes to be moved to the body of the bill to give it more weight in a court of law.
The last time that we brought forward sexual assault amendments to the code we lost them after a number of years under the charter in the Supreme Court of Canada. There is no doubt in my mind, nor do I think there is doubt in anyone else's mind, that these amendments will also be the subject of a charter challenge.
We support this bill and we hope it will survive the charter challenge. If it does not then we will have to go back to the drawing board once again because this issue is perhaps the most crucial issue that women have to fight under the Criminal Code of Canada.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to join with my colleagues from the committee and the Minister of Justice in this debate today on the third reading of Bill C-49.
First I want to say that I was pleased to be a member of the legislative committee. The committee worked very well and co-operatively in hearing the witnesses and extracting from them substantive arguments and some technical amendments. We put them forward and the committee process was one of consensus and co-operation. I am pleased that it was so. I am also pleased that we were able to agree on the amendments and bring them forward.
I am very proud to be part of a government that has made security of women in our society a priority. Our government recognizes that security of the person and the ability to live without fear are essential to women's achievement of equality. We have taken action to ensure that these fundamental rights for women are protected in Canada.
Bill C-49 is evidence of our government's and society's efforts to ensure the security of women who are victims of sexual assault.
Last August the Supreme Court of Canada struck down section 276 of the Criminal Code in the Seaboyer decision which governed the reception of evidence of a victim's sexual history during the course of a sexual assault trial. The Supreme Court of Canada held that section 276 overshot or overstepped the mark in protecting complainants. That decision evoked expressions of concern from many women and women's groups. If assailants could use the provisions of the charter of rights to strike down protections such as the rape shield provision, it would seem that the justice system was offering greater protection to the assailant than to the victim.
The government moved quickly to respond to these concerns. It was a narrow decision by the Supreme Court, but the perception was that women did not have very much protection and, in some cases, they did not. Therefore, we had to move very quickly.
The Minister of Justice undertook an immediate consultative process with women's groups, the bar, provincial and territorial governments and other legal experts to canvass as many views as possible on the direction that the new law should take.
I would emphasize that it was the consensus, and I would say society's consensus, that the new law had to take into account today's reality of violence against women. The Minister of Justice agreed.
Bill C-49, an act to amend the Criminal Code regarding sexual assault, received first reading in the House of Commons on December 12, 1991. It is of landmark value in protecting the rights of women victims of sexual assault.
The bill provides for strict guidelines in determining the admissibility of past sexual history as evidence and outlines clearly the procedure which must be followed in admitting such evidence. According to the bill's provisions, evidence of the victim's sexual activity would not be admissible unless that evidence was specific, was relevant to the issue to be proved, and its probative value
June 15, 1992

was not substantially outweighed by the danger of prejudice to the proper administration of justice.
The bill also legally defines for the first time the concept of consent, a definition of consent to sexual activity, that is clear and unambiguous. Under the present law, a man accused of sexual assault can be acquitted if he can persuade a judge that he honestly believed the woman consented.
Under the legislation proposed by Bill C-49, the test of consent would be whether the woman's behaviour was sufficient to convince an objective third party that the woman had agreed to the man's sexual advances. Bill C-49 clearly states that submission does not signal consent nor does silence and that is very important. Under this bill, no clearly means no. This means a great deal to the women of Canada.
Also, for the first time in the history of Canadian common law, or one of the few times, the bill has a preamble. This was the subject of much discussion and debate.
When I found out that I would be sitting on the committee, I sent letters to constituents who had expressed an interest in issues affecting women. I sent them copies of the bill and some of the information about the bill and I asked them for their advice.
One woman, a professor at the University of Alberta, Professor Susan Jackel, wrote me a four-page letter in response. She is a professor of history and Canadian studies and also has offered advice to the government on constitutional matters. She is not a lawyer. I want to quote what she had to say on the preamble. I believe this to be very important.
I cannot tell you how important it is to the women of Canada to see their own experience and understanding reflected in the wording of a law, not only in its technical sections, but in the general statement at the beginning about the values of Canadian society. To read that "the Parliament of Canada is gravely concerned about the incidence of sexual violence and abuse in Canadian society"; that Parliament is likewise cognizant of "how sexual assault and, more particularly, the fear of sexual assault affect the lives of the people of Canada"; and that "the Parliament of Canada wishes to encourage the reporting of incidents of sexual violence or abuse," in the interests of justice for all Canadians, is indeed a milestone.
She goes on to say:
Much of my recent research on the history of women as citizens of Canada, and as activists in the reform of law, has uncovered a long, rather regrettable story of many intelligent women's sense of alienation from the laws that govern them. Women have seen the
Government Orders
law as an oppressive, or at best insensitive, instrument when it comes to the daily reality of their lives.
This departure from the practice of common law, to put a preamble to a bill, is welcomed by women in society for these very reasons. It provides guidance to the courts. It interprets the daily lives and fears and the reality of violence against women for those who read the law. I believe that is very important.
The amendments of Bill C-49 are of crucial importance in protecting the rights of women who have been victims of sexual assault. These women should not have to be revictimized in the course of bringing the accused to justice. Bill C-49 sends a clear message that our society will not tolerate sexual assault or any other form of violence against women.
Once again, I want to quote from Professor Jackel's letter. It was four pages long and she puts it in much better words than I can. It is important to read what she has to say about sexual assault and put it on the record. She states:
The fact of sexual assault is part of that oppression for a minority of women; the fear of such assault-and it is present in the vast majority of women, in many circumstances-is one of the major impediments to free, trusting relationships between men and women.
She goes on to say:
As a professor and student advisor, I am especially aware of the limitations that women place upon themselves in pursuing their studies, out of justified caution about being in the wrong place at the wrong time. Women students make academic decisions-not to take an evening course, not to study in the library in the evenings, not to take a course that might end in their being labelled "feminist"- because of fear. Combating that fear, through the law and the administration of justice, is thus not only a security-of-the-person issue, but it is also an equality issue, as defined in sections 15 and 28 of the Charter.
She says further:
Women who cannot take equal advantage of education and training opportunities out of fear are at a disadvantage relative to men. The law should act positively to ameliorate this disadvantage, without removing the safeguards that are needed for an over-all balanced approach to justice.
That is what this law does. It helps remove the fear women have about the law itself and about how they will be treated before the courts and within the judicial system. I believe that is important.
I want to thank Professor Jackel for her advice to me which I was able to bring forward to the committee.
The Prime Minister has said that one Canadian woman suffering violence at home or elsewhere is one too many. Therefore our government has made a priority in putting an end to violence against women.

Government Orders
Our government's goal is zero tolerance. Our commitment to that goal is evident in the federal family violence initiative announced in February 1991. It is providing $136 million over four years for programs in the area of health and social services, criminal justice, community action, housing and support services for aboriginal communities.
Women's security is a key focus of the family violence initiative. As children, as seniors and at all ages in between, women are the most frequent victims of family violence. Through the family violence initiative our government has pledged to work closely with its partners in society to eliminate family violence through activities such as the promotion of community-based projects, the creation of new emergency shelters for women and support for training for police and the judiciary in understanding the depth and breadth of family violence.
I would also note that an estimated one-quarter of the federal government's Canada Assistance Plan contributions to the provinces and territories is used to provide support to victims of family violence.
I would also like to point to our government's establishment last August of the Canadian Panel on Violence Against Women. This is the first comprehensive national examination of violence against women that has ever been undertaken in this country and indeed, the first of its kind in the world.
Co-chaired by Pat Freeman Marshall of Tbronto and Marthe Asselin Vaillancourt of Jonquiere, Quebec, the panel's members are representative of Canada's best knowledge, experience, sensitivity and leadership on this issue.
The panel has been mandated to examine the issue of violence against women through an interactive, responsive and grassroots dialogue. It has embarked upon an intensive schedule of consultations in large and small communities across Canada in an effort to reach all possible participants including victims of violence, frontline, social service, education and health care workers, and other community members.
The panel began its operations in September and has visited so far more than 130 communities in all of Canada's provinces and territories.
Early next month, the panel will issue an interim report which will provide an overview of its work done so far and what panel members have heard in the course of their public consultations, as well as preliminary proposals for eliminating violence against women. This will set the stage for the second round of the panel's public consultations which will begin again this summer.
We can expect the panel's final report in December. It will include recommendations and a concrete plan of action to help make Canadian society safer and more equitable for women.
In conclusion, our government considers the security of women in society to be of absolute paramount importance. I thank the many members of this House who have made a significant contribution through their support and through their personal efforts to the advancement of women's equality in society.
I want to quote once again from Professor Jackel as she sums up her letter to me providing advice on Bill C-49: "I know that you and your colleagues will listen carefully to all presenters at your committee hearings, but I hope that in the end your decision will be to recommend this bill to Parliament substantially unchanged. I believe it has been drafted with care and deserves to become law".
I believe that also. I call on members of the House to support us in making this bill law.

Mr. Speaker, in most cases the women of Canada have benefited from the decisions of the Supreme Court. Our justices have, for example, upheld the laws that ban the production and importation of hard-core pornography. Unfortunately, this type of enlightened and progressive vision was abandoned when the high court struck down the provision of the Criminal Code known as rape shield.
The women of Canada were angered by the court's decision because they viewed this action as a direct assault on their security. The decision in effect would allow for continued victimization of women who have been sexually assaulted.
The decision gave defence attorneys the right to raise a woman's past sexual experiences and use them as relevant testimony in determining consent. The lack of a rape shield provision would result in brutal cross-examination of women by defence lawyers who are seeking to
June 15, 1992

discredit a victim's testimony based on negative stereotypes of women.
It is time for the cycle of victimization to end. No in every conceivable circumstance means no. Men must realize that sex is a matter for two mutually consenting adults. The old power games must be put to rest. The antiquated and unrealistic view of sexuality must be shelved. This is not a time for subtlety or for carefully selected words. Far too many children and women have fallen prey to this insidious violence against their bodies and their minds.
This is why I find myself in the unusual or awkward position of having to praise the government for its swift action. I share the Minister of Justice's concern when she says we must protect the rights of rape victims. This is why I am more than happy to support this law.
Bill C-49 is the first piece of legislation in history that is founded both on the experience and expertise of women. This is a bill that recognizes the reality of a rape trial and takes into account the constitutional rights of both the accused and the victim.
The most important element of this bill is that it says a complainant's sexual history is rarely relevant. By admitting such evidence, the court would be seriously compromising the woman's case as to consent.
It completely boggles my mind that because a woman consented to sex the previous week, the last hour, or if she had sex many times with different men, that somehow this previous consent applies to every subsequent sexual advance.
This bill was introduced in December of last year and will hopefully fill the gap left by the Supreme Court Seaboyer and Gayme case.
The preamble of this bill is essential in clearly expressing to the people of Canada this House's collective condemnation of sexual violence, not only against women but against children as well. This law is the first in the Criminal Code to have a preamble that explicitly says a victim's sexual past is rarely relevant.
I find it strange that some segments of society have ridiculed this legislation. I am certain that many members of this House have seen caricatures in the newspa-
Govemment Orders
pers that portray lawyers sitting behind an amorous couple arranging the affidavits, making certain that consent is established.
Consent is the crux of sexual assault trials. If it has been established that consent has been given, the woman's claim of attack is rejected. It is imperative that the law be absolutely clear on this matter, as must the partners involved in the sexual activity.
The bill states that consent is the voluntary agreement of the complainant to engage in the sexual activity in question. There is no need for lawyers to be present. All you need are two people who understand each other's needs and open and frank communication.
Refusing to talk about sex can lead to very serious problems. By talking to our partners we establish clear guidelines as to what is acceptable and welcome behaviour and what is, for lack of any other description, a violent attack.
This act invalidates consent obtained under certain circumstances such as agreement through a third party or when a complainant is incapable of consenting to sex by reason of intoxication or any other conditions. This law will invalidate consent when the accused has abused their position of power or authority.
Finally, the law allows women to change their minds and refuse consent at any juncture.
These provisions recognize the reality of sexual assault. They tell us that the government recognizes that far too often women have been forced to engage in sexual activities by their bosses for fear of losing their jobs. They recognize that women and children are often in subordinate positions and are at high risk of being victimized. It also acknowledges and addresses the painful reality that often the perpetrators of sexual assault are friends, relatives, or co-workers of the victims.
Bill C-49 also recognizes that the incapacity to refuse consent by reasons of intoxication is by no means consent. Men can no longer use that defensive, mistaken belief concerning consent. This bill makes people responsible for their actions. Because an individual has had too much to drink and because of this irresponsible behaviour one believes that consent was obtained is hardly a reason to let him off the hook.

June 15, 1992
Government Orders

Bill C-49 will finally give women the tools they need to confront their assailants.
It is reported in 1992 that one woman in four, or 25 per cent of the female population, has been sexually assaulted, but less than one in 10 report it. Since the law seems to have been written for the accused rather than for the victim, only 5 per cent of those accused of sexual assault were convicted.
For too long, our society has accepted violence and assault against women as a man's right and a symbol of his superiority. I am glad that we are daring to abolish that myth today.
Nevertheless, I find it hard to take that in the late 20th century, we must have recourse to the law to ensure women's right to say no. We have a great deal to learn about communication and respect.
This legislation has been eagerly awaited for a long time. I must congratulate the Minister of Justice here for her efficiency. Although I do not always agree with what the government does, I cannot overlook this major step for the greater welfare of women in particular.
It is high time for our society to face the problem of violence. We must stop finding excuses and instead look at reality as it is. The reason this bill is before the House today is that our society is seriously sick and the only way we know to exercise control is through the law.
This is no fairy tale and we all have our work cut out for us to make this society human again.
The preamble of Bill C-49 is a guide so that lawyers and judges understand the importance of discretion regarding the sexual history of the complainant, who is usually a woman. It recognizes the unique character of this kind of offence, as well as its effects on the population. It reminds us how serious this offence is.
Historically, a woman's sexual history and reputation were considered relevant evidence, since it was accepted that loose morals were an indication of her consent.
With Bill C-49, regardless of a person's past, consent still means saying yes and no will always mean refusal of consent. Unfortunately, for far too many men, the law will remain an abstraction. Men must organize so that the problem comes out in the open. Their education
must begin with their peers if we really want to work on stopping this violence. It must start today.
Some steps have been taken and the white ribbon campaign is an example. This must continue. Men of all ages assault women; men of all ages deny it; men of all ages do not want to admit that there is a problem, that they have had a problem. But still, all these men have had at least one woman in their life, their mother.
We are barely beginning to lift the veil on all the violence and assault in the military world. As soon as the veil is lifted, voices are raised to lower the veil again and deny what is going on. This happened just a few months ago. What are we afraid of? Do we always have to go to court to protect those who have been assaulted, always after the damage is done?
Despite what many people think, sexual assault is not only physical assault. The human being as a person is violated. It leaves a deep wound that can never be forgotten, even if it can be survived. It is the violation of someone's body. In too many cases, it is done on a bet or a dare, as an initiation rite or an act of wild misbehaviour. It is using someone else to satisfy a desire, nothing else, like merchandise that is discarded once it is no longer needed. That is what we do when we let ourselves go-

The bill was modified somewhat during the legislative committee process. Aside from a few minor technical changes, there are three major amendments. The preamble to the bill was changed to make special mention of the prevalence of sexual assault against women and children.
We supported this amendment. However, we hoped that it would mention certain doubly disadvantaged groups such as visible minority women, sex-trade workers, disabled persons, lesbians and those whose immigration status is questionable. Unfortunately this was not accepted by the government.
We also requested that the preamble be moved to the main body of the legislation so that the statement it makes would carry more weight in a court of law. Originally the legislation required that the accused take all reasonable steps to ascertain consent. The bill was amended by the government with the support of our party so that it now reads "take reasonable steps to ascertain consent".

Government Orders
It is imperative that the new legislation be able to meet any new charter challenge. We do not want to find ourselves in the same situation as we did after last fall's Supreme Court decision.
The final amendment put forward by the government allows for the publication of a judge's decision when the judge allows evidence of a complainant's prior sexual history to be used in the trial. This decision would allow for such publication on a case by case basis.
I hope this bill will give the women of this country security and confidence in the justice system. I hope it will remove the fear that women could be victimized a second time by a system that is insensitive to the nature of sexual assault.

Bill C-49 is a step in the right direction to start protecting victims of sexual assault. It is a first step, but it is up to all of us to work at rooting out the causes of sexual assault. The economy must pick up so that people work. Above all, men must be educated to respect their partner and look for help when they lose control. Women must be educated to protect themselves and use the few available resources to be able to recover.
Our society is very sick when people are only considered commodities. We must all work to restore every woman's pride in who she is. We must all get involved, if only by realizing that all our sexist behaviour, from the jokes we tell to what we do, makes it harder to leam mutual respect. That is one attitude to correct and the House of Commons is a good place to practise what we preach.
We cannot expect the law to solve all problems. Together we formulate rules for our society and together we must see that they are enforced. We each have a role to play in ensuring that our children enjoy a better quality of life than those who live on the street. Violence and sexual assault must no longer be the lot of women and children, and all of us, you and I, must see to it starting today.

Madam Speaker, I rise to speak again on Bill C-49, the new sexual assault law.
I am disappointed that most of the amendments I proposed did not pass. The amendments I put forward were those drafted by a large number of diverse women's organizations. Unfortunately some women's organizations have withdrawn their support of this bill because important amendments were not included.
One of these amendments is the naming of women who are most vulnerable to violence and who have the least access to our justice system. One of the amendments that did pass was the amendment that changed "all reasonable steps" to simply "reasonable steps".
I was alone on the committee in voting against that amendment because I believe that the provision "all reasonable steps" would have passed the charter challenge, as a number of legal experts across the country also believe that it would survive a charter challenge.
The committee which studied the sexual assault bill heard over and over again from prostitutes, disabled women, black women, aboriginal women and immigrant women that some women believe that the justice system does not serve them, that there is no point in reporting assault to the police or going to court because their race, ability and type of employment are held against them.
These women wanted their situation clearly spelled out in the bill to let doubly disadvantaged women know that this law is meant for them also and to let police, lawyers and judges know that their concerns are to be taken seriously.
In addition to being sexually assaulted, many women have further pain and humiliation in store when they try to access our justice system.
Many Canadians, including some members of this House, do not understand the depth of the pain and violation that is involved in sexual assault. They do not understand the effect sexual assault has on women. They think of it as sex that got out of hand rather than an act of violence which often leads women to suicide, to drug and alcohol use, to fear, hatred, disgust, nightmares,

Government Orders
severe eating disorders, debilitating insecurity and selfblame, anxiety attacks and problems in relationships.
One in five rape victims attempts suicide as opposed to one in 50 non-assaulted women. Sixty per cent of female clients receiving treatment for drug and alcohol abuse at a treatment centre were found to be victims of sexual assault.
Those are some of the long-term psychological effects.
Physical effects of sexual assault can include permanent physical disability, unwanted pregnancy, sexually transmitted disease, including AIDS, broken bones, bruises and death. Our society still expects women to take responsibility for sexual assault. It does not expect the victim of any other crime to take that responsibility. It does not expect people who have been injured by a drunk driver to have worn brighter clothing or driven a brightly coloured car. Everybody knows the responsibility lies with people not to drive drunk.
For the first time, sexual assault laws will be brought into line with the other laws of our nation. It is the responsibility of people not to commit sexual assaults. Some people think that if women did not go out at night that would reduce the risk of sexual assault. What about the hundreds of women who are assaulted on university campuses? This kind of logic says that maybe they should stop going to university.
What about women who are assaulted in their work places? Should they stop going to work? Should we stop walking on our streets? Should we not go to the grocery store, not visit our family and our friends? One woman was sexually assaulted while shovelling her own driveway in winter in broad daylight. Maybe women should stay at home.
However, the majority of sexual assaults occur in a private home. Women are actually safer on the streets than in their homes. So where do we go to be safe? The problem with changing women's behaviour to avoid sexual assault is that no matter what we do, no matter where we are, no matter what we look like, and no matter what we wear we are targets for sexual assaults. Some are targets even more than others because as a result of their race or because they are poor or a
prostitute they are more vulnerable and less likely to be believed.
The problem is not women's behaviour. The problem is the behaviour and attitudes of the men who commit this crime. This should be the focus. We are going to stop sexual assaults by convicting the men who commit them and by changing attitudes so that our society no longer tolerates them.
Most women are sexually assaulted by men they know. Often the men are men they are supposed to trust and have faith in, such as their fathers, teachers, priests, doctors and friends.
A Canadian study of sex offenders reveals that their profile does not deviate from the average male. There is no one out there who has sex offender written on his forehead. The rehabilitation programs for sex offenders in prison are notoriously ineffective.
They concentrate on sex rather than on violence, power and negative attitudes toward women. Rape is a crime of power, a crime of anger and ignorance, not a crime of sex. It does not matter what a woman is wearing or not wearing. Nowhere in the Charter of Rights and Freedoms does it state that one's human rights, that one's right to security of the person is suspended because of an item of clothing.
Different cultures and different people within a culture have very different ideas about what constitutes too little clothing. Clothing does not say yes or no, only people can do that.
Sexual assault happens to women of all ages, from three months to well into their nineties. Studies show that women who are disabled are far more likely to be sexually assaulted than other women because they are more vulnerable and often less believed.
The portrayal of women in the media and in pornography reinforces beliefs about women asking for it. Fifty-six per cent of men in a study reported that pornography played a role in their offences. A study of video pornography found that 13 per cent of all the scenes involved sexual violation, including rape, sexual harassment, sado-masochism and sexual mutilation.
A national survey of Canadians' use of pornography showed that young men aged 12 to 17 are the primary consumers of pornography. Thirty-five per cent of these

young men expressed an interest in watching sexually violent scenes, including rape, torture and bondage.
The day our society says that it is not natural for boys to be interested in these things is the day that our society stops feeding our young men material that tells them it is fun to rape women and that women enjoy it. That will be another step forward in ending violence against women.
A number of respected studies have found a link between violent and dehumanizing pornography and the acceptance of rape myths, acceptance of violence against women, decrease in sensitivity to the suffering of rape victims and an increase in male willingness to rape.
I congratulate the Supreme Court of Canada on the Butler decision, in which it said once and for all that the problem of pornography was violence and dehumanization, not explicit sex.
As with sexual assault the issue is not sex but violence and degradation. Police officers, customs officers, lawyers and judges need education to examine these issues so that they will not assume that gay or lesbian erotica is necessarily obscene while the rape and torture of women and children is not.
Rarely do we see the pain of sexual assault reflected. Rarely do we see the real victims. Rarely do we see the racism and hatred that often accompanies sexual assault.
Aboriginal women and women of colour have been victims of racist attacks. There are no available statistics on this type of violence. Just over a year ago a white man was convicted of drugging, raping and videotaping 50 young native women aged 11 to 17. In Vancouver another white man targeted aboriginal women. He sexually assaulted nine women and forced them to continue to drink until they died.
I have often heard, in defence of a sexual assault law without strength or substance, that women lie about sexual assault. In fact, the opposite is true. A Winnipeg study showed that 87 per cent of sexual assault victims did not report the crime to the police. A further 12 per cent told no one at all. The reason is because it is humiliating, costly and emotionally debilitating for women to access the criminal justice system on this issue.
Forty-seven per cent of those who did not report it said they believed that the police would do nothing about it. They believed the police and courts had negative attitudes toward women and victims of sexual assault.
Government Orders
Thirty-five per cent feared another assault by the attacker if they did report it and 64 per cent said that fear and shame kept them from reporting it.
When a woman reports sexual assault her private life is open to scrutiny as if it is anyone else's business, in a manner that no victim of any other crime is put on trial. She does not even get a lawyer to represent her. While the accused can access legal aid, she cannot. She merely has the status of a witness of a crime committed against her own body.
I have been told how police, Crown attorneys and judges can be insensitive to sexual assault victims, taking their cues from pornography, the media and misinformation rather than from compassion and reality.
An aboriginal woman from the Northwest Territories was forcibly taken from her home in Vancouver, handcuffed, confined in a space with a violent man and made to testify. Was she a criminal? No, she was the victim of a sexual assault. The man she was confined with was the man who had beaten and raped her. What other victim of a crime would be treated in this way?
The profound ignorance and insensitivity of too many police officers, lawyers and judges keeps women from reporting crimes and testifying. Many women also fear reprisals on the part of the rapist because there is no protection for them. Sometimes women just want to forget and get on with their lives rather than be tormented by the court process and wait for up to a year for the trial to come to court and be finished with.
It is finally time for that to end. This law is one legislative step. It must be accompanied by mandatory training for judges, lawyers and police officers on issues of violence against women and children, and on women's equality issues.
This law means very little when many women are afraid of the criminal justice process because they fear it will only revictimize them. Just because a woman has had sex with a partner before does not mean she has given her consent for ever and ever. No means no. It means no when the woman is a virgin; it means no when the woman is married; it means no when the woman has had several boyfriends; it means no if the woman is lesbian; it means no when she is disabled; it means no when she is a prostitute; it means no when she is homeless. There is never any excuse for sexually assaulting any woman or any child.

June 15, 1992
Government Orders
No means no and that is the end of it. It is clear and it is simple. We must train girls to know what their rights are and boys what their responsibilities are. Everyone- girls and women, boys and men-has the right to say no to sex. It is the responsibility of boys and men to take that no seriously.
There were amendments that I had hoped to see included in this bill, but unfortunately they were not. I still support the bill. It is a small legislative step toward that eventual goal of ending the unequal status of women and children in our society and creating a safe and open society for all of Canada's people.

Madam Speaker, I also rise to take part in this debate. I was a member of the legislative committee. I was not a member of any of the previous committees but on the legislative committee I had very mixed feelings toward the bill.
These mixed views that I hold on the bill come from many directions. As a woman I have to say that I understand the reasons for the purpose of this bill. I also have to say that I would have liked to have seen other elements brought into consideration along with this bill. There are other stronger considerations I would have liked to have seen, but I will deal with them later in my speech.
The purpose of this bill is to tell Canadians that Parliament will no longer tolerate violence against women, particularly sexual assault.
As a lawyer I have mixed views because many of the witnesses who appeared before us have said that the bill will be challenged. As a lawyer I have to understand on what basis it will be challenged.
It will probably be challenged on the basis that this bill makes no distinction between an intentional rape or sexual assault and an unintentional rape or sexual assault. I say rape and sexual assault because rape is no longer in the Criminal Code. It is incorporated under the terms of sexual assault. I will also deal with that if I have the opportunity later. I really think that rape should be a specific section within the Criminal Code. When we can prove rape we should be proving the most offensive
violence against women. As a lawyer I find it very wrong that it is not specifically there in the code.
I would like to discuss something that Professor Stuart of Queen's University said to the committee, specifically as it relates to the particular area of concern that I have about the bill being challenged under section 7. This is in reference to something said by Chief Justice Lamer.
In one of his cases he stated that there must be a difference between an intentional and an unintentional crime. As a legislator it pains me to think that we could not have come up with a better bill that would not be challenged as soon as it became law.
In the preamble the reasons for the bill are set out. It is very good to set out a preamble, but if we are using a bill to tell Canadians and educate society that this bill means serious business it seems to me that a preamble will get lost in those many statutes passed here in Parliament and across Canada.
It should have been incorporated somewhere in the Criminal Code prior to this as a preamble specifically with a sunset clause to show that after a while we should review it to see if the purpose of the legislation had been followed through or not. Therefore I really do feel, as my colleagues have said, that preamble should have been specific not just in terms of violence against women and children but specifically against doubly disadvantaged women, those groups that came before us to present their case for having a preamble that would represent visible minority women, disabled women, sex trade workers and rape crisis centre clients. They were particularly insistent in naming women who were perceived to be doubly disadvantaged. We could go on to say there are other groups that would be classified as being doubly disadvantaged.
If the minister was using a preamble to educate or to tell the judiciary and the lawyers what was the purpose of the law, then I felt it should have gone further in an attempt to hit specifically and target the doubly disabled groups. It is not doing that. It is saying women and children. Unless the woman who comes in to make a complaint looks like the policeman's wife or daughter, sometimes it is very difficult for him to believe the person is really saying: "I am serious about the charge, about the sexual assault that has just happened".

I do not think it was strong enough, for that reason, in the preamble or in incorporating it somewhere in the Criminal Code in terms of a sunset clause or in terms of a clear direction to the courts and to the enforcement people.
The women and the groups that have worked hard on this matter should be disappointed because they did not obtain a preamble for which they had worked very hard with the minister. Society as a whole knows that violence against women exists. If they are allowing Parliament to pass this legislation, they want it to be the best possible to stop the violence right away.
By the same token, I have said that there were definitely two groups of witnesses. Most of the women's groups supported the bill but wanted to see a stronger preamble. The others, the lawyers and those involved in civil liberties-no one was opposed to the purposes of the bill-felt that it lacked integrity in the sense that it would be challenged.
Probably the most important point about the preamble is the direction it gives. If a preamble gets lost in the shuffle, it has very little effect except to remind people. No judge has to be bound by a preamble whether or not what Parliament hoped to achieve by this bill is actually being followed through.
Another thing I want to say is from a legal point of view. It is difficult to pass a bill when, before it is even passed, different groups say that it will be challenged before. This bill will be challenged. It will be challenged on the mistaken belief section because it limits a defence present in the law for other crimes, shall we say. In the case of murder, if one does not have the specific intent one can be charged with manslaughter because it was a general intent.
When we do away with the mens rea that is so much a part of the Criminal Code in Canada, that specific intent, then it will be challenged.
Professor Stuart, who I thought had a very interesting brief, said there should be something to the effect that we have a negligent sexual assault with a five-year maximum. He said: "Given the above concerns about fairness to the accused"-and I mentioned that earlier-"and possible constitutional problems, it is suggested that section 273.2 be replaced by a provision declaring that where an accused is charged with an offence under section 271, 272 or 273, where the accused
Government Orders
has a belief in consent but did not take reasonable steps to ascertain whether the complainant was consenting, the accused is guilty of an offence punishable on indictment with a penalty of five years imprisonment". This would take into account the person who is intoxicated and who cannot form an intent. Yet he will be found guilty, as Professor Stuart said, of a negligent sexual assault.
We are leaving too much confusion for the courts. I think what will happen is that this will become a very costly bill. Women will find that they will present a case. It will be appealed and it will be thrown out. It will become discouraging.
I realize it is encouraging that it will be made easier for women to take the process into court because of the present law, but I think women will become discouraged very quickly because it is an imperfect law. As a legislator I feel that it should be a perfect bill. If we are going to do a strict liability, that if one is intoxicated is no defence and it is the same liability as someone who took the specific intent to commit a sexual assault on a woman, we are educating Canadians in a very tough way.
I have to admire the present advertising that is being done by the Government of Ontario in terms of telling the people of Ontario that when out on a date they could be committing a sexual assault unless there is consent. It follows through from that.
By the same token, there is no education. The minister has said that there is a panel to review violence against women. Yet in the news this weekend or this past week we heard that the people on the panel were upset. The National Action Committee has said that the panel is not representing the purposes for which it was set up and has questions on that.
There is no more Court Challenges Program. Women cannot challenge decisions or find money to challenge decisions. I see a bill that should have been better perfected to enable a clear direction. Maybe there should be a panel that reviews a judge's decision that has been so clearly offensive to society in terms of a judge, as he reviews a woman before his court, saying there was no crime.
I just feel that we are passing a bill for which the purpose is very relevant, very much a part of our society, and very much a part that is not only distasteful but hateful and against women. Yet we are not talking about education in the schools, education in the universities, or education of the general population, those in law enforcement or our judicial process.

Government Orders
We are passing something that again leaves women exposed. We did not even put in a preamble as groups of women that came before our committee wanted. We made a few changes, mostly as a result of the Canadian Bar Association. They will perhaps improve the bill but they will not stop the challenges.
I have said already in the House tonight that I think a bill people say will be challenged before is perhaps, as some women say, better than no bill, but I find it a bit of a disservice. I find it will allow lawyers to take more challenges to court in an already heavily overworked court system in terms of the charter.
If we wanted better justice in this bill, we would have clearly stated that it was a liability, that if one was drunk one was liable on a sexual assault. We should have noted the difference, that if one is drunk and has a specific intent to go out and rape a person or sexually assault a person tonight then there is a difference. That should be noted. The crime is the crime but for the person who is intoxicated, if found guilty of the assault, the punishment is the same.
Another area I found wanting is when it comes down to the determination of allowing the voir dire, under what grounds we will allow the admissibility of past sexual history. Again I think it will be challenged unfortunately because it could go to the very basis of the truth of the matter, the full answer, and the defence.
I just think we could have passed a better bill, a stronger bill with a preamble. We could have passed a bill that would have precluded any arguments on the defence, but we would have excluded the consent based on the argument that there is no defence based on belief of consent or doing away with somebody's basic right of mistaken belief.
We could have said it clearer in this bill and we would have been telling Canadians that no means no, that there is a no means no law. At the same time we would have been telling the courts, the legal system, that there are no loopholes and that it will not be challenged the day after or the first time a charge is laid in court by a complainant. There will be a negative to what should be a good bill. This has been my concern from the beginning about this bill both as a woman who knows what is happening out there and as a lawyer who has heard in committee that it will be challenged and knows full well why it will be challenged. As a legislators I think we could have done better on a bill we all agree on so that it would not be challenged the day after it is passed.
Madam Speaker, it is about two or three minutes to six o'clock. Might we call it she o'clock so the bells might begin?
